('59', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. LETTER TO N. H. PURANDARE
('59', 0, 2, 3, 72) January 13, 1933
('59', 0, 3, 4, 89) MY DEAR PURANDARE, I have your letter.
('59', 0, 3, 5, 128) I am sorry to have had it.
('59', 0, 3, 6, 155) I don’t like the spirit underlying it.
('59', 0, 3, 7, 194) You have looked upon the whole thing as a commercial transaction, whereas I have looked upon the whole thing as a matter of selfless service.
('59', 0, 3, 8, 336) You left the question of remuneration entirely in my hands, although I asked you to tell me what you would charge for giving me a corrected collection of your speeches on untouchability and for supervising the printing.
('59', 0, 3, 9, 556) But you would not think of it, telling me that there was no mercenary motive behind it.
('59', 0, 3, 10, 644) That being so, I had no hesitation in undertaking the delicate task, but at the end of it, I shirked it, and I asked Haribhau to name the sum.
('59', 0, 3, 11, 787) He named Rs. 125 and I straightaway accepted.
('59', 0, 3, 12, 833) Believe me, so far as I am concerned, I did not think of the Arya Bhushan bill in connection with fixing up your fee, remuneration or honorarium, whatever it may be called.
('59', 0, 3, 13, 1006) Nor did I then know nor do I now know that the Arya Bhushan bill is exorbitant.
('59', 0, 3, 14, 1086) My understanding is that they should not make anything but nominal profits.
('59', 0, 3, 15, 1162) You are thinking of anything between Rs. 500 to 3,000. I can only meet your proposal with a reasonable offer.
('59', 0, 3, 16, 1272) You can take over the book yourself by simply paying the printing charges and sell the book on your own account and make whatever profit you can, only you should not increase the published price, for any increase in the price would be unjust to the public.
('59', 0, 3, 17, 1529) I have already asked Haribhau to pay you Rs. 125 if you would accept the amount in full payment and not feel any dissatisfaction.
('59', 0, 3, 18, 1659) For I would be deeply hurt if, after having left the thing in my hands, you were dissatisfied with the amount declared by me.
('59', 0, 4, 19, 1785) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 0, 4, 20, 1807) N. H. PURANDARE 604 SADASHIV PETH POONA 2
('59', 0, 5, 21, 1849) From a microfilm: S.N., 18915

('59', 1, 1, 2, 1919) 2. LETTER TO DHANNU LALL SHARMA
('59', 1, 2, 3, 1951) January 13, 1933
('59', 1, 3, 4, 1968) DEAR FRIEND, I will not refer you to any of my statements this time, but I will ask you to re read your own letter 1. I suggest to you that that letter is libellous, insulting and unworthy of one who holds the position of General Secretary of a Sanatan Dharma Sabha.
('59', 1, 3, 5, 2235) If you will re read your letter calmly and dispassionately, you will at once apologize to the pandits whom you have libelled, and, in any event, till you apologize, your letters will neither be read nor replied to.
('59', 1, 3, 6, 2450) I am sorry for it.
('59', 1, 4, 7, 2469) Your sincere friend, SJT.
('59', 1, 4, 8, 2495) DHANNU LALL SHARMA GENERAL SECRETARY SHREE SANATAN DHARMA SABHA 220 HARRISON ROAD CALCUTTA

('59', 1, 7, 11, 2644) January 13, 1933
('59', 1, 8, 12, 2661) DEAR SATYANANDA BABOO, You are always so good and always think of me whenever there is anything to say to me.
('59', 1, 8, 13, 2771) I think that this is hardly the time to consider improvements in Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill.
('59', 1, 8, 14, 2859) The first thing is to get the Viceregal sanction.
('59', 1, 8, 15, 2909) When that is had, many improvements may be possible.
('59', 1, 8, 16, 2962) I am not therefore just now applying my mind to your suggestion 2. After the principle of the Bill is once accepted, the Government themselves may
('59', 1, 9, 17, 3109) 1 In which the addressee had referred to Gandhiji's “Appeal to Sanatanists”, 4 1 1933, and said that the pandits had deceived not only him but the whole world; vide “Appeal to Sanatanists”, 4 1 1933
('59', 1, 10, 18, 3308) 2 That the Bill be confined to giving authority to the trustee of a temple to allow the untouchables to enter it and worship as the caste Hindus do (S.N. 18893)
('59', 2, 0, 1, 3469) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 3
('59', 2, 1, 2, 3512) take it up or may advise amendments so far as that may be necessary to free the Bill from any possible political mischief.
('59', 2, 1, 3, 3635) So far as I am concerned, my one thought in connection with the temple entry is the purification of caste Hindus.
('59', 2, 1, 4, 3749) But of course I shall bear your suggestions in mind whenever the occasion arises for their use.
('59', 2, 2, 5, 3845) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('59', 2, 3, 8, 3945) LETTER TO S. T. RAMANUJA IYENGAR
('59', 2, 4, 9, 3978) January 13, 1933
('59', 2, 5, 10, 3995) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter together with your article 1. I am sorry indeed that there should have been any molestation of you by the audience.
('59', 2, 5, 11, 4143) I have, as you must be aware, repeatedly written against intolerance, and I shall gladly re emphasize my warning when the time comes.
('59', 2, 5, 12, 4277) As for your article, we must agree to differ.
('59', 2, 5, 13, 4323) 2 Our conception of sanatana dharma is different.
('59', 2, 5, 14, 4373) In your impatience you have not even cared to understand my fundamental position.
('59', 2, 5, 15, 4455) I can only say, ‘Read all my statements with a fresh mind, then if you have still doubts, discuss them with Sjt.
('59', 2, 5, 16, 4568) Rajagopalachariar and if you are not still convinced and would care to do so, come down to Yeravda and I shall gladly give you one hour and try to convince you that the position I take up and the means I adopt to vindicate are both perfectly defensible.’ Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 2, 5, 17, 4845) S. T. RAMANUJA IYENGAR 4 VARADARAJA PERUMAL COIL ST.

('59', 3, 6, 12, 5767) 6. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('59', 3, 7, 13, 5799) January 13, 1933
('59', 3, 8, 14, 5816) MY DEAR C.R., Vallabhbhai had a battle royal with me last night on your behalf.
('59', 3, 8, 15, 5896) If a person, an utter stranger to him, had chance to be there, from the vehemence of Vallabhbhai’s language, he would have concluded that we must be most quarrelsome persons.
('59', 3, 8, 16, 6071) He thought that I was doing violent injustice to you, inasmuch as, without consultation with you, I made proposals that might prove to be utterly embarrassing, as had happened on two occasions.
('59', 3, 8, 17, 6265) The cause of our quarrel was my compromise proposal 1. He thought that I had no right to publish it without consultation with you, and he was quite sure that though you were too good to mention it to me, you had felt very much embarrassed by it, if not also irritated.
('59', 3, 8, 18, 6534) I told him that you were too good to conceal your embarrassment from me, if you were really embarrassed, and that would be quite unlike you.
('59', 3, 8, 19, 6675) I even added that in this particular instance you happened even to like my proposal and that even if it was discovered that you did not
('59', 3, 9, 20, 6811) 1 For a discussion, vide “Talk with Sadashivrao and Shinde”, 13 1 1933
('59', 4, 0, 1, 6882) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 5
('59', 4, 1, 2, 6925) like it and that you were really embarrassed, it was impossible for me every time to consult you, or such other colleagues on such occasions.
('59', 4, 1, 3, 7067) I went further and argued that work on such lines would become almost impossible.
('59', 4, 1, 4, 7149) People act together when there is a general agreement between them on fundamentals and [provided] that their deductions from those fundamentals were, as a rule, identical, and that if, at times, they came to different deductions, a timely confession of error would keep their friendship in tact, as also the common cause.
('59', 4, 1, 5, 7471) Nothing that I could say, however, would conciliate Vallabhbhai.
('59', 4, 1, 6, 7536) The curfew bell, mutually agreed upon by us, came to the rescue, and put an end to what promised to be an endless discussion.
('59', 4, 1, 7, 7662) But I retired to bed with a determination that I would refer the matter to you.
('59', 4, 1, 8, 7742) Your reply, one way or the other, would bring some consolation to your counsel, and you know that it won’t make me disconsolate if you agreed with your counsel on both his propositions, namely, that before giving to the world the compromise proposal which I had given to Pandit Panchanan Tarkaratna I should have consulted you, and that it, as a matter of fact, did embarrass you.
('59', 4, 1, 9, 8123) You would also add to your opinion on these points, your opinion whether on merits you consider my proposal to be sound or otherwise.
('59', 4, 1, 10, 8257) A perfect tragedy was enacted here yesterday.
('59', 4, 1, 11, 8303) Five pandits and their five advisers came to the jail gate yesterday an hour and a half after the appointed time and took two hours and a half in exchanging brief notes with me, the three notes 1 that they exchanged with me taking all the two hours and a half.
('59', 4, 1, 12, 8564) And, will you believe it, when I tell you that they would not come in and carry on the discussion because I would not remove one word I had added to their draft, the word being an adjective added to the word ‘untouchables’.
('59', 4, 1, 13, 8788) The adjective applied was ‘as at present classified’.
('59', 4, 1, 14, 8842) Of course it altered the whole scope of their discussion.
('59', 4, 1, 15, 8900) So they went away.
('59', 4, 1, 16, 8919) Of course it is not our position that there is no untouchability at all in the Shastras.
('59', 4, 1, 17, 9008) Our position is that there is no untouchability in the Shastras as we practise it today.
('59', 4, 1, 18, 9097) They were expected to prove that untouchability as at present practised has sanction in the Shastras.
('59', 4, 1, 19, 9199) It is an impossible task to perform honestly.
('59', 4, 1, 20, 9245) No text that has yet been cited on their behalf has proved it.
('59', 4, 1, 21, 9308) The Shastris on our behalf are really very learned men, and also pious men.
('59', 4, 1, 22, 9384) It is their honest conviction that there is no warrant for the untouchability of the present day in the Shastras.
('59', 4, 1, 23, 9498) The real
('59', 4, 2, 24, 9507) 1 Vide “Fraagment of Letter to Lord Sankey”, 22 11 1932
('59', 5, 0, 1, 9563) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 5, 1, 2, 9603) untouchability will be there for all time.
('59', 5, 1, 3, 9646) It is a sound hygienic rule practised all over the world.
('59', 5, 2, 4, 9704) Yours sincerely,
('59', 5, 3, 5, 9721) From a microfilm: S.N. 18922
('59', 5, 4, 6, 9750) 7. LETTER TO GEORGE JOSEPH
('59', 5, 5, 7, 9777) January 13, 1933
('59', 5, 6, 8, 9794) MY DEAR JOSEPH, You can better imagine than I can describe my joy at receiving your letter, and especially your letter 1 to Pyarelal.
('59', 5, 6, 9, 9928) I shall try to have your letter delivered to him.
('59', 5, 6, 10, 9978) But let me say two things in connection with that letter.
('59', 5, 6, 11, 10036) My fast 2 was not a fast unto death in its literal sense.
('59', 5, 6, 12, 10094) The Roman Catholic priest, who is a visitor to this prison, knows me, and when I was on the eve of taking that fast, he came over to me in his kindly manner just to say one word, and he said how he drew the distinction between a suicide and a sacrifice.
('59', 5, 6, 13, 10348) A suicide carried with it a certainty of destruction.
('59', 5, 6, 14, 10402) A sacrifice meant risking life, the greater the risk, the greater the sacrifice.
('59', 5, 6, 15, 10483) But there should be nothing beyond risk.
('59', 5, 6, 16, 10524) I had no hesitation in agreeing with the distinction, and my fast being conditional was not a fast amounting to suicide, but it was a fast involving the greatest risk, but still a risk and no more.
('59', 5, 6, 17, 10722) You will be interested to know that some of my Roman Catholic friends have detected no flaw in the fast.
('59', 5, 6, 18, 10827) Of course, in Hinduism some few extreme cases there are in which ending of life is peremptory, but these I need not consider at present.
('59', 5, 6, 19, 10964) There is general agreement between Hinduism and other faiths that suicide is a sin.
('59', 5, 6, 20, 11048) Now, about the Inner Voice.
('59', 5, 6, 21, 11076) 3 Here again I can agree with you whole heartedly when you say that the voice of God can never counsel or ountenance sin.
('59', 5, 6, 22, 11198) Encouragement to sin can only come from the devil.
('59', 5, 6, 23, 11249) But the real difficulty comes in when the question of
('59', 5, 7, 24, 11303) 1 In which the addressee had expressed his views on Pyarelal's book The Epic Fast and stated: “The Inner Voice is either a hallucination or the voice of God.
('59', 5, 7, 25, 11461) If it is truly the voice of God, it cannot counsel self destruction because the life that God gives is for Him alone to put an end to .
('59', 5, 7, 26, 11597) .” 2 Vide
('59', 5, 8, 27, 11607) 3 For a discussion, vide “Discussion with a Friend”, 13 1 1933
('59', 6, 0, 1, 11670) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 7
('59', 6, 1, 2, 11713) sin itself is debatable.
('59', 6, 1, 3, 11738) Those who would consider a particular act to be sinful will naturally reject the claim that it was prompted by God.
('59', 6, 1, 4, 11854) Hence it was that in answer to a question I said 1 that whilst in self defence and for the sake of truth which I worship I was bound to say what I believed, my claim was not to be accepted as part of argument in determining relevant questions.
('59', 6, 1, 5, 12098) The opponents were bound to rule [out] that claim as wholly beside the point.
('59', 6, 1, 6, 12176) Whether the claim for the voice of God was well or ill made in a particular case can only be decided after the claimant’s death, and in some extraordinary cases it may even then be difficult.
('59', 6, 1, 7, 12368) Apart from the danger of hypocrisy there is the still greater danger of self deception to which mankind is prone, and it is possible for self deceived people to attain great things and yet their claim that the voice of God was behind their acts might be wholly wrong.
('59', 6, 1, 8, 12636) These are final difficulties which will remain to the end of time, but if the truth is to make any progress, then self deluded people must also be allowed full play.
('59', 6, 2, 9, 12802) Finally comes the question of confession.
('59', 6, 2, 10, 12844) You may not know that I have some very valued Roman Catholic friends also.
('59', 6, 2, 11, 12919) I am in the habit of picking up knowledge more from personal contact than from printed texts.
('59', 6, 2, 12, 13013) These friends have not yet been able to clearly define the function of Confession and the Confessor.
('59', 6, 2, 13, 13114) For instance, what is one to confess who has no consciousness of guilt and when there is, I can understand a Confessor granting absolution, but can he also guide the future acts of the penitent?
('59', 6, 2, 14, 13309) In the place of the Confessor Hinduism has the Guru.
('59', 6, 2, 15, 13362) I have all my life striven to find one, one to whom I can shift all my burdens and roam about merely doing his will.
('59', 6, 2, 16, 13479) But then such implicit limitless obedience is not a mechanical act; and having got the spirit of obedience instinctively within me I would be satisfied by nothing less than tendering complete obedience.
('59', 6, 2, 17, 13682) But it seems to me that it is not given to all to find the true Guru in this short span of life.
('59', 6, 2, 18, 13779) But it is given to all to make that diligent search, and it may be that that very search is its own reward, and that it keeps one in possession of peace and joy everlasting.
('59', 6, 2, 19, 13953) Anyway, you will accept my testimony that ceaseless search has not only given me such joy and peace, but has protected me from conscious error.
('59', 6, 2, 20, 14097) I thank you for copying for me that extract from Imitation of
('59', 6, 3, 21, 14159) 1 Vide, passim
('59', 7, 0, 1, 14174) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 7, 1, 2, 14214) Christ.
('59', 7, 1, 3, 14222) I read that book in one single sitting, I think, in the year 1905 or 1906, and a friend, only a few months ago, sent me another copy.
('59', 7, 1, 4, 14356) With our love to all of you,
('59', 7, 2, 5, 14385) Yours sincerely, GEORGE JOSEPH, ESQ., M.A., BARRISTER AT LAW “HILL VIEW”, MADURA
('59', 7, 3, 6, 14466) From a microfilm: S.N. 18923

('59', 10, 7, 14, 19449) You are entitled to call yourself an Indian since you have felt like one from your childhood, but that is not a substitute for your German birth.
('59', 10, 7, 15, 19595) The adoption should be an addition both to your name and to your strength, and what can be finer than that we should all add on the virtues of our own nations to those of the others!

('59', 10, 7, 19, 19927) I have none of the gifts that he has, and what is more, we dearly love each other, and as years roll on, our love becomes stronger, and we understand also each other better and better.
('59', 10, 7, 20, 20112) I would have you therefore to say that you like us both equally for whatever gifts God has bestowed upon us.

('59', 11, 2, 3, 20704) January 14, 1933
('59', 11, 3, 4, 20721) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('59', 11, 3, 5, 20754) The question is not so much what the Harijans need, but how the caste Hindus should behave towards them.
('59', 11, 3, 6, 20859) In my opinion, it is the clear duty of caste Hindus to give to the Harijans the same rights that they enjoy.
('59', 11, 3, 7, 20968) The fact that evil has survived numberless generations does not make it any the less an evil.
('59', 11, 3, 8, 21062) Similarly, the fact that untouchability has survived the great religious teachers whom you name does not warrant the present generation in continuing it, if it can be proved to be an evil.
('59', 11, 3, 9, 21251) I am convinced it is.
('59', 11, 3, 10, 21273) A person who has heard the inner call should still be open to reason and therefore conviction.
('59', 11, 3, 11, 21368) That attitude enables him and others to test the truth of his claim.
('59', 11, 3, 12, 21437) I do say with my conception of Hinduism that God denies Himself what Harijans are denied, because they are called Harijans.

('59', 15, 1, 11, 27477) His blessings will always be with you.
('59', 15, 1, 12, 27516) You cannot have a girl from the Ashram, for it would be improper to arouse the least traceof such a feeling in any girl in the Ashram.

('59', 19, 2, 3, 34947) January 15, 1933
('59', 19, 3, 4, 34964) PREMA, Your continued sulking shows that you have a good measure of childishness in you.
('59', 19, 3, 5, 35053) If you do not tolerate my criticizing you, you are not at all likely to tolerate anybody else doing so.

('59', 19, 3, 11, 35533) Let me tell you that this is not freedom but self will.

('59', 19, 3, 13, 35687) It is not right for you to sulk; on the contrary, you should feel sorry and weep for having made me suffer.

('59', 19, 3, 15, 35880) If I am making any mistake in doing so, it is your duty to point it out humbly to me.
('59', 19, 3, 16, 35966) If you are sure that you are innocent, you should be confident of being able to prove it to me.

('59', 21, 5, 8, 38406) 28. LETTER TO JIVRAM K. KOTHARI2
('59', 21, 6, 9, 38439) January 15, 1933
('59', 21, 7, 10, 38456) The words “twenty four hours” you have taken rather literally.
('59', 21, 7, 11, 38519) You should have understood my intention in using them.
('59', 21, 7, 12, 38574) For twenty four hours mean for as long as possible.
('59', 21, 7, 13, 38626) When it is raining or is very hot, when there is a strong wind or it is extremely cold, or when for any other reason it is absolutely impossible or will be harmful to remain or sleep or work in the open, one’s moral duty is to take shelter under a shade or a roof or in a house with the doors and the windows shut.
('59', 21, 7, 14, 38941) All that you should have read in my words is that it is desirable to spend as much time as possible in the open without anything between oneself and the sky.
('59', 21, 7, 15, 39099) Those who understand this will spend the least possible time inside their houses and will also see that there is adequate ventilation inside.
('59', 21, 7, 16, 39241) And now about knowing the time of the day.
('59', 21, 7, 17, 39284) A village worker does not require a clock or a watch.
('59', 21, 7, 18, 39338) All his activities follow nature.
('59', 21, 7, 19, 39372) His clock also is nature’s.
('59', 21, 7, 20, 39400) His manner of indicating time is different from ours.
('59', 21, 7, 21, 39454) He will not ask a person to come at four.
('59', 21, 7, 22, 39496) He will say: ‘Come at prayer time,, or ‘Come an hour or two before sunset’, or ‘Come at daybreak’, or ‘Come when the birds start singing’, or ‘Come at dinner time’, or ‘Come when I am weaving tape’, or ‘Come at twilight’ or ‘at supper time’.
('59', 21, 7, 23, 39738) One can thus use different descriptions for different hours of the day.
('59', 21, 7, 24, 39810) And the worker is so regular in his tasks that he does not need to look at the sky to know the time of the day.
('59', 21, 7, 25, 39922) Every day he does the same job at the same hour and takes the same time for doing it.
('59', 21, 7, 26, 40008) Because of this exact regularity, when the work is over he knows what time of day it is.
('59', 21, 7, 27, 40097) Since he is not in the habit of consulting a watch, he cannot say how many hours he would require
('59', 21, 8, 28, 40195) 1 Addressee’s wife 2 The addressee was working in Orissa
('59', 22, 0, 1, 40252) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 23
('59', 22, 1, 2, 40296) for a given job.
('59', 22, 1, 3, 40313) But he says that he weaves a certain number of yards of tape daily, and from that he and others can judge for how many hours he must be working.
('59', 22, 1, 4, 40458) It was because of this that in former days time was not counted in hours but was measured by the amount of work done.
('59', 22, 1, 5, 40576) Even when the village worker travelled, he experienced no difficulty, for he knew how many miles he could walk between sunrise and sunset.
('59', 22, 1, 6, 40715) Such a worker rests not according to the clock but only when he feels tired.
('59', 22, 1, 7, 40792) In short, one feels very little need for a clock in a village; one may say that one feels no need at all.
('59', 22, 1, 8, 40898) The village worker measures his work by reference to the movements of the sun or the other heavenly bodies.
('59', 22, 1, 9, 41006) Clouds are no obstacles to this, because there are very few days in the year when the sky is covered with clouds.
('59', 22, 1, 10, 41120) Even on such days, however, his work goes on as usual.
('59', 22, 1, 11, 41175) Prayer time also is observed without any conscious effort.
('59', 22, 1, 12, 41234) If one’s hours of the day are filled with work and succeed one another in the same order, one will know without looking at the clock when it is time for prayer.
('59', 22, 1, 13, 41395) It will, then, rarely happen that one gets up late and has to worry about how to make up for the lost time.
('59', 22, 1, 14, 41503) It is not necessary to adjust the time of evening prayer with the prayer hour in the Ashram.
('59', 22, 1, 15, 41596) People living in different parts of the world cannot do a particular thing at the same hour.
('59', 22, 1, 16, 41689) It will, therefore, be most convenient for you to start your prayer when the sun sets in that part of the country.
('59', 22, 1, 17, 41804) I think I have answered all your doubts, big and small.
('59', 22, 2, 18, 41860) [From Gujarati]
('59', 22, 3, 19, 41876) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. III, pp.

('59', 25, 15, 18, 45319) DEAR COL.
('59', 25, 15, 19, 45329) DOYLE, Sjt.
('59', 25, 15, 20, 45341) Mathuradas, the only grandson of a deceased sister of mine, was recently discharged from Belgaum Prison.
('59', 25, 15, 21, 45446) He met me and told me that my letters were delivered to him with passages cut out.
('59', 25, 15, 22, 45529) Now my letters never contain anything that might possibly be considered of an obnoxious nature from the prison or any other standpoint.
('59', 25, 15, 23, 45665) They go from here duly censored.
('59', 25, 15, 24, 45698) The Superintendents here have done me the favour of drawing my attention to passages in my letters which they may not like.
('59', 25, 15, 25, 45822) But to cut out words or passages from a letter
('59', 25, 16, 26, 45869) 1 By Vasantram Shastri
('59', 26, 0, 1, 45892) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 27
('59', 26, 1, 2, 45936) without reference to the writer may lead to dangerous interpretations or interpretations not intended by the writer.
('59', 26, 1, 3, 46053) In my opinion any letter of which a passage is held objectionable should be referred to the writer and option given to him either of withdrawing the passage or the letter altogether.
('59', 26, 1, 4, 46236) And I cannot understand the practice of double censoring.
('59', 26, 1, 5, 46294) My letters are all thought out and conceived as one piece.
('59', 26, 1, 6, 46353) They contain mostly ethical matters.
('59', 26, 1, 7, 46390) The removal of a word may change the meaning.
('59', 26, 1, 8, 46436) I should not like my letters to be interfered with without my knowledge.
('59', 26, 1, 9, 46509) I may say that I often receive Maniben Patel’s letters with large patches making the letters meaningless.
('59', 26, 1, 10, 46615) I wish you could grant relief in this matter by no means trivial to me.
('59', 26, 2, 11, 46687) Yours sincerely,

('59', 26, 5, 14, 46772) 38. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('59', 26, 6, 15, 46798) January 16, 1933
('59', 26, 7, 16, 46815) DEAR COL.
('59', 26, 7, 17, 46825) DOYLE, I hope that you have now overtaken the Christmas week arrears and are comparatively free to devote a little attention to an important matter which we have often talked about but never thoroughly thrashed out.
('59', 26, 7, 18, 47041) I refer to the question of handcarding and hand spinning in the prisons.
('59', 26, 7, 19, 47114) I have told you that as early as 1922 these two things were first introduced at my request in this prison.
('59', 26, 7, 20, 47221) At first Sjt.
('59', 26, 7, 21, 47235) Shankerlal Banker and I were permitted to do this work on our own bows and wheels with our own cotton.
('59', 26, 7, 22, 47338) Then cotton was brought by Col.
('59', 26, 7, 23, 47370) Dalziel from Dharwar.
('59', 26, 7, 24, 47392) The result of our work was liked by Major Jones who followed Col.
('59', 26, 7, 25, 47458) Dalziel and he allowed all Civil Disobedience prisoners who volunteered to do this work regularly.
('59', 26, 7, 26, 47557) I was permitted to regulate and examine the daily work and issue the necessary instructions for improvement.
('59', 26, 7, 27, 47666) A record was kept of the work.
('59', 26, 7, 28, 47697) Spinning wheels and bows were manufac tured in the prison, spindles were made and the yarn was used as welt, and, if I am not mistaken, also for tapes.
('59', 26, 7, 29, 47849) I was allowed to train convict warders as carders, and a considerable quantity of yarn was thus produced.
('59', 26, 7, 30, 47955) On the resumption of Civil Disobedience in 1930 the question
('59', 27, 0, 1, 48016) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 27, 1, 2, 48057) was raised by me and several prisoners and permission was granted in some cases and not in others.
('59', 27, 1, 3, 48156) There was no fixed policy evolved when peace was declared and the C. D. prisoners were discharged.
('59', 27, 1, 4, 48255) The matter this time is also in the same uncertain state.
('59', 27, 1, 5, 48313) In Dhulia for instance Seth Jamnalal Bajaj tells me hand spinning is universal among the C. D. prisoners, so much so that much khadi has been manufactured out of the yarn so spun.
('59', 27, 1, 6, 48493) I know that in some other jails too it is freely allowed.
('59', 27, 1, 7, 48551) It is only here that almost complete prohibition reigns except with me, my companions and certain other prisoners and the female Civil Disobedience prisoners.
('59', 27, 1, 8, 48710) I have told you that many Civil Disobedience prisoners have been under vows to spin regularly as a sacrifice.
('59', 27, 1, 9, 48820) It is only after much effort that I have succeeded generally in persuading the Civil Disobe dience prisoners not to regard the vow as binding in prisons.
('59', 27, 1, 10, 48974) They know that I am trying to persuade you to give the permission to spin to those who regard it as a sacred duty, either as part of their task or as extra work to be kept by them for their use.
('59', 27, 1, 11, 49169) To carding and spinning by itself I am sure the Government can have no objection.
('59', 27, 1, 12, 49251) It has no connection with the Civil Disobedience campaign.
('59', 27, 1, 13, 49310) Spinning organizations have not been declared unlawful nor spinning an unlawful activity.
('59', 27, 1, 14, 49400) From the State point of view I can demons trate, as I did in 1922 by actual results, that it is a more remunerative occupation than several others followed in the prisons.
('59', 27, 1, 15, 49572) Indeed I endeavoured to show to one of your predecessors, viz., Col.
('59', 27, 1, 16, 49641) Mel, that it was possible even to make prisons self supporting by a universal introduction of all cotton processes in the prisons.
('59', 27, 1, 17, 49772) But whilst I was carrying on these conversations, he retired.
('59', 27, 1, 18, 49834) Inspectors General and Superintendents change rapidly and I was discharged all too prematurely owing to the attack of appendicitis.
('59', 27, 1, 19, 49966) If I can but get a little encouragement from you, I have the same confidence as in 1922 and could show you startling results.
('59', 27, 1, 20, 50092) But that may be a far cry.
('59', 27, 1, 21, 50119) My present purpose is to ask you please to regularize the practice, which is now followed haphazard, of allowing volunteers to do hand carding and hand spinning with such restrictions as may be considered necessary in the interest of the administration.
('59', 27, 2, 22, 50373) Yours sincerely,
('59', 27, 3, 23, 50390) M. K. GANDHI
('59', 27, 4, 24, 50403) Government of Bombay, Home Department, I.G.P. File No.

('59', 30, 6, 12, 53782) 44. LETTER TO BALKRISHNA BHAVE
('59', 30, 7, 13, 53813) January 16, 1933
('59', 30, 8, 14, 53830) According to me, the reasons why your body does not become strong and healthy are these: though you eat, you do not have faith in the food which you eat and feel aversion towards it, you waste your mental energy too much and neglect your health out of ignorant attachment to work.

('59', 41, 11, 15, 72304) 61. LETTER TO A COLLEGE STUDENT
('59', 41, 12, 16, 72336) January 17, 1933
('59', 41, 13, 17, 72353) It is not correct to say that I am a champion of mixed marriages.
('59', 41, 13, 18, 72419) It can be said that I do not oppose such marriages.
('59', 41, 13, 19, 72471) There is a difference between the two statements.
('59', 41, 13, 20, 72521) The statement that I am a champion of mixed marriages or even that I am not opposed to them is likely to give rise to some misunderstanding in so far as your idea of a mixed marriage is different from mine.
('59', 41, 13, 21, 72728) Today we hardly come across any true Brahmins or true Shudras.
('59', 41, 13, 22, 72791) Therefore what you do not regard as a mixed marriage is likely to be one and what, if I accepted the popular parlance, would be a mixed marriage may not actually be such.
('59', 41, 13, 23, 72962) For instance, if a so called Shudra girl possessing the qualities of a Brahmin girl marries a real Brahmin I would not call it a mixed
('59', 41, 14, 24, 73097) 1 Daughter of Maganlal Gandhi and wife of Benarsilal Bazaj
('59', 42, 0, 1, 73156) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 43
('59', 42, 1, 2, 73200) marriage, whereas you would regard it as such.
('59', 42, 1, 3, 73247) On the other hand, if a so called Brahmin boy with the qualities of a Shudra marries a so called Shudra girl with Brahmin like qualities it would be a mixed marriage in my view.
('59', 42, 1, 4, 73425) You would also regard it as one.
('59', 42, 1, 5, 73458) Both of us will, however, do it for different reasons.
('59', 42, 1, 6, 73513) You should understand from this that I never reject a scientific truth that has been established.
('59', 42, 1, 7, 73611) But you should also note that in [the realm of] science what has come to be accepted as truth today is not unlikely to be proved as untruth tomorrow.
('59', 42, 1, 8, 73761) Sciences founded on deduction are always bound to suffer this basic imperfection.
('59', 42, 1, 9, 73843) We cannot therefore regard it as an absolute truth.
('59', 42, 1, 10, 73895) I think I understand and also believe in varnashrama dharma.
('59', 42, 1, 11, 73956) But you and I seem to understand the purport of varnashrama dharma in different ways.
('59', 42, 2, 12, 74042) In spite of saying all this I ought to caution you that if you propose to consider the question of untouchability in a scientific way you should understand that interdining and mixed marriage have nothing to do with the question, and you should act accordingly.
('59', 42, 2, 13, 74304) As for me today I am living, but tomorrow I may not be there, but this problem is certainly going to be there even after me.
('59', 42, 2, 14, 74429) At the moment I am not at all canvassing for interdining and mixed marriage.
('59', 42, 2, 15, 74506) We shall see about it when I start advocating them.
('59', 42, 2, 16, 74558) It is neither scientific nor moral to condemn, because of faults you find in me, the noble work that I happen to be doing.
('59', 42, 2, 17, 74681) [From Gujarati]
('59', 42, 3, 18, 74697) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. III, p.

('59', 43, 7, 14, 75885) 64. A NOTE ON THE THE PROPOSED INTRODUCTION OF HAND SPINNING IN YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON1
('59', 43, 8, 15, 75973) January 18, 1933
('59', 43, 9, 16, 75990) Of carded cotton yields 840 yards of yarn of 1 count, i.e., 8400 yards of yarn of 10 counts.
('59', 43, 9, 17, 76083) An average good spinner spins at least 150 yards per hour of 10 counts.
('59', 43, 9, 18, 76155) Therefore in 6 working hours he will spin 900 yards—4.14 tolas.
('59', 43, 9, 19, 76219) Therefore 9 such men will spin 1 lb.
('59', 43, 9, 20, 76256) of yarn per day.
('59', 43, 9, 21, 76273) At the rate of 3 as.
('59', 43, 9, 22, 76294) per lb.
('59', 43, 9, 23, 76302) of 10 [count] yarn as the ordinary wage of a spinner, 9 men will earn 3 as.
('59', 43, 9, 24, 76378) a day, i.e., 1/3 of an anna each.
('59', 43, 9, 25, 76412) At the present moment at least.
('59', 43, 9, 26, 76444) 1000 C. D. prisoners in this jail are not producing even half of this small amount of wealth.
('59', 43, 9, 27, 76538) In other words there is a dead waste of at least Rs. 10 per day in the Yeravda Central Prison.
('59', 43, 9, 28, 76633) The outlay required for producing the yarn is 120 lb.
('59', 43, 9, 29, 76687) of cotton per day.
('59', 43, 9, 30, 76706) It is likely that it will not be necessary to supply spinning wheels to all these spinners.
('59', 43, 9, 31, 76798) I am unable to say off hand how many will have their own spinning wheels.
('59', 43, 9, 32, 76872) But that will need to be ascertained.
('59', 43, 9, 33, 76910) I have given the lowest possible estimates so as to err on
('59', 43, 10, 34, 76969) 1 Vide also “Letter to E. E. Doyle, 16 1 1933.
('59', 44, 0, 1, 77016) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 45
('59', 44, 1, 2, 77060) the safest side.
('59', 44, 1, 3, 77077) It may also be stated that it is possible to do the spinning through the takli, the easiest and the cheapest method, but the output would be 1/3 compared to the wheel.
('59', 44, 1, 4, 77245) I suggest that the beginning should be made at once with those who volunteer to do the spinning and who can produce their own spinning wheels .
('59', 44, 1, 5, 77389) There remains now the question as to what to do with the yarn.
('59', 44, 1, 6, 77452) Yarn of 10 counts can be utilized to weave coarse cloth or the yarn as it is produced can be sold without the slightest difficulty.
('59', 44, 1, 7, 77584) I have made no reference in this note to carding.
('59', 44, 1, 8, 77634) The usual estimate is that one carding bow can supply ten spinners with carded cotton.
('59', 44, 1, 9, 77721) The processes to be gone through before spinning is begun are carding and sliver making in which last is the simplest.
('59', 44, 1, 10, 77840) If further particulars are required I will gladly supply them.
('59', 44, 1, 11, 77903) I have here confined myself only to the commercial aspect and made no reference to those with whom spinning is a part of daily sacrifice.
('59', 44, 1, 12, 78041) I think that for such the permission should be granted at once, in view of the fact that it is being done in several prisons.
('59', 44, 2, 13, 78167) M. K. GANDHI
('59', 44, 3, 14, 78180) Government of Bombay, Home Department, I. G. P. File No.

('59', 45, 12, 20, 80067) 68. LETTER TO C. NARAYANA MENON
('59', 45, 13, 21, 80099) January 18, 1933
('59', 45, 14, 22, 80116) DEAR FRIEND, Do you mean to suggest that in Malabar the public temples do not belong to the Hindus who have the right of worship there?
('59', 45, 14, 23, 80252) Will you contend that even when the temple was first built, it was not the property of Hindus although Hindus subscribed to the cost of
('59', 46, 0, 1, 80388) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 47
('59', 46, 1, 2, 80432) building it?
('59', 46, 1, 3, 80445) And if that was so, then the trustees would not be trustees, but they would be absolute owners.
('59', 46, 1, 4, 80541) There are thousands of such temples owned by private persons.
('59', 46, 1, 5, 80603) A public temple is so called only because it is public property; that is to say, the property of those members of the public at whose instance and with whose money and on whose behalf the temple was built.
('59', 46, 1, 6, 80809) Do you think that the multitude of people who give donations daily have no right whatsoever to the temple to which they give donations?
('59', 46, 1, 7, 80945) Of course you may say that the right does not include authority to change the character or quality of those who are entitled to offer worship.
('59', 46, 1, 8, 81088) If you do so, you will simply beg the question.
('59', 46, 1, 9, 81136) For the contention of the reformers is that the so called Harijans are only so called, and that they should never have been excluded from rights enjoyed by any other members of the Hindu family, provided that they conform to the regulations as to cleanliness and the like.
('59', 46, 1, 10, 81409) The purity of the temples themselves is irrelevant to the present discussion.
('59', 46, 1, 11, 81487) You don’t want to say that if a temple has dancing girls and swindling Brahmins, it should be opened to Harijans, and not if the Brahmins cease to swindle and the girls cease to dance in those temples?

('59', 46, 1, 13, 81769) He certainly has more leisure than Malaviyaji.
('59', 46, 1, 14, 81816) About my fast you need have no fear.
('59', 46, 2, 15, 81853) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('59', 48, 2, 3, 83543) January 18, 1933
('59', 48, 3, 4, 83560) MY DEAR N., I have your two interesting and instructive letters.
('59', 48, 3, 5, 83625) It is very great work you are doing, and if the young men who have responded to your call remain steadfast and do not give in after the first flush of enthusiasm is exhausted, the street cleaning you are doing must prove infectious and it would be a great advance towards the removal of untouchability.
('59', 48, 3, 6, 83928) I am therefore surprised that anybody should cavil at the work itself or take exception to the fact that you, who have become an Indian by adoption and by right of love, should have taken the lead, and if anybody thinks that I would not have advised such work if I was out, he is wholly mistaken.
('59', 48, 3, 7, 84225) I have personally undertaken such work before now, both publicly and privately, and the cleaning of Harijan quarters that was done all over India on the 18th ultimo was due to the suggestion made by me and heartily taken up by the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 48, 3, 8, 84490) You are at liberty to make public use of this letter.

('59', 48, 3, 10, 84651) I am glad therefore of the correction you have made.
('59', 48, 3, 11, 84704) As you know, I am deeply interested in the question of scientific or (which is the same thing) hygienic and spiritual dietary.
('59', 48, 3, 12, 84831) Tell me therefore more about your diet.
('59', 48, 3, 13, 84871) Give me the actual things you take and the quantities, and how far you have been on this diet.
('59', 48, 3, 14, 84966) As you seem to have read practically everything I have ever written, perhaps you are aware that I have lived on fruits and nuts for over six years, that I have gone without milk for over nine years, and it has been the most disappointing thing for me to have been obliged to take even goat’s milk.
('59', 48, 3, 15, 85264) I know of no one of my acquaintance who has been able to do hard physical work as also hard mental work, as you seem to be doing, merely on fruits and vegetables, that means, no protein, no starch and no fat of any kind.

('59', 50, 4, 6, 87594) 75. LETTER TO VAMANBUWA BRAHMACHARI
('59', 50, 5, 7, 87630) January 18, 1933
('59', 50, 6, 8, 87647) SHRI BRAHMACHARIJI, Your letter.
('59', 50, 6, 9, 87680) I can see you on the 25th instant at 2 o’clock and shall reserve one hour for you.
('59', 50, 6, 10, 87763) I shall not give this time to anyone else.
('59', 50, 6, 11, 87806) But according to my vow I regard it a duty to answer your doubts.
('59', 50, 6, 12, 87872) (1) 1 I agree with all that you say in the first question but there is the difference of interpretation which is almost impossible to explain through correspondence.
('59', 50, 6, 13, 88038) All human beings are like blind men but all the devotees of truth are partially right in the same way that the seven blind men were right on their part in giving varying descriptions of the elephant on each touching different parts of its anatomy, (2) Untouchability as practised today is found nowhere in the Shastras.
('59', 50, 6, 14, 88358) This is the impression I have gathered on hearing what many Shastris say.
('59', 50, 6, 15, 88432) (3) Everything can be found in the Gita.
('59', 50, 6, 16, 88473) According to the change of place, time and circumstances, conduct as prescribed by the principle can change but never the principle itself.
('59', 50, 6, 17, 88613) (4) This too is a fact that we have degenerated and continue to do so because of failure in observing dharma.
('59', 50, 6, 18, 88723) (5) What you say is not true.
('59', 50, 7, 19, 88753) (6) In no way do I regard myself as more learned and wiser than anyone else.
('59', 50, 7, 20, 88830) (7) I have never taken such a vow 3 as you think I have.
('59', 50, 8, 21, 88887) 1 The addressee had asked whether Gandhiji had faith in the Vedas, whether he accepted their traditional interpretation or he had his own original interpretation.

('59', 51, 8, 18, 90340) When his attention was drawn to the report of an interview 2 between him and
('59', 51, 9, 19, 90417) its correspondent appearing in a Madras paper Gandhiji said: I had decided not to express any opinion on the proposal that a committee should be appointed to gauge opinion in respect of temple entry, because I did not attach any importance to the proposal.
('59', 51, 9, 20, 90674) But now that mention has been made, I can unhesitatingly say that the appointment of such a committee would be a most unfortunate thing.
('59', 51, 10, 21, 90811) 1 The addressee had referred to the dehumanizing effects of the Western industrial civilization.

('59', 52, 1, 2, 91082) I do not believe that the Government can ever endorse such a proposal.
('59', 52, 2, 3, 91153) The report stated that Mr. Gandhi said that he had decided to express his views on the proposal and that if the Viceroy refused sanction to the introduction of Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill, he (Mr. Gandhi) would resist it with his life.
('59', 52, 2, 4, 91383) While characterizing the report as a misrepresentation of a conversation never intended for publication, Mr. Gandhi said that he never told the correspondent that he had decided to express his views on.
('59', 52, 2, 5, 91586) the proposal for a committee.
('59', 52, 2, 6, 91616) On the contrary, he had decided not to do so.
('59', 52, 3, 7, 91662) Explaining why the appointment of a committee would be most unfortunate, Mr. Gandhi said that Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill was thoroughly inoffensive.
('59', 52, 3, 8, 91806) It not only did not seek interference with religion, but was intended to sound the religious feelings of the people concerned.
('59', 52, 3, 9, 91933) There was no question of sanctioning any law; the only thing the Viceroy was requested to do was to give his formal consent to the introduction of the Bill, which was the result of the unanimous vote of the Madras Council.
('59', 52, 4, 10, 92156) Mr. Gandhi expressed surprise regarding the second part of the interview attributed to him, and said that he had no recollection whatsoever of having said that if the Viceroy refused to sanction, he would resist it with his life.
('59', 52, 4, 11, 92386) He had no such settled plan before him, and if he had, he was not in the habit of making premature announcements to the public and that, even before bringing such an important decision to the notice of the authorities concerned.
('59', 52, 4, 12, 92615) Indeed, he could say emphatically that he himself did not know what he would do if permission was withheld.
('59', 52, 4, 13, 92723) But I know it to be a terrific ordeal for me, if the progress of reform was interfered with by the refusal of sanction to the introduction of a measure indispensable for the growth of religious freedom.

('59', 59, 1, 2, 104381) 85. LETTER TO MADAN MOHAN MALAVIYA
('59', 59, 2, 3, 104416) January 20, 1933
('59', 59, 3, 4, 104433) I have seen your statement convening a Conference of sanatanists 1. I had purposely refrained from worrying you over the question of temple entry.
('59', 59, 3, 5, 104580) Much as I stood in need of your invaluable assistance, I knew that you were preoccupied with matters of the highest moment, and I felt that the least I could do, as also the most that was possible, was deliberately to forgo that assistance.
('59', 59, 3, 6, 104821) Friends in Kerala pressed me to ask you to go to their rescue.
('59', 59, 3, 7, 104884) I refused to do so, and I warned them against troubling you.
('59', 59, 3, 8, 104945) But now I see that you have yourself taken the initiative and a tremendous responsibility.
('59', 59, 3, 9, 105036) I hope and pray that great good will come out of the Conference.
('59', 59, 3, 10, 105101) I wish that it had been possible for us to meet before the Conference, or that we had exchanged ideas before you propounded your suggestions about temple entry.
('59', 59, 3, 11, 105262) I feel, however, that I should submit to you my own position.
('59', 59, 3, 12, 105324) If the Bombay Meeting, during and immediately after the fast week 2, that passed the resolution was representative of Hindu India, it is up to every Hindu to make good that resolution in its fulness.
('59', 59, 3, 13, 105524) That resolution, as you know, has definite reference to temple entry.
('59', 59, 3, 14, 105594) It prescribes no conditions.
('59', 59, 3, 15, 105623) The whole trend of the resolution is that temple entry and the use of public institutions by Harijans on the same terms as the other Hindus is a debt long overdue by caste Hindus.
('59', 59, 3, 16, 105803) I feel that it would be wrong, if not a manifest breach of faith, to import any conditions specially applicable to Harijans.
('59', 59, 3, 17, 105928) Naturally, Harijans would be expected to conform to the conditions that are implied in Hinduism and have to be observed by everyone who enters temples.
('59', 59, 3, 18, 106080) But that is a different thing from laying down special conditions to be observed by Harijans by way of penance.
('59', 59, 3, 19, 106192) Most of the things that are included in your suggestions can be enunciated in a different and perfectly harmless manner, that is to say, by saying that it is the right of Harijans to enter all public temples under the same conditions that are applicable to all Hindus, irrespective of their caste or status, that is to say, (here may be described these general
('59', 59, 4, 20, 106553) 1 At Ahmedabad on January 25. For Madan Mohan Malaviya’s statement, Did; “Statement by Madan Mohan Malaviya”, 19 1 1933 2 From September 20 to 26, 1932
('59', 60, 0, 1, 106705) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 61
('59', 60, 1, 2, 106749) conditions, such as, daily bath, recitation of Dwadash 1 or other mantras, abstention from carrion or beef, intoxicating drinks, if the latter abstention is enjoined in any of the current Smritis and Puranas).
('59', 60, 1, 3, 106959) From all the discussions that I had with the Shastris who favour the present movement and who are hostile to it, I have gathered that there is no warrant whatsoever for untouchability as we now know it.
('59', 60, 1, 4, 107162) There is perfect confusion as to whom, of all the people classified as untouchables in the census books, the verses oft quoted apply.
('59', 60, 1, 5, 107296) Untouchability by birth seems to be utterly non existent.
('59', 60, 1, 6, 107354) There is no proof whatsoever to show that any single one of the untouchables so classed is the progeny of a Brahmin woman through a Shudra man or that he is a descendant of such a union.
('59', 60, 1, 7, 107541) I would, therefore, beg of you not to surrender on the matter of principle.
('59', 60, 1, 8, 107617) I would far rather that the reformers were left to plough the lonely furrow than that they should be called upon to lend themselves to an unworthy surrender.
('59', 60, 1, 9, 107775) The surrender, in my opinion, of the highest type I have suggested in my compromise proposal, where the most delicate susceptibilities of a minority, however small it may be, have been taken into consideration.
('59', 60, 1, 10, 107986) Even that has cost me much criticism, but I am unaffected by it, because, in my opinion, it is perfectly honourable and satisfies all sincere and religious minded reformers and dissenters.
('59', 60, 1, 11, 108175) If I am obscure, you will, I know and hope, use the wire freely.

('59', 62, 6, 9, 110769) 90. LETTER TO RAMANANDA CHATTERJEE
('59', 62, 7, 10, 110804) January 20, 1933
('59', 62, 8, 11, 110821) DEAR RAMANAND BABOO1, This letter is not for publication.
('59', 62, 8, 12, 110879) This sudden opposition in Bengal against the Yeravda Pact comes upon me as a painful surprise.
('59', 62, 8, 13, 110974) The Secretary of the British Indian Association has sent me the text of the Resolution in which, among other things, an appeal is made to me to assist in revising the Pact in so far as Bengal is concerned.
('59', 62, 8, 14, 111180) 2 I have refrained from taking any part in the public discussion of the question, because I do not want to make confusion worse confounded, or to give an opinion on a matter on which I am not sufficiently informed.
('59', 62, 8, 15, 111395) I therefore seek your assistance and guidance in enabling me to form a judgement.
('59', 62, 8, 16, 111477) Two Harijan friends from Bengal, dreading that I might weaken, have asked me what I think about the opposition, and I have told them that I have not altered my opinion and that the Pact could not be changed without the unanimous consent of all the parties concerned.
('59', 62, 8, 17, 111744) My own position is that Harijans cannot be given too much by caste Hindus.
('59', 62, 8, 18, 111819) It is my confirmed opinion that if all the seats available to Hindus were taken by Harijans and other depressed classes, the so called superior castes will not only lose nothing, but will gain by the sacrifice, if such it may be called.
('59', 62, 8, 19, 112056) Taking this into consideration, please tell me whether you share the views of the opposition, and if you do, on what grounds, and why
('59', 62, 9, 20, 112190) 1 Editor, Modern Review
('59', 62, 10, 21, 112214) 2 Vide “Letter to British Indian Association”, 18 1 1933
('59', 63, 0, 1, 112271) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 63, 1, 2, 112312) those grounds were not at least urged at the Conference in Bombay by any one of the Bengal representatives.
('59', 63, 1, 3, 112420) You hardly need my assurance that I would be grateful to you for your frank opinion, even though it may be against the Pact.
('59', 63, 1, 4, 112545) I have no other end in life to serve but that of truth.
('59', 63, 1, 5, 112601) It is therefore never too late for me to mend an error, of which the conviction has gone home to me.
('59', 63, 2, 6, 112702) Yours sincerely,
('59', 63, 3, 7, 112719) From a microfilm: S.N. 18983

('59', 68, 3, 6, 119948) 1 From Salivati’s letter of yesterday received by me I thought that he had done likewise, but now I see that the fault seems to have been entirely his.
('59', 68, 3, 7, 120100) His motives was no doubt good, but his judgement wholly bad, but before I can give my final opinion, I would like you to send me his despatch as it was received by you.

('59', 68, 3, 10, 120749) The unfortunate report came at such an awkward time when the slightest error on my part could have undone a structure that is being built up with patient toil and most delicate care.
('59', 68, 3, 11, 120932) Happily, the A. P. interview 3 I really gave most reluctantly, both out of my regard for you and solicitude for Salivati, and your prompt publication of my telegram averted what might have proved a dangerous situation.

('59', 70, 1, 2, 123553) 102. LETTER TO KARNAD SADASHIVA RAO
('59', 70, 2, 3, 123589) January 21, 1933
('59', 70, 3, 4, 123606) MY DEAR SADASHIVA RAO,
('59', 70, 4, 5, 123629) I have your letter of 13th instant written on the train.
('59', 70, 4, 6, 123686) Untruthful propaganda and abuse are the lot generally of all reformers.
('59', 70, 4, 7, 123758) Why should we be any exception to the general rule?
('59', 70, 4, 8, 123810) Those who can stand such abuse and will not retaliate by matching two untruths against one have not only nothing to fear but will actually gain in strength through such unscrupulous opposition.
('59', 70, 4, 9, 124004) Therefore, so long as consciousness of the correctness of the campaign and the purity of the means employed in conducting it continue, we may not become agitated in any shape or form over such opposition.
('59', 70, 4, 10, 124209) But we may be sure of thriving on it.
('59', 70, 4, 11, 124247) And when we have positive consciousness of the truth in us and the strength derived from it, we need never be afraid of being charged with weakness.
('59', 70, 4, 12, 124396) He who for fear of appearing weak hesitates to say or do the right thing becomes untruthful in the very act, and therefore it may be said of him that he never had consciousness of the truth in him.
('59', 70, 5, 13, 124594) I read through the questions you left with me.
('59', 70, 5, 14, 124641) I have not dealt with them because you will find that every one of the points is amply covered in the statements already made by me.
('59', 70, 5, 15, 124774) I wonder if you have seen my letter 1 to the Editor of the Justice published on the day of its expiry.
('59', 70, 6, 16, 124877) There now remains your question about the conduct of Congressmen in connection with the provincial and district branches of the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 70, 6, 17, 125039) They should be identified with activities of these organizations only in so far as their services are wanted and no further, even though the work may appear to them to be languishing.
('59', 70, 6, 18, 125223) In a service that may take in the activity of as many true servants who will offer their services, one need not belong to or work through an organization.
('59', 70, 6, 19, 125378) Even a cup of water lovingly handed to a Harijan, giving or procuring medical aid for an ailing Harijan, giving shelter to a shelterless Harijan, and innumerable such individual
('59', 70, 7, 20, 125556) 1 Vide “Letter to T. A. V. Nathan”, 11 1 1933
('59', 71, 0, 1, 125602) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 71, 1, 2, 125643) acts are a solid contribution to the removal of untouchability.

('59', 76, 7, 20, 134527) 112. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 76, 8, 21, 134562) January 21, 1933
('59', 76, 9, 22, 134579) Referring to the Delhi message published this morning, in which probable difficulties in the way of the Government according sanction to the Temple entry Bills were anticipated, Gandhiji observed: If the report is an intelligent anticipation of the forthcoming Viceregal decision I can only say it will be a tragedy.
('59', 76, 9, 23, 134896) I emphatically repudiate the suggestion that there is any political objective behind these measures.
('59', 76, 9, 24, 134997) If court decisions had not hardened a doubtful custom into law, no legislation would probably be required.
('59', 76, 9, 25, 135104) I would
('59', 77, 0, 1, 135112) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 77, 1, 2, 135153) myself regard State interference in religious matters as an intolerable nuisance.
('59', 77, 1, 3, 135235) But, here, legislation becomes an imperative necessity in order to remove the legal obstruction and, based as it will be on popular will so far as I can see, there can be no question of a clash between parties representing rival opinions.
('59', 77, 1, 4, 135474) It has been suggested that one of the reasons for withholding sanction is likely to be that there has been no demand on the part of Harijans for legislation to remove their social disabilities.
('59', 77, 1, 5, 135668) But, I do know that Dr. Ambedkar’s memorandum bristles with suggestions for legislation regarding all sorts of social disabilities.
('59', 77, 1, 6, 135800) Yet, I hope nobody wants a hurricane agitation on behalf of Harijans before the social and religious yoke is removed from off their necks.
('59', 77, 1, 7, 135939) Furthermore, I make bold to claim, if there has not been a loud demand by Harijans for temple entry, I am responsible for it, because I have been advising them not to enter the agitation on a large scale, whilst caste Hindus are themselves making Herculean efforts to implement the Bombay Resolution of September last, which pledges caste Hindus to opening public temples, among other things, to Harijans.
('59', 77, 1, 8, 136345) In conclusion, I would only repeat that the refusal to sanction the introduction of a measure demanded by caste Hindu opinion would obstruct the progress of reform, whose advisability no lover of religious freedom has questioned.
('59', 77, 2, 9, 136575) Mr. Gandhi has declined to comment on the suggestion that the Government
('59', 77, 3, 10, 136648) might decide in favour of a single Central legislation, saying that he would like to
('59', 77, 4, 11, 136733) have more details regarding this proposal.
('59', 77, 4, 12, 136776) The Hindu, 23 1 1933

('59', 80, 4, 7, 141469) 116. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('59', 80, 5, 8, 141501) January 22, 1933
('59', 80, 6, 9, 141518) PREMA, I was relieved to get your letter.
('59', 80, 6, 10, 141560) Even worry is a child of imagination.
('59', 80, 6, 11, 141598) Why should I worry if I do not get a letter from you, and why should I feel relieved on getting one?
('59', 80, 6, 12, 141699) If you ask me this question, I would not be able to reply to it, or would only say: ‘‘This is what ignorant attachment means.” A foolish letter from you would not upset me.
('59', 80, 6, 13, 141872) If, however, I see your error or shortcoming and do not point it out to you, I would not be doing my duty as your well wisher, co worker, friend or father.
('59', 80, 6, 14, 142028) What I find strange is that you should get angry with me and sulk for telling you something with a sincere motive, instead of thanking me for it.
('59', 80, 6, 15, 142174) Should we not thank a person for telling us frankly what he feels?
('59', 80, 6, 16, 142241) I learnt this in my very childhood.
('59', 80, 6, 17, 142277) I do want you to learn it from me.
('59', 80, 6, 18, 142312) If my understanding of a situation is wrong, I deserve to be pitied, and, if it is correct, I would be doing you good.
('59', 80, 6, 19, 142431) In either case, you gain something, in that you come to know better the person with whom you have thrown in your lot.
('59', 80, 6, 20, 142549) I want that all of you should know my shortcomings and deficiencies and it is always my effort to show them myself.
('59', 80, 6, 21, 142665) I don’t wish to hide even my thoughts.
('59', 80, 6, 22, 142704) I would even write them down if I had the necessary gift.
('59', 80, 6, 23, 142762) But I know I cannot do that.
('59', 80, 6, 24, 142791) I don’t think there can be any power in the world which can penetrate all the secrets of thought.
('59', 80, 6, 25, 142889) Probably we shall be able to know them if somebody invents a machine to reveal them.
('59', 80, 6, 26, 142974) Even while I was writing these few sentences, my imagination traversed the universe many times over.
('59', 80, 6, 27, 143075) You will admit that everybody cannot understand whether or not he has the poison in his heart.
('59', 80, 6, 28, 143170) Because one does not consciously wish to nurse hatred, it does not mean that there is no hatred in one’s heart.
('59', 81, 0, 1, 143282) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 81, 1, 2, 143323) It takes hold of us against our will.
('59', 81, 1, 3, 143361) You will probably not admit that anybody whose heart is full of anger is also full of hatred.
('59', 81, 1, 4, 143455) If you do not, then the word ‘‘poison” does not have the same meaning for you and me.
('59', 81, 1, 5, 143541) I remember that Ba often charged me with having poison in my heart.
('59', 81, 1, 6, 143609) How can I deny that charge?
('59', 81, 1, 7, 143637) I may not have believed that there was any poison in my words.
('59', 81, 1, 8, 143700) But that is beside the point.
('59', 81, 1, 9, 143730) What should matter to me is that she felt the poison.
('59', 81, 1, 10, 143784) Words which are perfectly truthful and spoken with perfect love will never hurt anybody.
('59', 81, 1, 11, 143873) They may sometimes hurt one in the beginning, but such a person himself will afterwards admit their beneficial effect on him.
('59', 81, 1, 12, 143999) I should like you not to be your own judge in all matters.
('59', 81, 1, 13, 144058) It is possible that others judge you better than you do yourself.
('59', 81, 1, 14, 144124) I will now end this tale of “poison”.
('59', 81, 1, 15, 144162) The question of your leaving the Ashram does not arise just now.
('59', 81, 1, 16, 144227) It will arise only after I am released and return to the Ashram to stay there.
('59', 81, 1, 17, 144306) That is how I read your letter.
('59', 81, 1, 18, 144338) Morally speaking, it can arise only then, if at all, for, so long as I cannot return to the Ashram to stay in it, in the eyes of the inmates of the Ashram I will remain a prisoner.
('59', 81, 1, 19, 144519) All of you who decided to stay on when I bade good bye to the Ashram bound yourselves thereby to remain there till I returned.
('59', 81, 1, 20, 144646) If I am right in believing this, it is a waste of time and energy to think now what should be done when I return to stay there.
('59', 81, 1, 21, 144774) The news you have given about happenings in the Ashram is very useful to me.
('59', 81, 1, 22, 144851) You should discuss the problem of Lakshmi with Narandas, and if both of you decide that she should be married, it should be done soon.
('59', 81, 1, 23, 144986) Her restlessness also is likely to be the result of an unconscious desire to get married.
('59', 81, 1, 24, 145076) She is now of marriageable age, and she does intend to marry.
('59', 81, 1, 25, 145138) The desire to wait till I am released should be regarded as nothing but ignorant attachment to me.
('59', 81, 1, 26, 145237) You should try and understand her heart properly, and not wait for her emphatic consent.
('59', 81, 1, 27, 145326) It seems to me desirable to take the advice of Lakshmibehn and Durgabehn in this matter.
('59', 81, 1, 28, 145415) They would understand the problem better than you can.
('59', 81, 1, 29, 145470) I understand from what you yourself have said that you have no experience of how a girl feels when she desires to marry.
('59', 81, 1, 30, 145591) In other words, you have never felt the desire to marry.
('59', 81, 1, 31, 145648) I also know some other unmarried women who have never felt it.
('59', 81, 1, 32, 145711) Some other women remain unmarried with an effort of will.
('59', 81, 1, 33, 145769) They know what marriage means.
('59', 81, 1, 34, 145800) What advice should I give you about your health?
('59', 81, 1, 35, 145849) Ghee seems
('59', 82, 0, 1, 145860) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 83
('59', 82, 1, 2, 145904) to be absolutely necessary for it.
('59', 82, 1, 3, 145939) Whenever you leave the Ashram, your weight increases, and as soon as you return to the Ashram you lose the weight you had gained.
('59', 82, 1, 4, 146069) You must get over this weakness.
('59', 82, 1, 5, 146102) How it can be done, you alone know.
('59', 82, 1, 6, 146138) I hope you experience no difficulty now in speaking.
('59', 82, 1, 7, 146191) I don’t wish to catch anybody in my snare.
('59', 82, 1, 8, 146234) What would be my plight if all people became my slaves?
('59', 82, 1, 9, 146290) And, moreover, I am sure that any such effort would be doomed to failure.
('59', 82, 1, 10, 146364) Even if it is true that I try to catch people in my snare, why should you lose confidence in yourself for that reason?
('59', 82, 1, 11, 146483) Your letters are sufficient evidence that you are vigilant and not likely to succumb.
('59', 82, 1, 12, 146569) It does seem, however, that you are perpetually afraid that you will let yourself be caught.
('59', 82, 1, 13, 146662) That is a bad sign.
('59', 82, 1, 14, 146682) Having resolved that you will not let yourself be caught, why should you feel afraid?
('59', 82, 1, 15, 146768) But may it also not be possible that you and I do not mean the same thing by ‘‘getting caught”?
('59', 82, 3, 16, 146864) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 10323
('59', 82, 4, 17, 146909) 117. LETTER TO BHAGWANJI P. PANDYA
('59', 82, 5, 18, 146944) January 22, 1933
('59', 82, 6, 19, 146961) BHAGWANJI, Chit and chitta are two different words, but the latter is derived from the former.
('59', 82, 6, 20, 147056) Chit means consciousness, or it can be interpreted to mean that which can have consciousness, namely, the atman.
('59', 82, 6, 21, 147169) To say that the chitta of one who has overcome attachment is always serene and contented means that his atman is so.
('59', 82, 6, 22, 147286) Chitta may also mean the mind.
('59', 82, 6, 23, 147317) The word should be interpreted according to the context in the sentence or the verse in which it occurs.
('59', 82, 6, 24, 147422) In trying to explain the meaning of dhyanayoga, one frequently has to use the word yoga.
('59', 82, 6, 25, 147511) It should be remembered when doing so that yoga means skill in work or action done without attachment.
('59', 82, 7, 26, 147614) Blessings from
('59', 82, 9, 27, 147629) From Gujarati: C.W. 350a.

('59', 86, 9, 10, 151936) I note what the resolution says about a distinct name.
('59', 86, 9, 11, 151991) A name is inevitable till there is a complete fusion.
('59', 86, 9, 12, 152045) The only question therefore is what name to distinguish the so called untouchables by; and ‘Harijans’ was the name suggested by some of them, and as it was a name that exactly fitted the condition, I adopted it; for, those who are forsaken by mankind become the chosen of God, and ‘Harijan’ literally means that.

('59', 89, 6, 14, 156211) 132. LETTER TO SUMANGAL PRAKASH
('59', 89, 7, 15, 156243) YERAVDA MANDIR, January 23, 1933
('59', 89, 8, 16, 156276) SUMANGAL, I have your letter after many weeks, nay, months.
('59', 89, 8, 17, 156336) It is only proper to utilize some time for improving your health.
('59', 89, 8, 18, 156402) I keep getting news of Kanta.
('59', 89, 8, 19, 156432) Saroop gives me news of her, as does Prabhavati.
('59', 89, 8, 20, 156481) I have no doubt she has been putting her time to good use.
('59', 89, 8, 21, 156540) If one gets food from outside after securing permission, for the sake of one’s health, one is doing nothing wrong.
('59', 89, 8, 22, 156655) But it is praiseworthy if one is content with whatever food one gets inside and refrains from asking for more.
('59', 89, 8, 23, 156766) But he who cannot maintain his health on the food he gets in prison, and has secured permission to obtain it from outside and can easily have it, yet does not do so and so spoils his health, is obstinate.
('59', 89, 8, 24, 156971) Perhaps he could be considered a literalist.
('59', 89, 9, 25, 157016) 1 Title of the head of a small principality
('59', 90, 0, 1, 157060) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 91
('59', 90, 1, 2, 157104) I certainly do not think there is any harm in having a shikha 1. It is a time honoured custom which the reformer may not try to change and so run into trouble.
('59', 90, 1, 3, 157264) You may not find a strong reason in support of every custom, yet if it is popular and there is nothing morally wrong in it, is deserves to be followed.
('59', 90, 2, 4, 157416) The statement that “a few medicines are found to be effective but they are well known” is not happily phrased.
('59', 90, 2, 5, 157527) The meaning can be made more explicit.
('59', 90, 2, 6, 157566) Although one may not repose one’s faith in allopathy, some allopathic medicines can certainly be used.
('59', 90, 2, 7, 157669) One does not have to go out and look for them.
('59', 90, 2, 8, 157716) They are well known household remedies such as castor oil, quinine, kariata, sonamukhi.
('59', 90, 2, 9, 157804) I have not come to any harm from fasting.
('59', 90, 2, 10, 157846) Fasting may be resorted to in old age.
('59', 90, 2, 11, 157885) Then, a fast undertaken from spiritual motives is not difficult to go through.
('59', 90, 2, 12, 157964) Of course one does become emaciated because there is not enough fat in the body.
('59', 90, 2, 13, 158045) You write in haste and therefore your letters are difficult to decipher.
('59', 90, 2, 14, 158118) If you write a little slowly they will be easier to read.
('59', 90, 3, 15, 158176) Blessings from

('59', 92, 1, 2, 160226) 137. LETTER TO S. J. SOMAVANSHI
('59', 92, 2, 3, 160258) January 23, 1933
('59', 92, 3, 4, 160275) BHAI SOMAVANSHI, I read your loving letter from beginning to end.
('59', 92, 3, 5, 160341) I have received the books 1 also.
('59', 92, 3, 6, 160375) I also listened to the life story of the Maharaj.
('59', 92, 3, 7, 160425) I have read almost all the marked portions of the book.
('59', 92, 3, 8, 160481) Both failed to impress me.
('59', 92, 3, 9, 160508) Chiefly because we find no basis for regarding the so called untouchables as untouchables; nor for the treatment meted out to them.
('59', 92, 3, 10, 160640) How am I at fault?
('59', 92, 3, 11, 160659) I have been saying for the last 45 years the very thing about the eradication of untouchability that I say now.
('59', 92, 3, 12, 160771) My views have been well known in India for more than 25 years.
('59', 92, 3, 13, 160834) Now and then some opposition was certainly heard but I incurred no one’s wrath.
('59', 92, 3, 14, 160914) Now that I am ready to do penance for it I am blamed.
('59', 92, 3, 15, 160968) But the Shastras and the saints have preached the necessity of tapascharya 2 whenever dharma dwindles and this is what I am attempting to do.
('59', 92, 3, 16, 161110) There is no headstrongness about it.
('59', 92, 3, 17, 161147) How can that man be headstrong who is ever prepared to correct his errors?
('59', 92, 3, 18, 161222) By pointing out the omission on the part of saints to lay stress on this particular problem you are doing them and me an injustice.
('59', 92, 3, 19, 161354) The saints do not try to remove all the evils, nor can they do so.
('59', 92, 3, 20, 161421) They simply disseminate dharma and in the process try to remove some evil.
('59', 92, 3, 21, 161496) Even the avatars are unable to destroy all evil; they perform their deeds concentrating on the chief evil of their times.
('59', 92, 3, 22, 161618) An important feature of the non violent spirit is that it always keeps the popular will in view.
('59', 92, 3, 23, 161715) The anti untouchability movement may also be taken as basically meant to test public will.
('59', 92, 3, 24, 161806) The highest religion is useless for those who are not prepared to live by it.
('59', 92, 3, 25, 161884) Compulsion has absolutely no place in the spirit of non violence.
('59', 92, 3, 26, 161950) You are correct in suggesting that I should offer daily prayers to God to show me the right path.
('59', 92, 3, 27, 162048) I not only constantly do that but believe that I take no action without His command; you may rest assured on this.
('59', 92, 3, 28, 162163) MOHANDAS GANDHI From a microfilm of the Hindi: S.N. 18997
('59', 92, 4, 29, 162221) 1 Biographies of a Marathi saint 2 Self suffering as moral discipline

('59', 93, 1, 2, 162332) 138. A LETTER
('59', 93, 2, 3, 162346) January 23, 1933
('59', 93, 3, 4, 162363) Observing silence implies abstaining from talking, gestures, food and drink, and closing one’s eyes and ears, i.e., remaining in seclusion and losing oneself in thought.
('59', 93, 3, 5, 162533) On the day of silence, one should remember God.
('59', 93, 3, 6, 162581) The purpose of silence is meditation.
('59', 93, 3, 7, 162619) [From Hindi]
