('59', 94, 0, 1, 163724) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 95
('59', 94, 1, 2, 163768) 141. STATEMENT ON VICEROY’S DECISION
('59', 94, 2, 3, 163805) January 24, 1933
('59', 94, 3, 4, 163822) Having read the Government decision on the two Bills 1
('59', 94, 4, 5, 163877) about untouchability now before the country, I cannot help expressing my regret on general grounds that the Government could not see their way to allow both the Bills to be discussed by the respective Legislatures and the country.
('59', 94, 4, 6, 164108) Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill restricts itself to one particular issue of temple entry and that too in the Madras Presidency, and the opening of each temple depends on the will of the majority of those entitled to temple entry.
('59', 94, 4, 7, 164328) It therefore reduces the possibility of a clash between one party and another party to a minimum and to a zero if the reformers play the game, i.e., allow for the religious scruples even of a microscopic minority as my compromise proposal does.
('59', 94, 4, 8, 164573) But this was not to be.
('59', 94, 4, 9, 164597) From a strict sanatanist point, the Madras Bill was perhaps the lesser of the two evils as they would put it.
('59', 94, 4, 10, 164707) It was easier for a reformer to cope with, and for me personally too as a fasting hostage, for Viceregal sanction would have in all probability successfully prevented a fast over Guruvayur.
('59', 94, 4, 11, 164897) But the Government of India had willed otherwise.
('59', 94, 4, 12, 164947) I must try to trace the hand of God in it.
('59', 94, 4, 13, 164990) He wants to try me through and through.
('59', 94, 4, 14, 165030) If He does, He will have to give me adequate strength as He has always vouchsafed those who would surrender themselves wholly to Him.
('59', 94, 4, 15, 165164) The all India Bill is short and sweet, being of negative character in one way.
('59', 94, 4, 16, 165243) It gives no direct aid to the reformer.
('59', 94, 4, 17, 165283) It merely refuses aid to any and every individual sanatanist who would come to seek assistance in the secular courts to impose his will on the whole Hindu society and to enforce a custom which the latter may consider to be repugnant to Hindu Shastras and the innate moral sense of man.
('59', 94, 4, 18, 165569) It abolishes legal untouchability, leaving the social and religious to its fate.
('59', 94, 4, 19, 165650) The sanction given to this Bill is an unintentional challenge to Hinduism and the reformer.
('59', 94, 4, 20, 165742) Hinduism will take care of itself if the reformer will be true to himself.
('59', 94, 4, 21, 165817) Thus considered, the Government of India’s decision must be regarded as a godsend.
('59', 94, 4, 22, 165900) It clears the issue.
('59', 94, 5, 23, 165921) 1 Vide footnote 3, “Letter to Ranchhoddas Patwari”, 11 1 1933. For Gandhiji’s reaction to the announcement, vide “Talk witha M. G. Bhandari”a, 24 1 1933
('59', 95, 0, 1, 166074) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 95, 1, 2, 166115) makes it easy for India and the world to understand the tremendous importance of the moral struggle now going on in India.
('59', 95, 1, 3, 166238) It takes it at one sweep to its natural platform to which it was timidly advancing.
('59', 95, 1, 4, 166322) As a life long reformer and fighter, I must take up the challenge in all humility, and so must every Hindu who was directly or indirectly a party to the resolution 1 adopted under the chairmanship of the revered Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya.
('59', 95, 1, 5, 166563) The resolution bears repetition:
('59', 95, 2, 6, 166596) This Conference resolves that henceforth, amongst Hindus, no one shall be regarded as ‘untouchable’ by reason of his birth, and that those who have been so regarded hitherto will have the same rights as other Hindus in regard to the use of public wells, public schools, public roads and all other public institutions.
('59', 95, 2, 7, 166914) These rights shall have statutory recognition at the first opportunity, and shall be one of the earliest Acts of the swaraj Parliament, if it shall not have received such recognition before that time.
('59', 95, 3, 8, 167115) It is further agreed that it shall be the duty of all Hindu leaders to secure,
('59', 95, 4, 9, 167194) by every legitimate and peaceful means, the early removal of all social
('59', 95, 5, 10, 167266) disabilities now imposed by custom upon the so called untouchable classes
('59', 95, 6, 11, 167340) including the bar in respect of admission into temples.
('59', 95, 6, 12, 167396) Let the reader carefully note the words printed in italics.
('59', 95, 6, 13, 167456) The resolution contemplates, if at all possible, the removal of legal untouchability even before the establishment of a swaraj Parliament.
('59', 95, 6, 14, 167595) The opportunity has now offered itself.
('59', 95, 6, 15, 167635) No Hindu who is jealous of the honour of Hinduism or the word given to Harijans dare let the opportunity slip.
('59', 95, 6, 16, 167746) Even the sanatanist, if he will read the all India Bill, as I do, may not resist it.
('59', 95, 6, 17, 167831) For, has he not said to me, has he not said it even in his writings, that he has no quarrel with political and civic rights being given to Harijans on the same terms as caste Hindus?
('59', 95, 6, 18, 168014) In other words, he has no objection to Harijans being treated as equals with the rest in the eye of the law.
('59', 95, 6, 19, 168123) If he is not, in the eye of religion, that is a matter for the sanatanist and his conscience.
('59', 95, 6, 20, 168217) The law’s assistance must not be summoned to aid him to enforce his conscience against a fellow being.
('59', 95, 6, 21, 168320) The sanatanist Shastris whom I had the pleasure of meeting had been able only to cite me verses to the effect that if anyone is polluted by the touch of an untouchable he has either to take a sip of water or
('59', 95, 7, 22, 168528) 1 On September 25, 1932; vide also “Resolution ata the Hindu Leaders’ aConference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932
('59', 96, 0, 1, 168630) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 97
('59', 96, 1, 2, 168674) have a bath.
('59', 96, 1, 3, 168687) There seems to be nowhere mention of punishment for an untouchable entering a public place including a temple.
('59', 96, 1, 4, 168798) And, in no case, should the aid of secular law be summoned to punish an untouchable guilty of mere infringement of a sacerdotal rule.
('59', 96, 1, 5, 168932) The present Bill rightly renders such an interference by law impossible.
('59', 96, 1, 6, 169005) The opening of temples to Harijans would, under the Bill, be regulated by mutual adjustment.
('59', 96, 1, 7, 169098) Where the opinion of the temple going population is not ripe for reform, naturally the Harijans cannot enter the temples.
('59', 96, 1, 8, 169220) Where the opinion is ripe, the law cannot be invoked by individuals to thwart the will of the majority.
('59', 96, 1, 9, 169324) But whatever the sanatanists may decide, the movement for temple entry now broadens from Guruvayur in the extreme south to Hardwar in the north, and my fast, though it remains further postponed, depends not, now, upon Guruvayur only but extends automatically to temples in general.
('59', 96, 1, 10, 169606) That is to say, the fast becomes dependent upon the actions of reformers not regarding the Madras Bill which was to cover Guruvayur only, but regarding the all India Bill which covers all temples including Guruvayur.
('59', 96, 1, 11, 169823) And so it has been throughout my life.
('59', 96, 1, 12, 169862) One step has naturally led me on to another, even despite myself.
('59', 96, 1, 13, 169928) I was confining my attention to the Madras Bill.
('59', 96, 1, 14, 169977) It was enough for me.
('59', 96, 1, 15, 169999) Even on Saturday last, that is, the 21st January, when the Associated Press correspondent asked my opinion of the Associated Press Delhi correspondent’s forecast, I declined to commit myself to any opinion on the all India Bill as compared to the Madras Bill.
('59', 96, 1, 16, 170259) 1 I was not prepared to face a bigger and graver contingency.
('59', 96, 1, 17, 170321) But now that it comes upon me as an accomplished fact, I dare not flinch.
('59', 96, 1, 18, 170395) The Government pronouncement would have one to think that the Bill will be one long drawn out agony, and may never become the law of the land.
('59', 96, 1, 19, 170538) They are right, from their standpoint, in being over cautious.
('59', 96, 1, 20, 170601) But if Hindu conscience is really roused against untouchability, as the latter is practised today, the Bill can become law in no time.
('59', 96, 1, 21, 170736) The Government cannot resist the unequivocal expression of Hindu opinion in favour of it.
('59', 96, 1, 22, 170826) Despite sanatanist opposition, my belief is that a vast mass of Hindu opinion is against untouchability, though it may not take energetic steps to remove it.
('59', 96, 1, 23, 170984) It is that faith which sustains me.
('59', 96, 1, 24, 171020) No further ordinary propaganda will convince the
('59', 96, 2, 25, 171069) 1 Vide “Interview to Associated Press”, 21 1 1933
('59', 97, 0, 1, 171119) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 97, 1, 2, 171160) Hindu mind of the sense of wrong of untouchability if it is not already convinced by years of work in that behalf.
('59', 97, 1, 3, 171275) It requires then, as it has done before now, the extraordinary propaganda of penance.
('59', 97, 1, 4, 171361) It may be that it needs the stimulus of a fast on the part of one who has made his life one with them.
('59', 97, 1, 5, 171464) If so, they shall have it.
('59', 97, 1, 6, 171491) They must either remove untouchability or remove me from their midst.
('59', 97, 1, 7, 171561) Let me proclaim it, for the thousandth time, that for me, as with my co workers, the removal of untouchability is an indispensable religious need and the opening of temples to Harijans, being a pure spiritual act, is an indispensable test of that removal.
('59', 97, 1, 8, 171817) It is the one thing that alone can give new life and new hope to Harijans, as no mere economic uplift can do.
('59', 97, 1, 9, 171927) Economic and all other uplift will follow temple entry as light follows dawn.
('59', 97, 1, 10, 172005) The one single act of opening temples to Harijans will purify Hinduism, and will open the hearts of both caste Hindus and Harijans to receive new light.
('59', 97, 1, 11, 172158) The message of the temples will penetrate every Harijan hut; the message of economic and educational uplift will touch only those to whom it is personally brought.
('59', 97, 1, 12, 172322) This proposition of mine can easily be understood by those who, like me, believe in temples as an integral part of Hinduism, as churches and mosques are of Christianity and Islam.
('59', 97, 1, 13, 172502) It is not necessary that every Harijan should at once enter the temples.
('59', 97, 1, 14, 172575) It is enough and necessary if he knows that he has acquired that right.
('59', 97, 1, 15, 172647) And in this religious conception of Hinduism fasts and the like take their natural and necessary place.
('59', 97, 1, 16, 172751) They are then, no more coercion than any bona fide cry of love of the Divine is.
('59', 97, 2, 17, 172832) The Hindu, 25 1 1933
('59', 98, 0, 1, 172853) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 99
('59', 98, 1, 2, 172897) 142. LETTER TO G. M. THENGE
('59', 98, 2, 3, 172925) January 24, 1933
('59', 98, 3, 4, 172942) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('59', 98, 3, 5, 172975) 1 My statement 2 has not the meaning that you have assigned to it, as would be quite clear to you if you will read it as a whole.
('59', 98, 3, 6, 173105) I have considered myself to be incapable of coming to a judgement one way or the other, if only because I have not all the data for coming to a judgement.
('59', 98, 3, 7, 173260) I have therefore stated in unequivocal language that every Congressman has to decide for himself or herself, taking stock of the circumstances over which they alone have control and I have none, as also of their own individual obligations of which they alone can have knowledge and I can have none.
('59', 98, 4, 8, 173559) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('59', 98, 6, 11, 173653) 143. LETTER TO SUBRAHMANIA SHASTRI
('59', 98, 7, 12, 173688) January 24, 1933
('59', 98, 8, 13, 173705) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter enclosing your reply to Acharya Dhruva’s opinion in Sanskrit about untouchability.
('59', 98, 8, 14, 173829) I do not remember having said whichever side stops correspondence is to be considered to have accepted the other’s position.
('59', 98, 8, 15, 173954) In my opinion such a thing should not be regarded as conclusive, because each party may exhaust all points of difference
('59', 98, 9, 16, 174075) 1 The addressee had written: ‘‘In answer to those Congressmen who wish to know whether they should prosecute the civil disobedience campaign or should take an active interest in the campaign against untouchability, you have reminded them of the celebrated English proverb: ‘Much wants more and loses all.’ I presume that you intend thereby to convey that we have had enough of the civil disobedience movement in the past and that we do not want it any longer, lest we stand to lose all that we aspire for.
('59', 98, 9, 17, 174581) .” 2 Dated January 7, 1933; vide “Statement to the Press”, 7 1 1933
('59', 99, 0, 1, 174649) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 99, 1, 2, 174691) and may still maintain their respective positions.
('59', 99, 1, 3, 174742) However, you will not find me suddenly stopping the correspondence, because I want to get all the wisdom and all the information that I can from everyone.
('59', 99, 1, 4, 174897) Coming to your reply or rejoinder as you call it, I shall leave Acharya Dhruva to answer for himself, but you do not carry conviction even to a layman like myself.
('59', 99, 1, 5, 175061) You say that the word api 1
('59', 99, 2, 6, 175089) only denotes the unfitness of the Chandala and the height of the path of devotion.
('59', 99, 2, 7, 175172) Do you not see the inconsistency of your statement?
('59', 99, 2, 8, 175224) If the Chandala is unfit, there is no height (I suppose you mean ‘greatness’) about the path of devotion.
('59', 99, 2, 9, 175330) The path of devotion is truly great, because it brings peace and joy and salvation even to the Chandala.
('59', 99, 2, 10, 175435) Instances of the use of api by way of emphasis can surely be multiplied.
('59', 99, 2, 11, 175508) In your second paragraph, emphasis is not on the fact that here the Chandala was pious but that it was the Chandala who was speaking.
('59', 99, 2, 12, 175642) Most of the sanatanists who oppose temple entry by Harijans contend that no piety on the part of a Chandala would cure him of his disability.
('59', 99, 2, 13, 175784) In the third clause, your admission that all life as atman is one rules out the impassable barrier between touchables and untouchables.
('59', 99, 2, 14, 175920) The verse in question itself notes the differentiation between persons and bodies and yet insists on equality of treatment.
('59', 99, 2, 15, 176044) I need not labour the rest of your replies except to say that they are unconvincing to me.
('59', 99, 2, 16, 176135) However, without my comments on your reply, I am forwarding it to Acharya Dhruva, for his own independent reply which I shall gladly send to you when it comes to me.
('59', 99, 3, 17, 176301) Yours sincerely,

('59', 102, 1, 2, 178862) 148. LETTER TO R. N. BHIDE
('59', 102, 2, 3, 178889) January 24, 1933
('59', 102, 3, 4, 178906) DEAR FRIEND, I have your pathetic letter.
('59', 102, 3, 5, 178948) Do not mix up two questions, the fast and temple entry.
('59', 102, 3, 6, 179004) Dismiss the fast from your mind, because it is a personal matter and it may or may not come.
('59', 102, 3, 7, 179097) Temple entry is the question.
('59', 102, 3, 8, 179127) The economic and the educational questions are what the adjectives imply.
('59', 102, 3, 9, 179201) Temple entry is a spiritual act, transforming the whole society by one single act of admission.
('59', 102, 3, 10, 179297) It will electrify into a new life the whole of the Harijan population, and it will purify Hinduism as no single act that I can think of can do.
('59', 102, 3, 11, 179441) If you have the Hindu religious instinct in you, you will not find it difficult to follow my argument.

('59', 107, 6, 11, 188092) January 25, 1933
('59', 107, 7, 12, 188109) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('59', 107, 7, 13, 188142) Here are my answers: The opening of temples to Harijans is to be an act of penance on the part of caste Hindus or rather an act of payment of an obligation due to them.
('59', 107, 7, 14, 188311) 2 That one act will elevate them.
('59', 107, 7, 15, 188345) Throwingopen of temples to them is the foundation for their elevation and not a reward for good behaviour.
('59', 107, 7, 16, 188452) They will only be liable to the same conditions as caste Hindus are as to daily bath, etc.
('59', 107, 7, 17, 188543) But just as we do not ask every caste Hindu who enters a temple whether he has conformed to the conditions or not, unless he bears the mark of non performance on his own person at the time of entry, even so we may not cross question a Harijan in appearance showing no disregard of conditions whether he has fulfilled other conditions or not.
('59', 107, 7, 18, 188885) Please remember that abstention from flesh and drink is not an indispensable condition of entry for caste Hindus in all sects of Hinduism.
('59', 107, 7, 19, 189024) Personally, I would like such abstention to be a condition, but it cannot be imposed upon Harijans, if it is not imposed upon all Hindus.
('59', 107, 7, 20, 189162) If three or four orthodox Brahmins cause obstruction, miscalled satyagraha, by stretching themselves in front of the temple, they can be easily dodged.
('59', 107, 7, 21, 189314) Temple entry is not complete until Harijans are
('59', 107, 8, 22, 189362) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('59', 107, 9, 23, 189389) 2 For a discussion, vide “Talk with Duncan Greenless”, 25 1 1933
('59', 108, 0, 1, 189454) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 109
('59', 108, 1, 2, 189499) allowed to enter on the same terms and up to the same part as caste Hindus are allowed.
('59', 108, 1, 3, 189587) There is no question of Harijans entering the sanctuary if caste Hindus do not enter the sanctuary and only those who perform the ceremonial are allowed to enter.
('59', 108, 1, 4, 189750) I think this answers all your questions.

('59', 112, 3, 7, 194913) Varna refers to a person’s qualities of character and occupation.
('59', 112, 3, 8, 194979) Caste is based at best on convenience.
('59', 112, 3, 9, 195018) Caste deserves to be abolished, whereas varna should be reformed.

('59', 112, 3, 11, 195182) There may perhaps be no harm in serving one’s own community, but the best service which one can do to it is to cultivate relations with members of other communities.
('59', 112, 3, 12, 195348) One should not be attached to one’s own caste and be proud of it.
('59', 112, 3, 13, 195414) Though interdining and intermarriage will be restricted to groups of similar temperament and occupation, that is, within the limits of the same varna, this was not an essential feature of the system in former times.

('59', 116, 3, 4, 201932) Asked if his intention was to hold his fast in abeyance till the fate of Mr. Ranga Iyer’s Bill was known, Mahatma Gandhi replied that it would depend on circumstances arising from day to day.
('59', 116, 3, 5, 202124) If Mr. Ranga Iyer’s Bill hung up indefinitely, the question of temple entry could not await solution so long.
('59', 116, 3, 6, 202234) I am hoping that Mr. Ranga Iyer’s Bill being of a negative character, all Hindus will see that it does not interfere with religion in any shape or form and if sanatanists admit that the Harijans should suffer under no social disabilities they must make good their admission by welcoming the measure.
('59', 116, 3, 7, 202534) They do not seem to seek legal protection for enforcing religious observances.
('59', 116, 3, 8, 202613) Religious observance ceases to be religious, the moment it becomes enforceable by law.
('59', 116, 3, 9, 202700) It must depend on mutual goodwill and on the readiness of Hindus in general to perform religious observances.
('59', 116, 3, 10, 202810) There are numerous religious observances in the Hindu religion as in all other religions but they are not enforceable by law and what Mr. Ranga Iyer’s Bill provides is that the religious prohibition against temple entry should not be forced at the point of the bayonet.
('59', 116, 3, 11, 203080) But should the sanatanists not appreciate this obvious proposition of mine and there is opposition to the Bill, it would become a question for me as to what would be my duty.
('59', 116, 3, 12, 203255) But I am hoping that there would be an unequivocal declaration by the vast mass of Hindus to favour the Bill so as to compel the acceleration of its passage through all its stages.

('59', 121, 3, 6, 212676) If you have not already read my statement 1 on the Government of India announcement sanctioning the introduction of the All India Bill and withholding it for the Madras Bill, I would ask you please now to read it, and then criticize it freely, and tell me how to go about it.

('59', 121, 3, 8, 213225) Here the circumstances are quite novel.

('59', 121, 4, 14, 213687) 175. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('59', 121, 5, 15, 213726) January 26; 1933
('59', 121, 6, 16, 213743) MY DEAR SATISBABOO,
('59', 121, 7, 17, 213763) I understand every word of what you have said in your letter of the 21st and you are going to do as the spirit leads you.
('59', 121, 7, 18, 213885) I must think aloud all the reactions that your letters produce upon me so that whenever they find an echo in your heart, you may re adjust yourself
('59', 121, 8, 19, 214033) 1 Vide “Statement on Viceroy’s Decision”, 24 1 1933
('59', 122, 0, 1, 214085) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 123
('59', 122, 1, 2, 214130) accordingly.
('59', 122, 1, 3, 214143) But there is to be no re adjustment if there is no such echo in your heart because in reading letters, even yours, hurriedly, I may miss a word here and a word there which may alter a conclusion equally hurriedly come to.
('59', 122, 1, 4, 214365) Thus, take this startling statement of yours—I mean startling for me—“As soon as I feel that I have been able to set up some arrangement for serving the Harijans on proper basis, I shall revert to my old field of activity.” This is what you would undoubtedly do as a chemist and mechanic, as you have done so successfully often.
('59', 122, 1, 5, 214694) But service of Harijans is no such mechanical thing to be arranged, put on a basis, and then left to workers.
('59', 122, 1, 6, 214804) It is a spiritual act, soul acting upon soul, and therefore there is no such mechanical replacement as we have in purely temporal activities.
('59', 122, 1, 7, 214946) There do come replacements even in spiritual activities, but those replacements are of a different character.
('59', 122, 1, 8, 215056) Even the Pratishthan work is a spiritual activity but can be arranged up to a point as a temporal activity; not so the Harijan work.

('59', 133, 2, 5, 234150) 191. LETTER TO V. JAGATHRAKSHAKAN
('59', 133, 3, 6, 234184) January 27, 1933
('59', 133, 4, 7, 234201) DEAR FRIEND, I think we have made a fetish of preservation of the purity of stock through unnatural restrictions.
('59', 133, 4, 8, 234315) The ancients never knew these restrictions.
('59', 133, 4, 9, 234359) This does not mean that I am an advocate of promiscuous unions.
('59', 133, 4, 10, 234423) I think that it is a wise rule to have marriage among people having common thought and common habits of life, but it is a vicious thing when it becomes so rigid as to make a departure from it a sinful act, especially in these days when the varnas have lost their purity, if not their original significance altogether.
('59', 133, 4, 11, 234741) The division between the superior and inferior people that you seem to believe in is, in my opinion, a monstrous perversion of truth.

('59', 134, 13, 19, 235989) 195. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 134, 14, 20, 236024) January 27, 1933
('59', 134, 15, 21, 236041) Mr. Gandhi said that he was surprised and pained to find that Mr. Iyengar, an
('59', 134, 16, 22, 236119) ex judge, had spoken “so irresponsibly” as he had done.
('59', 134, 16, 23, 236175) 1 If he had taken the trouble
('59', 134, 17, 24, 236205) of studying the movement, he would at once have seen that, with Mr. Gandhi, the
('59', 134, 18, 25, 236285) removal of untouchability was an article of faith before he knew anything of politics.
('59', 134, 19, 26, 236372) If he (Mr. Gandhi) had been guided by political, instead of religious instinct, he would
('59', 134, 20, 27, 236461) have excluded temple entry from the programme and confined his attention to
('59', 134, 21, 28, 236537) economic and educational uplift.
('59', 134, 21, 29, 236570) But he had staked his popularity, such as it was,
('59', 134, 22, 30, 236620) 1 Srinivasa Iyengar was reported to have said at a sanatanist meeting in Madras that the present temple entry movement was but a political stunt of Gandhiji and his followers to placate the Harijans and win them over to the Congress so as to present a united front.
('59', 135, 0, 1, 236886) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 135, 1, 2, 236928) because he believed that without temple entry untouchability could not be said to
('59', 135, 2, 3, 237010) have been abolished from Hinduism.
('59', 135, 2, 4, 237045) Mr. Gandhi added: I make an offer to Mr. Iyengar and other sanatanists who say that they do not wish to ill treat Harijans, and would like to promote their economic and other temporal welfare.
('59', 135, 2, 5, 237238) Let them join the Servants of Untouchables Society and finance and work its programme for temporal uplift and leave temple entry to me and those who think with me.
('59', 135, 2, 6, 237402) Mr. Iyengar should know that the Society contains few Congressmen.
('59', 135, 2, 7, 237469) The organization contains many prominent Liberals.
('59', 135, 2, 8, 237520) Indeed, sanatanists can, if they mean what they say, by bringing money and workers to the Society, take charge of it and shape its policy.
('59', 135, 2, 9, 237659) If this does not suit them, let them run a rival organization and spread its branches all over the country, and win the hearts and gratitude of Harijans.
('59', 135, 2, 10, 237813) I would take my chance of gaining religious merit by prosecuting the temple entry movement and showing that it will, at a stroke, uplift the Harijans and caste Hindus, and purify both and automatically promote the temporal welfare of the former.
('59', 135, 2, 11, 238059) Mr. Iyengar should realize that, in a matter concerning the masses, no stunt can be of much use.
('59', 135, 2, 12, 238156) They are open to be appealed to by everybody, and only honesty and hard work can win in the end.
('59', 135, 3, 13, 238253) As for the charge of religious interference, Gandhiji said: I have already dealt with the question in my previous statements.
('59', 135, 3, 14, 238379) I can only reiterate my view that I myself will be the first person to oppose religious interference by the State even when real power passes to the people.
('59', 135, 3, 15, 238536) But sanatanists cannot have it both ways.
('59', 135, 3, 16, 238578) They would want, as they have done before, the aid of law to sustain what, to one like me, appears to be prejudice or worse; and when I seek to remove that interference, the cry of interference is at once raised by the upholders of prejudice in the name of religion.
('59', 135, 3, 17, 238845) Indeed, I want to respect even prejudice, for I realize what may appear to me prejudice may be enlightenment to others.
('59', 135, 3, 18, 238965) But these are matters where the aid of the law cannot be sought.
('59', 135, 3, 19, 239030) The law can only take a temporal view of the questions that come before it.
('59', 135, 3, 20, 239106) It cannot recognize the Agamas 1
('59', 135, 4, 21, 239139) upholding thieving.
('59', 135, 4, 22, 239159) I have, at the Ashram, neighbours who honestly believe that thieving is an occupation enjoined by God to them as a caste.
('59', 135, 4, 23, 239281) I respect their prejudice, but the law does not.
('59', 135, 4, 24, 239330) I am here not giving a hypothetical case.
('59', 135, 4, 25, 239372) I am quoting from actual experience.
('59', 135, 5, 26, 239409) 1 Scriptures
('59', 136, 0, 1, 239422) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 137
('59', 136, 1, 2, 239467) Mr. Iyengar says that I do not believe in the Shastras.
('59', 136, 1, 3, 239523) He will fail to produce a single statement of mine to support his accusation.
('59', 136, 1, 4, 239601) Surely, he is too good a lawyer to claim infallibility for his interpre tation of the Shastras or his judgment of their authenticity.
('59', 136, 1, 5, 239735) I would ask him and those who are flinging all sorts of charges against me, distorting my writings in order to prove them, whether they will uphold sanatana dharma by such methods.
('59', 136, 1, 6, 239916) Let them believe me when I say that I am quite capable of saying so if I had the slightest desire to found a new religion or a new sect.
('59', 136, 1, 7, 240053) I have no other wish in this world, but to find light, joy and peace through Hinduism.
('59', 136, 1, 8, 240140) It is for that reason that I want to see it purified.
('59', 136, 1, 9, 240194) It satisfies me because, as I have understood and lived it, it has enabled me to treat other religions on a footing of absolute equality and their followers even as my blood brothers and sisters.
('59', 136, 1, 10, 240390) Hinduism and my conception of the Gita, of the Vedas, the Upanishads, the Bhagavata, and the Mahabharata, teach me that all life is one, and that in the eye of God there is no superior and no inferior.
('59', 136, 1, 11, 240592) I am sick of controversy.
('59', 136, 1, 12, 240618) But I am more sick of untruth and impurity.
('59', 136, 1, 13, 240662) I invite sanatanists to join hands with me in fighting them.
('59', 136, 2, 14, 240723) The Hindu, 28 1 1933, and The Bombay Chronicle, 28 1 1933

('59', 146, 6, 8, 254324) 214. LETTER TO A. RANGASWAMI IYENGAR
('59', 146, 7, 9, 254361) January 29, 1933
('59', 146, 8, 10, 254378) MY DEAR RANGASWAMI, I had a visit from Salivati yesterday.
('59', 146, 8, 11, 254437) Poor man, he is very much dejected.
('59', 146, 8, 12, 254473) He has really no defence.
('59', 146, 8, 13, 254499) The sub editor at your end made no mistakes at all in carrying out his message.
('59', 146, 8, 14, 254579) But in his own over zeal for the cause, Salivati drew upon his imagination.
('59', 146, 8, 15, 254655) He admits that many things he attributed to me I never said, but he simply inferred from a word here and a word there that had dropped out of my lips that I had meant what he said.
('59', 146, 8, 16, 254836) That of course was very dangerous, but he thought that he would serve the cause by allowing his imagination full play.
('59', 146, 8, 17, 254955) He admits also that I had warned him that he was not to make any use whatsoever of the conversation, but again he thought there was no harm, since the cause was good.
('59', 146, 8, 18, 255122) There was no mala fides behind his action.
('59', 146, 8, 19, 255165) I think and hope that this mistake will last him for the rest of his life.
('59', 146, 8, 20, 255240) Therefore, beyond warning him that he must act purely as a reporter and not at all as a protagonist of a cause, nothing further need be done.
('59', 146, 8, 21, 255382) When one sees so much of indifferent, incompetent and even unscrupulous reporting it would be a pity to punish a mistake, though serious, quite unintentional.
('59', 146, 9, 22, 255541) Yours sincerely, [PS.]
('59', 146, 10, 23, 255564) 1 Honorary Organizer and General Secretary of a society for the service of depressed classes

('59', 148, 1, 2, 256797) 217. LETTER TO M. M. ANANTA RAU
('59', 148, 2, 3, 256829) January 29, 1933
('59', 148, 3, 4, 256846) DEAR FRIEND, I have your last letter which is undated but which was received yesterday.
('59', 148, 3, 5, 256934) The first part of that letter is a complaint against unseemly behaviour of certain people at the meeting organized by the “followers of sanatana dharma”.
('59', 148, 3, 6, 257088) I was grieved to hear of the incident referred to by you.
('59', 148, 3, 7, 257146) I shall discuss it with Shri Rajagopalachariar who is expected here tomorrow.
('59', 148, 3, 8, 257224) It hurts me whenever there is any rowdyism or untruthfulness on either side.
('59', 148, 3, 9, 257301) Honest differences of opinion there will always be.
('59', 148, 3, 10, 257353) The cause of Truth cannot be served by hard swearing, stone throwing or untruthfulness.
('59', 148, 3, 11, 257441) The second part of your letter relieved the pain caused by the first part owing to the manner in which you approached my argument about untouchability.
('59', 148, 3, 12, 257593) As it so happened, I read your letter aloud amongst us, four prisoners, and I must confess to you that, as I proceeded, I could not help bursting into laughter, in which my companions heartily joined.
('59', 148, 3, 13, 257794) But behind the laughter was also a sadness that you, an agent of sanatana dharma, could not see that religion could not be treated in terms of algebra.
('59', 148, 3, 14, 257946) You have, instead of going straight to the core of my argument, launched out into an irrelevant discourse, ending in a ludicrous algebraical formula.
('59', 148, 3, 15, 258096) You will pardon me for writing straight from the heart.
('59', 148, 3, 16, 258152) Of all the letters that I have been receiving only yours and one or two others that I can mention have been courteous and have attempted to argue cogently.
('59', 148, 3, 17, 258308) I should only return your courtesy and your honest attempt to convince me by giving you an honest reply.
('59', 148, 3, 18, 258413) Let me tell you that all the letters and literature that have come to me have only confirmed me in the opinion that untouchability, as we are practising today, is a big blot upon Hinduism and an atrocious error in which we are still persisting, simply because of our laziness to understand and act up to the very fundamentals of Hinduism.
('59', 148, 3, 19, 258752) This inglorious persistence in error cuts me to the quick, but I am an optimist.
('59', 148, 3, 20, 258833) I have implicit faith in the ultimate victory of Truth.
('59', 148, 3, 21, 258889) I know therefore that untouchability will go and Hinduism will live a purified religion.
('59', 148, 3, 22, 258978) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 148, 3, 23, 259000) M. M. ANANTA ROW From a microfilm: S.N. 19263. Also C.W. 9573. Courtesy: Government of Mysore

('59', 150, 1, 2, 260184) 220. LETTER TO DHIRENDRANATH MUKHERJI
('59', 150, 2, 3, 260222) January 29, 1933
('59', 150, 3, 4, 260239) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('59', 150, 3, 5, 260281) So much untruth, almost bordering on the libellous, is being broadcast at the present moment about me that I should warn you not to believe anything against me unless you have it verified by me or you yourself have verified it from my authentic writings.
('59', 150, 3, 6, 260536) Thus, I have never declared to the world that “the hereditary caste system of the Hindu society is an artificial creation of some designing men”.
('59', 150, 3, 7, 260682) By hereditary system I suppose you mean varnashramadharma.
('59', 150, 3, 8, 260741) If so what I have said and written is that I believe in hereditary varnashramadharma which is one of the gifts that Hinduism has made to the world.
('59', 150, 3, 9, 260889) Again, what I have resisted and what I would resist with my life is untouchability as it is being practised today.
('59', 150, 3, 10, 261004) But I have never said that there is no such thing as untouchability.
('59', 150, 3, 11, 261073) On the contrary, I have said that untouchability of a kind is common to all mankind and all religions and that it is a necessary institution, and in that real sense all mankind become untouchable while they are performing certain functions of nature.
('59', 150, 3, 12, 261324) This is only one instance of natural necessary untouchability, but that carries no sin with it.
('59', 150, 3, 13, 261420) Again, interdining, intermarriage and the like are no part whatsoever of the campaign against untouchability as it is being practised today.
('59', 150, 3, 14, 261561) I have written in favour of interdining and even intermarriage under certain circumstances, but that is wholly irrelevant to the present discussion.
('59', 150, 3, 15, 261710) You can, if you desire to know my views on things not pertaining to untouchability, do so by studying my writings.
('59', 150, 3, 16, 261825) I hope this fully answers your letter.
('59', 150, 4, 17, 261864) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 150, 4, 18, 261886) DHIRENDRANATH MUKHERJI SENHATI P.O. KHULNA DIST.
('59', 150, 4, 19, 261935) (BENGAL)

('59', 159, 3, 21, 274996) 4. Don’t you think that you have made the hostel of the high school very expensive?
('59', 159, 3, 22, 275080) 5. What place have you given to the mother tongue in your scheme?
('59', 159, 3, 23, 275146) 6. Does the phrase “for high class Hindus” mean that the untouchable communities cannot take advantage of the high school?
('59', 159, 3, 24, 275269) I have heard of a case in which it was ruled that, if an institution was established for a particular class, there was no bar to the admission of other classes if they could be admitted without injury to the interests of the former and if that class did not raise any objection to these others being admitted.
('59', 159, 3, 25, 275579) I hope you are all right.

('59', 163, 4, 7, 280383) 246. LETTER TO BHAGWANDAS
('59', 163, 5, 8, 280409) January 31, 1933
('59', 163, 6, 9, 280426) DEAR BABOOJI, The shorter form is more affectionate than the longer.
('59', 163, 6, 10, 280495) way I use it as such.
('59', 163, 6, 11, 280517) I wish I could induce you to follow my rule—not to publish a newspaper unless it becomes self supporting.
('59', 163, 6, 12, 280623) If the public want a newspaper, they should pay for it, and when it does not pay for itself, it shows that it is not wanted.
('59', 163, 6, 13, 280748) For such a paper naturally there are no advertisements.
('59', 163, 6, 14, 280804) There is no padding.
('59', 163, 6, 15, 280825) It contains only that which the editor cannot help giving and the staff of such newspapers will also be chosen for its spirit of self sacrifice.
('59', 163, 6, 16, 280970) You at least may not be party to a paper that exists on charity.
('59', 163, 6, 17, 281035) Of course you will throw these ideas in the waste paper basket of your mind if you have any rigid notions about the conduct of newspapers and if these ideas find no echo in you.
('59', 163, 6, 18, 281213) I take it that as editor of the supplement you have every right to add your own comments to any of the opinions you may be publishing in the supplement.
('59', 163, 6, 19, 281366) I am now torturing my brain and heart to yield to me the right method of dealing with the situation that has arisen from the Viceregal decision.
('59', 163, 6, 20, 281511) My statement is but the prelude to the action that is developing.
('59', 163, 6, 21, 281577) The suggestion you make does not appear to me to be practical in the sense that the people require prolonged training for its adoption.
('59', 163, 6, 22, 281713) The vast mass of those who are today in the habit of attending temples fervently believe in darshan and its spiritual benefit.
('59', 163, 6, 23, 281840) They will not deny to themselves a spiritual benefit for the sake of
('59', 164, 0, 1, 281909) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 165
('59', 164, 1, 2, 281954) others who might be deprived of it and from their own standpoint they will be right.
('59', 164, 1, 3, 282039) If they could be persuaded to believe that there can be no spiritual benefit to be derived from a temple whose trustees perpetuate injustice, it would be a different thing.
('59', 164, 1, 4, 282212) That is the lesson we are trying to drive home, but we have not yet succeeded to the extent we would like to.
('59', 164, 1, 5, 282322) I never knew that Sri Prakasa was a stickler for the proper spelling of his name in the Roman character.
('59', 164, 1, 6, 282427) 1 His name in Devanagari can only be spelt in one way.
('59', 164, 1, 7, 282482) Rendered in a character with defective phonetics, it cannot be a matter of much consequence how it is spelt.
('59', 164, 1, 8, 282591) However I shall respect his weakness.
('59', 164, 1, 9, 282629) I had a letter some time ago from Shivaprasad which led me to think that he was making steady headway.
('59', 164, 1, 10, 282732) But your letter seems to point the other way.
('59', 164, 1, 11, 282778) I would therefore like you to give me an accurate account about him when Sri Prakasa returns.
('59', 164, 1, 12, 282872) Of course if you can get the permission for the publication of my opinion of your book, if I succeed in sending one, I should have no objection whatsoever.
('59', 164, 1, 13, 283028) Of course my private letters do find their way to the Press.
('59', 164, 1, 14, 283089) That’s no concern of mine.
('59', 164, 1, 15, 283116) What I have to guard against is sending of opinions on books for publication or messages to newspapers for publication apart from untouchability.
('59', 164, 2, 16, 283262) Yours sincerely,

('59', 167, 7, 16, 287564) 252. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO VICEROY
('59', 167, 8, 17, 287608) February 1, 1933
('59', 167, 9, 18, 287625) THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE VICEROY NEW DELHI
('59', 167, 10, 19, 287687) DEAR SIR, On the 30th December I sent you a telegram 1 for submission to His Excellency on the question of what is known as Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill regarding temple entry.
('59', 167, 10, 20, 287857) I have had no acknowledgement of it, formal or otherwise.
('59', 167, 10, 21, 287915) Nevertheless I deem it my duty to make my submission to His Excellency on the decision just announced regarding Sjt.
('59', 167, 10, 22, 288032) Ranga Iyer’s Bills.
('59', 167, 10, 23, 288052) Though I feel that it would have served the cause of humanity better, in point of time, if Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill had been allowed, I feel thankful that sanction has been granted for the introduction of Sjt.
('59', 167, 10, 24, 288259) Ranga Iyer’s Bills, one of which is drawn after Dr. Subbaroyan’s disallowed Bill.
('59', 167, 10, 25, 288341) My purpose in addressing this submission is to invite His Excellency’s attention to some considerations that warrant helpful
('59', 167, 11, 26, 288466) 1 Vide “Telegram to Private Secretary to Viceroy”, 3 12 1932
('59', 168, 0, 1, 288527) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 169
('59', 168, 1, 2, 288572) action by the Government of India regarding the consideration of the Bills by the Assembly at as early a date as is consistent with the importance of the object of the Bills.
('59', 168, 1, 3, 288747) Not knowing the procedure of the Assembly, I sought Sjt.
('59', 168, 1, 4, 288804) M.R. Jayakar’s assistance and guidance which he very kindly gave me yesterday.
('59', 168, 1, 5, 288883) He told me that the Government, if they wished, could make it possible to pass one at least of the Bills during the ensuing session of the Assembly.
('59', 168, 1, 6, 289032) If such is the case, I would urge that the Government are morally bound to give such assistance as may be necessary for the speedy consideration of the measures.
('59', 168, 1, 7, 289194) By the acceptance of the Yeravda Pact relating to the representation of the ‘depressed classes’, now commonly described as ‘Harijans’, in the legislatures, they bound themselves morally to facilitate as far as it lay in their power the observance by caste Hindus of all the other conditions of the Pact, which had reference to social and religious matters.
('59', 168, 1, 8, 289551) Inasmuch as His Majesty’s Government endorsed the legislative part of the Pact, they recognized the representative character of the Conference that passed the various resolutions.
('59', 168, 1, 9, 289731) One of them is as follows: 1
('59', 168, 2, 10, 289760) It is in due fulfilment of the pledge thus given to the Harijans that the Bills have been brought.
('59', 168, 2, 11, 289859) They are necessary inasmuch as the English Law of Trusts bars the progress of reform in the shape of opening temples to the Harijans.
('59', 168, 2, 12, 289993) I am advised that the decisions of British Courts hold it a breach of trust by a trustee who would open temples contrary to the usage prevailing at the time of his entering upon his trust.
('59', 168, 2, 13, 290182) Therefore it is not open either to the trustees or the congregations of the numerous Hindu temples even if they so wished to admit Harijans if usage shows, as it would show, that the general body of Hindu temples are not open to them on the same terms as to the caste Hindus.
('59', 168, 2, 14, 290458) But for decisions based on the English Law of Trusts it would be possible for Hindu pandits and the laity to vary the custom and introduce reforms.
('59', 168, 2, 15, 290606) The Bills are designed to remove this obstacle to progress and restore the condition that existed prior to the decisions referred to above.
('59', 168, 2, 16, 290746) His Excellency may not know that cases have already occurred in which Harijans have been fined for entering temples in good faith
('59', 168, 3, 17, 290876) 1 This is not reproduced here.
('59', 168, 3, 18, 290907) For the text of the Resolution, vide “Statement on Viceraoy’s Decision”, 24 1 933
('59', 169, 0, 1, 290989) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 169, 1, 2, 291031) and for the sole object of offering worship.
('59', 169, 1, 3, 291076) Hindu religious usage warrants no such punishment.
('59', 169, 1, 4, 291127) It enjoins purification of the idol and the temple and prescribes purification of caste Hindus in the shape of a bath, but no punishment of the offending worshipper.
('59', 169, 1, 5, 291293) Until therefore the Bills are passed or an equivalent is found by the Government, the vital part of the Hindu pledge cannot be performed.
('59', 169, 1, 6, 291431) For me, personally, holding my life as hostage for the due and timely fulfilment of the pledge, an indefinite prolongation of the impediment is an intolerable agony.
('59', 169, 1, 7, 291597) And as a prisoner I have, I feel, a right to seek Government’s active assistance.
('59', 169, 1, 8, 291679) I ask for no State interference in religious matters.
('59', 169, 1, 9, 291733) I am personally opposed to it.
('59', 169, 1, 10, 291764) In the present case what is sought is to remove the existing State interference.
('59', 169, 1, 11, 291845) I hesitate to point out how the Government can help the introduction and consideration of the Bills.
('59', 169, 1, 12, 291946) It would be presumption on my part to make any such attempt.
('59', 169, 1, 13, 292007) I hope however that I have shown sufficiently clearly that this is a case for the Government of India to facilitate the progress and passage of the Bills in every way legitimately open to them.
('59', 169, 1, 14, 292201) Though I have shown this to some friends, I am not sending it to the Press.
('59', 169, 2, 15, 292277) From a copy: C.W. 7925. Courtesy: G. D. Birla

('59', 174, 9, 13, 300274) 262. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('59', 174, 10, 14, 300298) After morning prayer, Thursday, February 2, 1933
('59', 174, 11, 15, 300347) MIRA, Though I have not received your weekly letter as usual, I must commune with you as I do every Thursday morning.
('59', 174, 11, 16, 300465) There is one pound increase in weight to report this week.
('59', 174, 11, 17, 300524) The saltless continues.
('59', 174, 11, 18, 300548) The articles have become stereotype: papaw, 20 dates, four oranges, two sour limes, four dessert spoonfuls honey, one lb.
('59', 174, 11, 19, 300670) goat’s milk, one dessert spoonful almond paste.
('59', 174, 11, 20, 300718) Honey I take twice with hot water and ten grains of soda bicarb each time and limes twice with cold water and soda bicarb.
('59', 174, 11, 21, 300841) Milk in the morning and almond paste evening.
('59', 174, 11, 22, 300887) There is a variation between the paste and _ lb.
('59', 174, 11, 23, 300936) This gives you an accurate idea of my food.
('59', 174, 11, 24, 300980) I began yesterday to take unboiled fresh milk.
('59', 174, 11, 25, 301027) They say that unboiled milk if fresh and clean is any day preferable to and more digestible than boiled milk.
('59', 174, 11, 26, 301137) I shall watch the effect of the experiment.

('59', 176, 1, 2, 303554) 264. LETTER TO U. GOPALA MENON
('59', 176, 2, 3, 303585) February 2, 1933
('59', 176, 3, 4, 303602) MY DEAR GOPALA MENON, I have your letter.
('59', 176, 3, 5, 303644) Satyagraha regarding Guruvayur in the old style is not to be thought of just now.
('59', 176, 3, 6, 303726) We must for the moment concentrate upon the passing of legislation and educating public opinion in favour of complete removal of untouchability and in getting those temples opened which are private properties or about which both the trustees and the public are agreed.
('59', 176, 3, 7, 303995) Therefore our programme should be threefold: Firstly, meetings all over the country urging the Government of India to provide all facilities in their power for the introduction and consideration of the two Bills and appealing to the members of the House generally not to obstruct the passage of the Bills, regarding them as measures demanded by the dictates of humanity and non interference with anybody’s private faith, and appealing to the Hindu members to vote solidly for the measures so as to leave Hindu conscience complete freedom of action regarding untouchability.
('59', 176, 3, 8, 304569) Secondly, you have to carry on house to house propaganda amongst caste Hindus and induce them to show in a concrete manner that they have ceased to believe in untouchability as it is practised today.
('59', 176, 3, 9, 304769) Thirdly, propaganda should be carried on amongst Harijans with reference to the observance of the laws of cleanliness and abstention from food and drink forbidden by Hinduism.
('59', 176, 3, 10, 304945) And all this work should be carried on by men of character who have a living faith in Hinduism.
('59', 176, 4, 11, 305041) Yours sincerely,
('59', 176, 5, 12, 305058) From a microfilm: S.N. 19289

('59', 178, 1, 2, 306787) 266. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 178, 2, 3, 306822) February 2, 1933
('59', 178, 3, 4, 306839) Interviewed by the Associated Press, Mahatma Gandhi expressed pleasure that
('59', 178, 4, 5, 306915) Mr. Ranga Iyer’s second Bill, which is virtually a copy of Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill, has
('59', 178, 5, 6, 307001) received the Viceregal sanction.
('59', 178, 5, 7, 307034) He continued: I can only hope that every facility will be offered for the imme diate consideration of these measures by the Assembly.
('59', 178, 5, 8, 307168) Though they are private Bills, they are measures of all India importance and, from a humanitarian standpoint, of world importance.
('59', 178, 5, 9, 307299) I hope that members of the Assembly have no difficulty in recognizing that the Bills constitute no interference with anybody’s religion, whatever is being said to the contrary in utter disregard of the facts.
('59', 178, 5, 10, 307508) The Bills are necessary, if the State is to observe the strictest religious neutrality.
('59', 178, 5, 11, 307596) Both the Bills are simply designed to remove impediments in the path of progress and do not coerce anybody or alter any religious custom or usage.
('59', 178, 6, 12, 307743) Replying to another question regarding the chances of the introduction of the Bills in the Assembly this session itself on which Mahatma Gandhi had been seeking information from prominent persons, he stated that he could say on authority of those who had been members of the Assembly, it was perfectly possible not only for the Bills to be introduced, but if members desired it, the Bills would become law.
('59', 178, 6, 13, 308150) It was quite possible for the Government and members at least to afford reasonable facilities for the introduction of the Bills this session.
('59', 178, 7, 14, 308292) Asked for his views on the suggestion that the Bills should be circulated for eliciting public opinion, Gandhiji said: I can only hope that no such procedure will be adopted, because the question underlying the measure is in no sense new and the Bills contain no complicated sections which may be difficult to understand.
('59', 178, 7, 15, 308614) Opinion of different individuals and groups of parties is also well known.
('59', 178, 7, 16, 308689) Therefore, circulation of the Bills means, to me, a mere dilatory procedure.
('59', 178, 8, 17, 308766) Asked if any definite programme has been chalked out as a result of his
('59', 178, 9, 18, 308838) conversation with Messrs Birla, Rajagopalachariar and others, Gandhiji said that
('59', 178, 10, 19, 308919) they had compared notes and tried to understand the implications in the Viceregal
('59', 178, 11, 20, 309001) sanction for the introduction of the Bills as all India measures.
('59', 178, 11, 21, 309067) They had debated on
('59', 178, 12, 22, 309087) the method to be adopted for consolidating public opinion and for demonstrating the
('59', 179, 0, 1, 309171) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 179, 1, 2, 309213) sincerity of the sanatanists.
('59', 179, 1, 3, 309243) There was no essential difference between them and
('59', 179, 2, 4, 309294) reformers, and the latter did not revolutionize religious customs or flout Shastras.
('59', 179, 3, 5, 309379) It was felt that the sanatanist agitation was largley due to the refusal of the sanatanists to appreciate the reformer’s point of view, and the suspicion that more lay at the bottom of the movement for the removal of untouchability than was stated in their programme.
('59', 179, 3, 6, 309647) It was, therefore, recognized that propaganda for enlightening the public should be continued and workers should be advised not to engage in vain debating but confine themselves to placing the issues in the clearest possible manner.
('59', 179, 3, 7, 309880) The Bombay Chronicle, 3 2 1933

('59', 179, 8, 14, 310158) QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
('59', 179, 9, 15, 310180) Q. The report of the Hide Cess Committee, vide copy enclosed, states that the
('59', 179, 10, 16, 310258) depressed classes and the peasantry would derive much benefit from the development of the tanning industry and incidentally refers to the existing appalling waste.
('59', 179, 10, 17, 310422) Can this statement be accepted entirely in respect of unslaughtered cattle hides?
('59', 179, 10, 18, 310504) If it can be, how should the development be brought about so as to yield maximum benefit to the depressed classes and to the peasantry?
('59', 179, 11, 19, 310640) A. It can.
('59', 179, 11, 20, 310651) The development can be brought about only by teaching the classes concerned simple but scientific methods fitted for individuals and villages of lifting carcasses at the places where the cattle die and of treating every part in an economic manner excluding the use of meat for food.
('59', 179, 12, 21, 310934) Q. Should tanning of unslaughtered hides be taken up in India to the exclusion of slaughtered hides or only as an industry mixed up with that of slaughtered hides as at the present stage?
('59', 179, 12, 22, 311122) Is it in any way derogatory for caste Hindus to take up this industry as a profession?
('59', 180, 0, 1, 311209) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 181
('59', 180, 1, 2, 311254) A. I should love to have tanning of the unslaughtered hides as a separate industry distinct from that of slaughtered hides.
('59', 180, 1, 3, 311378) In my opinion it is not derogatory or irreligious for caste Hindus to take up this industry.
('59', 180, 1, 4, 311471) It is essential for the purpose of cow protection that this industry be developed as an aid to cow protection and therefore on philanthropic lines.
('59', 180, 2, 5, 311619) Q. Would not the tanning of unslaughtered cattle hides on a large scale by modern scientific methods be helpful to the following?
('59', 180, 2, 6, 311749) (a) Economic uplift of Harijan brethren and an immediate item of programme of work for the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 180, 2, 7, 311874) (b) Improvement of the living wealth of the country.
('59', 180, 2, 8, 311927) (c) The creation of a new field of activity for the educated unemployed.
('59', 180, 2, 9, 312000) (d) Protection of cows.
('59', 180, 3, 10, 312024) A. I have my doubts.
('59', 180, 3, 11, 312045) Home or village tanning is necessary.
('59', 180, 4, 12, 312083) Q. The unslaughtered cattle hides can be tanned to near perfection of the slaughtered ones.
('59', 180, 4, 13, 312175) Is your information to the contrary?
('59', 180, 5, 14, 312212) A. I believe that this is only partly true, if the carcass is taken up immediately after death and removed so as not to damage the hide.
('59', 180, 6, 15, 312349) Q. In the manufacture of leather goods, particularly shoes, difficulty is being experienced in providing lining which is to be thin and delicate.
('59', 180, 6, 16, 312495) Such a leather is only available from the skins of live sheep and goat.
('59', 180, 6, 17, 312567) Since Hindu India in a fair number is a flesh eater would it go against the principles of the industry of unslaughtered hides to utilize the skins for lining and other purposes of such sheep and goats as are unavoidably killed for food?
('59', 180, 7, 18, 312804) A. Much as I should like to answer otherwise, I believe that for the majority of Hindus the use of the skins of goats and sheep slaughtered for food will not offend their religious sense.
('59', 180, 8, 19, 312992) Q. In the event of the Agra Tannery at Agra restricting its activities to the tanning of unslaughtered hides exclusively, may the Tannery expect your blessings and distinguished patronage?
('59', 180, 9, 20, 313181) A. Any tannery restricting its activities as suggested would certainly receive my blessings if it is run on the lines suggested by me, but whoever does so should realize that in the initial stages he might have to lose.
('59', 180, 9, 21, 313401) I can say nothing of distinguished patronage.
('59', 180, 10, 22, 313447) From a microfilm: S. N. 19291

('59', 181, 8, 11, 314090) February 3, 1933
('59', 181, 9, 12, 314107) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('59', 181, 9, 13, 314162) 1 In every case where there has been resistance offered by prostration, whether in front of a temple or elsewhere, I have condemned it as being contrary to the rule of satyagraha.
('59', 181, 9, 14, 314342) For, satyagraha requires suffering in one’s own person, not offering physical resistance to another which prostration undoubt edly does.
('59', 181, 9, 15, 314479) Being the author of satyagraha I have endeavoured to lay down certain rules for the guidance of those who recognize my autho rity, but as I claim no monopoly of the knowledge of the doctrine of satyagraha, it is open to anyone to give what meaning he likes to satyagraha and lay down rules also according to his liking.
('59', 181, 9, 16, 314799) My letter to the President of the League in Ellore has only a limited application.
('59', 181, 9, 17, 314882) The word ‘dodge’ is to be taken in its dictionary meaning.
('59', 181, 9, 18, 314941) I never knew it to bear the meaning of tramping over any person.
('59', 181, 9, 19, 315006) Once Pandit Malaviyaji ‘dodged’ to the amusement of the public and to the discomfiture of the so called satyagrahi students
('59', 181, 10, 20, 315130) 1 The addressee had asked why it could not be called a satyagraha and could be “dodged” if four or five orthodox Brahmins prostrated themselves in front of a temple and peacefully resisted any attempt to allow untouchables in the temple.
('59', 182, 0, 1, 315368) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 183
('59', 182, 1, 2, 315413) prostrating in front of his college by erecting a bridge over them and making a safe passage for the fellow students who wanted to exercise the right of attending the college.
('59', 182, 1, 3, 315589) Not one of the prostrating brotherhood was in any shape or form injured or molested, and, if my recollection serves me right, the prostrating ones admired Malaviyaji’s non violent resourcefulness.
('59', 182, 1, 4, 315786) But that was only one way of dodging.
('59', 182, 1, 5, 315824) The dictionary says you can make a dodge behind, around, under, between or into what will hide one.
('59', 182, 1, 6, 315924) But you will recognize that all these dodgings exclude violence.
('59', 182, 2, 7, 315989) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('59', 189, 7, 11, 326871) 282. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH
('59', 189, 8, 12, 326905) February 4, 1933
('59', 189, 9, 13, 326922) CHI NARAHARI, I got your letter.
('59', 189, 9, 14, 326955) It is a good sign that we are able to see our own weaknesses.
('59', 189, 9, 15, 327017) Even if people call us simpletons or impractical fools, we will not violate truth in word or deed.
('59', 189, 9, 16, 327116) Your experience that it is difficult to live in that manner in a place like that is that of others too, but one may be said to follow dharma only if one does so even in the face of difficulties.
('59', 189, 9, 17, 327311) He is not the best captain who steers a ship in a calm sea; it is the one who does not let a ship sink even in stormy waters.
('59', 189, 9, 18, 327437) But we should not feel unhappy about the past.
('59', 189, 9, 19, 327484) We have learnt the necessary lesson from it.
('59', 189, 9, 20, 327529) In future let God decide what work you should take up and what you should not.
('59', 189, 9, 21, 327608) All that we should do is to resolve to cling to truth in whatever circumstances we may be placed.
('59', 189, 9, 22, 327706) We should have faith that God does not test beyond their strength those who trust Him.
('59', 189, 9, 23, 327793) The pity is that we do not trust Him.
('59', 189, 9, 24, 327831) If we do, why should we feel concerned whether we shall lose our good name by clinging to truth, or harm the cause or displease a co worker?
('59', 189, 9, 25, 327972) God is there to concern Himself with all these problems.
('59', 189, 9, 26, 328029) But my purpose in saying all this is only to advise you not to
('59', 190, 0, 1, 328092) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 191
('59', 190, 1, 2, 328137) bemoan the past.
('59', 190, 1, 3, 328154) Give me a description of Kuvalayananda’s Ashram.
('59', 190, 1, 4, 328203) Who are the teachers there?
('59', 190, 1, 5, 328231) What things do they teach?
('59', 190, 1, 6, 328258) What fee do they charge?
('59', 190, 1, 7, 328283) Manibehn and you should learn this lesson from what has happened, that a mother should know how to take care of the children’s teeth.
('59', 190, 1, 8, 328417) Their food should not be very soft and should not contain too much starch.
('59', 190, 1, 9, 328492) They should have sugar and jaggery in very small quantity only.
('59', 190, 1, 10, 328556) Instead, they may be allowed to suck juice from lots of sugarcane in the season.
('59', 190, 1, 11, 328637) When the season is over, the children may be given fruits containing sugar, like figs, munakka, dates, etc.
('59', 190, 1, 12, 328745) Moreover, the mother should stand by the side of the children when they brush their teeth in the morning and teach them to clean the teeth with the babool stick vigorously, and also see that they use a mixture of powdered coal and salt which has been properly sifted.
('59', 190, 1, 13, 329013) They should be taught to gargle properly after every meal and to massage the teeth and the gums with their fingers.
('59', 190, 1, 14, 329129) The truth is that most of us are scarcely fit to be parents.
('59', 190, 1, 15, 329190) Why should those who have not learnt the science of child care bring children into the world?
('59', 190, 1, 16, 329284) This question led some to the discovery of brahmacharya and some others to the discovery of artificial birth control.
('59', 190, 1, 17, 329402) The second is a dangerous and perilous way.
('59', 190, 1, 18, 329446) The middle course, that of lethargy and indifference, is still more dangerous and perilous.
('59', 190, 1, 19, 329538) While teaching Mani how to take care of the children’s teeth, teach her the whole science of child care.
('59', 190, 1, 20, 329643) She should also learn to observe the stools and the urine of the children.
('59', 190, 1, 21, 329718) She should examine them from time to time.
('59', 190, 1, 22, 329761) She should also examine their eyes, ears and nails, their habits of breathing and their tongues, and watch how they speak and what they do during the whole day.
('59', 190, 1, 23, 329922) All these things become very easy to do once the mother has formed the habit of doing them.
('59', 190, 1, 24, 330014) Tell Gomati that she may come whenever she wishes.

('59', 192, 1, 2, 331215) 284. STATEMENT ON “HARIJAN”
('59', 192, 2, 3, 331243) [Before February 5, 1933] 1
('59', 192, 3, 4, 331271) The first number of the English edition of Harijan 2 to be published under the auspices of the Servants of Untouchables Society will be published on Saturday the 11th instant.
('59', 192, 3, 5, 331447) It will be printed at the Arya Bhushan Press.
('59', 192, 3, 6, 331493) Mr. A.N. Patwardhan, of the Servants of India Society, is the declared Printer and Publisher.
('59', 192, 3, 7, 331587) Mr. R. V. Shastri, B.A., B.L., is the Editor.
('59', 192, 3, 8, 331633) Only recently the latter left a lucrative post in partnership in Calcutta, and gave his services on a mere living wage to Mr. A. V. Thakkar, Secretary of the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 192, 3, 9, 331825) When it was decided that this English edition is to be published in Poona, I asked Mr. Thakkar whether he could spare Mr. Shastri for the editorial work, and whether the latter would undertake the responsibility.
('59', 192, 3, 10, 332038) Both promptly responded.
('59', 192, 3, 11, 332063) I hope to contribute my full share so far as it is possible for me, to the contents of the paper.
('59', 192, 3, 12, 332161) I hope the paper will have a very large patronage.
('59', 192, 3, 13, 332212) It is desired to make the paper completely self supporting.
('59', 192, 3, 14, 332272) The annual subscription, inland, will be Rs. 4 including postage and Rs. 3 without, while the foreign subscription will be Rs. 5 8. A single copy will be priced one anna.
('59', 192, 3, 15, 332443) Intending subscribers will please send their names to Mr. Patwardhan, with subscription charges in money or stamps.
('59', 192, 4, 16, 332559) The Hindu, 6 2 1933
('59', 192, 5, 17, 332579) 1 Vide “Letter to V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 5 2 1933.
('59', 192, 6, 18, 332632) 2 After Gandhiji’s arrest in January 1932, Young India was discontinued, its last issue being that of January 14, 1932. As the movement against untouchability grew stronger, Gandhiji decided to bring out another journal, Harijan, to propagate his views.
('59', 192, 6, 19, 332886) The first issue of Harijan appeared from Poona on Fabruary 11 , 1933 under the editorship of R. V. Shastri.
('59', 192, 6, 20, 332994) On April 13, 1935, Mahadev Desai became its editor.
('59', 192, 6, 21, 333046) In 1940, during the Individual Civil Disobedience movement, it was suspended.
('59', 192, 6, 22, 333124) However from January 18, 1942 it again began to make its appearance from the Navajivan Press, Ahmedabad, till the press was raided on August 21, 1942 and the journal banned.
('59', 192, 6, 23, 333298) After the removal of the ban by the Government on January 10, 1946, the journal was revived on February 10, 1946, under the editorship of Pyarelal who continued to work in that capacity up to February 22, 1948. Subsequently, it was edited by Kishorelal G. Mashruwala and lastly by Maganbhai P. Desai till the journal stopped publication in March 1956.

('59', 193, 5, 6, 333884) 286. LETTER TO E. E. DOYLE
('59', 193, 6, 7, 333911) February 5, 1933
('59', 193, 7, 8, 333928) DEAR COL.
('59', 193, 7, 9, 333938) DOYLE, Major Bhandari has just shown me the Bombay Government’s order in connection with my cable 1 to Mr. Andrews.
('59', 193, 7, 10, 334054) As it was rather important that it should go at once I have asked Major Bhandari kindly to withdraw an amount from my private account which as a matter of fact is not my own property.
('59', 193, 7, 11, 334238) I am hoping for a revision of the Government’s order and thus to reimburse my private account.
('59', 193, 7, 12, 334333) My reason for asking for a revision is this.
('59', 193, 7, 13, 334378) But for the very heavy bill that was paid to the dental surgeon my account would show a good balance.
('59', 193, 7, 14, 334480) You will recall that the dental surgeon was called in at your suggestion and not mine; also that when you suggested that I should obtain a new plate I asked for Dr. Desai, a dentist friend, to be called in, and that I also told you in my letter of the 28th June, 1932 that I had suggested his name as “I had no desire to land the Government in the expense of a new set of teeth”, and I knew that “Dr. Desai would not want to make any charge for the plates he might make for me.” You will thus see that I could have had the plate without any charge and at that time I had never suspected that the dental charges if they had to be paid would be paid out of monthly allowance.
('59', 193, 7, 15, 335154) As you are aware, from month to month I was saving as much out of the hundred rupees as possible.
('59', 193, 7, 16, 335252) But you chose to call in a dental surgeon of your own selection.
('59', 193, 7, 17, 335317) I could have no objection and when the bill was shown to me by Major Bhandari and when he told me that the money had to be paid out of my allowance, though I demurred I did not wish to raise any objection because I did not think then that I would want to draw upon the balance that was then outstanding in my
('59', 193, 8, 18, 335626) 1 Vide “Draft Acable to C. F. Andrews”, 2 2 1933
('59', 194, 0, 1, 335675) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 195
('59', 194, 1, 2, 335720) favour.
('59', 194, 1, 3, 335728) But in the new circumstances that have arisen, I must ask for the dental charges being removed from my account and if that be done there wouldbe at once a balance in my favour.
('59', 194, 1, 4, 335905) I would further suggest that Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel’s and my accounts be amalgamated.
('59', 194, 1, 5, 335993) There is a balance in his favour still left.
('59', 194, 1, 6, 336038) If therefore these two accounts are amalgamated there would be a surplus left.
('59', 194, 1, 7, 336117) I have consulted the Sardar and he is quite willing that our accounts should be amalgamated.
('59', 194, 1, 8, 336210) In fact both of us have often suggested the adoption of this course to Major Bhandari.
('59', 194, 1, 9, 336297) May I ask you please to secure an early decision on this point as telegrams have to be frequently sent by me especially at this moment.
('59', 194, 2, 10, 336433) Yours sincerely,
('59', 194, 3, 11, 336450) M. K. GANDHI

('59', 194, 5, 13, 336520) 287. LETTER TO BILL LASH
('59', 194, 6, 14, 336545) February 5, 1933
('59', 194, 7, 15, 336562) DEAR FATHER LASH, You do confound a poor man like me.
('59', 194, 7, 16, 336616) Who is father, and who is brother, and when, and also perhaps why?
('59', 194, 7, 17, 336683) But that is neither here nor there.
('59', 194, 7, 18, 336719) It is a fine thing to find you in Sabarmati.
('59', 194, 7, 19, 336764) I hope you will feel as much at home there as at the C.S.S.A., and it is good too that you are there when Mary Barr is there.
('59', 194, 7, 20, 336890) I take a promise from every stranger that visits the Sabarmati Ashram that he should give me his criticism of the Ashram and especially tell me frankly all about the defects he might have noticed in it.
('59', 194, 7, 21, 337093) You have to make the promise, please.
('59', 194, 7, 22, 337131) Now, for your difficulty.
('59', 194, 7, 23, 337157) It is not necessarily wrong “to be compelled to act against one’s reasoning and instinct through fear of hurting someone whom we love”, provided of course that the thing we do is in itself not only not wrong but morally worth doing.
('59', 194, 7, 24, 337390) You will notice that I have copied your own wording.
('59', 194, 7, 25, 337443) Conversely, to be compelled even through love to do a thing that is wrong is undoubte dly wrong.
('59', 194, 7, 26, 337540) But then that love itself is wrong.
('59', 194, 7, 27, 337576) It is good for me to love you and be loved by you.
('59', 194, 7, 28, 337627) But it is immoral for me to do wrong for the sake of love.
('59', 194, 7, 29, 337686) If there is any likelihood of that happening, we have
('59', 195, 0, 1, 337740) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 195, 1, 2, 337782) to shun each other’s company.
('59', 195, 1, 3, 337812) Having stated these two propositions, let me cite the world’s experience in proof.
('59', 195, 1, 4, 337895) Whether it is right or wrong, it is a fact that in innumerable cases men and women are good, not for the sake of good, but for the sake of love which they owe to others or which they receive from them.
('59', 195, 1, 5, 338097) In an equal number of cases such love keeps us from falling.
('59', 195, 1, 6, 338158) Perhaps you will easily admit that Jesus Christ was and still remains one of the greatest among moral coercers of the world.
('59', 195, 1, 7, 338283) He continually coerces you, a very weak man otherwise, to do the right thing though your weak flesh would have you to do the wrong thing, and the strange thing is that you sing hymns of praise to Him for holding you tight in His chains.
('59', 195, 1, 8, 338520) You do not mind some people laughing at you for your helplessness and weakness.
('59', 195, 1, 9, 338600) Do not retort by way of answer: “But Jesus was Christ and God Incarnate.” I have given you the most telling illustration to show what is happening in everyday life.
('59', 195, 1, 10, 338765) Some have God to rely upon; others, poor mortals, have their parents; and yet others, like me, have their wives, sons and friends to lean on.
('59', 195, 1, 11, 338907) I had, not very many years ago, all but fallen, but the thought of Devdas, who was then living with me, of Mahadev, Mathuradas and others who were at that time surrounding me and whom I believed to be themselves leaning on me, and the thought of my wife, kept me from going to perdition.
('59', 195, 1, 12, 339195) It was their love which chained me so tightly and strongly that I could not burst through the bond although the flesh was pulling hard enough to tear the chains to bits and rush into hell fire.
('59', 195, 1, 13, 339389) That is the type of coercion and no other which my love, expr essed through my fast, was intended to exercise, the common thing in all these illustrations being the doing of a right act.
('59', 195, 1, 14, 339576) There is nothing wrong in people doing the right thing under the pressure of love and later doing the same thing for the sake of it.
('59', 195, 1, 15, 339709) I hope I have made my point clear, even though I might not have carried convition.
('59', 195, 1, 16, 339792) You must pardon me when I contradict you by saying that God’s shoulders are broad enough to bear the responsibility even of anything that is wrong.
('59', 195, 1, 17, 339940) In Christian parlance, does He not bear easily the humanly intolerable burden of the world’s sins?
('59', 195, 1, 18, 340039) This contra diction is unnecessary for our purpose, but I thought I would draw your attention to what I think is a clear slip.
('59', 195, 1, 19, 340166) My fast was certainly right so long as I hold the belief truthfully that it was prompted by God.
('59', 195, 1, 20, 340263) But even under God’s shelter I cannot claim immunity from a
('59', 196, 0, 1, 340323) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 197
('59', 196, 1, 2, 340368) fast which may be designed to compass unknowingly an immoral thing.
('59', 196, 1, 3, 340436) Therefore, the motive behind must be right, the end in front must be equally right, and the act itself propelled by the motive should also be right.
('59', 196, 1, 4, 340585) Hence in this chain the intermediate act, if it is violent, would vitiate both the motive and the end.
('59', 196, 1, 5, 340688) Hence the necessity for unadultered ahimsa—non violence in thought, word and deed.
('59', 196, 1, 6, 340771) And since the Gita says “Man can really only control his acts” 1, if they are right he may safely leave the rest to God, and whether he willingly and wittingly does so or not, God alone controls the rest.
('59', 196, 1, 7, 340976) I do hope that your foot is quite all right now.
('59', 196, 1, 8, 341025) If it is not, I would not now ask you to try the earth cure, but ask Narandas to send you to a doctor or fetch a doctor for you.
('59', 196, 1, 9, 341154) It is no use playing with even a small mischief.
('59', 196, 1, 10, 341203) With love from us,
('59', 196, 2, 11, 341222) Yours sincerely,
('59', 196, 4, 12, 341239) From a photostat: G.N. 40

('59', 200, 6, 18, 347759) You can serve in many ways while staying in Bombay While the treatment of the teeth is going on, you should live in the open air and daily go for as long walks—up to fifteen miles—as your body can endure without fatigue.
('59', 200, 6, 19, 347980) I am sure you go to bed early and rise early.
('59', 200, 6, 20, 348026) The morning hours should always be spent in taking walks.
('59', 200, 6, 21, 348084) In food, it is necessary to exclude all starches for the present.
