('59', 201, 6, 12, 349294) BHAI BALWANTSINH, I have your letter.
('59', 201, 6, 13, 349332) The guru must possess the virtues of a sthitaprajna 2. I have not come across such an embodiment of perfection.
('59', 201, 6, 14, 349444) But I have found a few people in all countries who possess varying degrees of these virtues.
('59', 201, 6, 15, 349537) 2. To remain equally unmoved by happiness and unhappiness, honour and dishonour means that one should not be hurt by insults nor feel elated by honours.
('59', 201, 6, 16, 349690) But in no way does it follow that one should not reply to the insult or end the sorrow.
('59', 201, 6, 17, 349778) 3. The virtues of a devotee can be acquired by effort and the direction of effort has been indicated in the chapter 3 on bhakti.
('59', 201, 6, 18, 349907) But there is nothing to hinder one from acquiring the virtues in a different way if it be possible.
('59', 201, 6, 19, 350007) 4. Sleep can become sounder by practice.
('59', 201, 6, 20, 350048) On waking from sound sleep there is awareness of nothing except sleep and a sense of well being.
('59', 201, 6, 21, 350145) Even when the Gita, etc., are recited many thoughts rise unawares in the mind.
('59', 201, 6, 22, 350224) Sound sleep is possible when the soul is in rapport with the Gita or, in other words, with God.
('59', 201, 6, 23, 350320) Therefore we should faithfully continue the present effort of filling ourselves with the Gita.
('59', 201, 7, 24, 350415) 1 The letter carries the following note in English evidently for the jail authorities: ‘‘This contains only answers to religious questions.

('59', 202, 1, 3, 350764) Anyway there is no longer much need of it.
('59', 202, 1, 4, 350807) One who studies Anasaktiyoga 1 well can easily get at the secret of the Ramayana.
('59', 202, 1, 5, 350889) 6. The history contained in the Ramayana is only secondary.
('59', 202, 1, 6, 350949) Spiritual philosophy is the main thing.
('59', 202, 1, 7, 350989) Dharma has been revealed through the unfolding of events.
('59', 202, 1, 8, 351047) Hence while studying the Ramayana, you must regard Rama as the Supreme Being and Ravana as the forces opposed to Him.

('59', 203, 4, 5, 352885) February 6, 1933
('59', 203, 5, 6, 352902) THE SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY HOME DEPARTMENT
('59', 203, 6, 7, 352960) DEAR SIR, I enclose herewith letter from Shrimati Mirabai (Slade) dated 28th ultimo and handed to me only this day.
('59', 203, 6, 8, 353076) It speaks for itself.
('59', 203, 6, 9, 353098) Being in answer to an anxious enquiry from me, the letter might have been given to me earlier.
('59', 203, 6, 10, 353193) Since this letter was written the usual weekly letter was received in which she stated that she was examined by the Civil Surgeon who had recommended her for transfer.
('59', 203, 6, 11, 353361) Miss Slade had repeatedly complained to me in her weekly letters about the stenches and the stifling atmosphere of Arthur Road Prison and recurring attacks of headache, giddiness, eruptions and the like.
('59', 203, 6, 12, 353565) But I felt, as she had felt, that as a prisoner she must suffer the hardships of prison life.
('59', 203, 6, 13, 353659) It might however be held pardonable, if not even right, in cases causing anxiety about health, for prisoners to bring to the knowledge of superior authority the condition of their health.
('59', 203, 6, 14, 353847) Acting in accordance with that rule I have approached Government before now, wherever I have felt the necessity of bringing to their notice cases of prisoners in whose welfare I have been interested as if they were my own nearest relatives.
('59', 203, 6, 15, 354088) The letter enclosed gives a true picture of Miss Slade’s health, and her attachment towards me.
('59', 203, 6, 16, 354184) It has been a privilege to me to enjoy that affection.
('59', 203, 6, 17, 354239) She came to me with the fullest consent of her late mother and the reluctant consent of her father the late Sir Edmond Slade who never cut off the annuity that he used to give to her.
('59', 203, 6, 18, 354423) I hardly need to say anything more about her family connections which are better known to Government than to me.
('59', 203, 6, 19, 354536) You will notice the dread she has of being sent away to a place further away from me.
('59', 203, 6, 20, 354622) I wish she was less sensitive, but her sensitiveness has to be taken into account as it so quickly affects her body.
('59', 203, 6, 21, 354739) I therefore suggest her transfer to the Female Yard attached to
('59', 204, 0, 1, 354803) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 205
('59', 204, 1, 2, 354848) this Prison.
('59', 204, 1, 3, 354861) From all the accounts that I have heard of the Yard, it is airy, roomy and much cooler than Arthur Road Prison.
('59', 204, 1, 4, 354973) She will certainly be happier there.
('59', 204, 1, 5, 355010) I suggest too that she be examined by specialists in view of what she says about her glands and the condition of her tonsils.
('59', 204, 1, 6, 355136) I would gladly name my doctors if Government would entertain their names, but I have no desire to press the point.
('59', 204, 1, 7, 355251) I should be entirely satisfied so long as she is examined by specialists.
('59', 204, 1, 8, 355325) It grieves me to have to approach the Government over a delicate and personal matter.
('59', 204, 1, 9, 355411) But I entertain the hope that perhaps the Government may even appreciate the fact that I have brought this matter to their notice.
('59', 204, 1, 10, 355542) I shall be thankful for an early decision.
('59', 204, 2, 11, 355585) I remain,
('59', 204, 3, 12, 355595) Yours truly,
('59', 204, 4, 13, 355608) M. K. GANDHI

('59', 210, 8, 13, 366807) You can surely find the correct meaning.

('59', 210, 8, 15, 366945) You can read many meanings out of sentences detached from their context.

('59', 210, 10, 17, 367097) answer more pointed questions in this connection, saying: You are treading on slippery ground.

('59', 211, 0, 1, 367784) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 211, 1, 2, 367826) 307. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 211, 2, 3, 367861) February 7, 1933
('59', 211, 3, 4, 367878) Commenting on the letter of Jagadguru Shankaracharya of Puri to Mr. Ranga Iyer and the latter’s reply thereto, Gandhiji said in an interview to the Associated Press: I am really sorry that the Jagadguru should have written that letter about the Bills.
('59', 211, 3, 5, 368130) I venture to think that the Bills do not, in any shape or form, interfere with religious liberty.
('59', 211, 3, 6, 368228) On the contrary, both the Bills jealously guard it.
('59', 211, 3, 7, 368280) Nor is the analogy used by the Jagadguru correct.
('59', 211, 3, 8, 368330) There is no technical question involved in the Bills requiring technical knowledge.
('59', 211, 3, 9, 368414) It is always open to worshippers to determine what company they would take with them for prayer.
('59', 211, 3, 10, 368511) You may call that even a change of religion if you like.
('59', 211, 3, 11, 368568) But you cannot deprive the people of that right.
('59', 211, 3, 12, 368617) What is there to prevent cent per cent of the worshippers in a temple admitting whomsoever they choose, even though such admission may be against the Agama governing that particular temple?
('59', 211, 3, 13, 368807) There is no religious interference involved in restoring to the people a right that should never have been taken away from them.
('59', 211, 3, 14, 368936) And if it is admitted that cent per cent of the worshippers can, if they choose, alter the rules of admission into a temple, then it should easily be conceded that a sufficient majority should have the right of determining the question of admission so long as they do not interfere with the liberty of the minority to perform worship in isolation from the majority.
('59', 211, 3, 15, 369302) Surely, it is a serious thing for a responsible person like the Jagadguru to label reformers, who claim to be followers of the same faith and believe in the same Shastras, as renegades from sanatana dharma.
('59', 211, 3, 16, 369509) It also passes my comprehension how the passage of the Bills can be considered an unconstitutional procedure.
('59', 211, 3, 17, 369619) If the Jagadguru’s letter is thus open to objection, I am afraid Mr. Ranga Iyer’s reply also needs some corrections.
('59', 211, 3, 18, 369736) I am not so sure as he is, that Malabar Hindu opinion is against the Bill, and so against the temple entry of Harijans.
('59', 211, 3, 19, 369856) The results of the Guruvayur referendum may be regarded as an indication to the contrary.
('59', 211, 3, 20, 369946) Eyewitnesses who have been in Malabar have also told me that popular opinion is by no means against temple entry.
('59', 211, 3, 21, 370060) But that is a
('59', 212, 0, 1, 370074) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 213
('59', 212, 1, 2, 370119) matter which can be determined anywhere if both the parties agree to have an unofficial referendum under joint supervision.
('59', 212, 1, 3, 370243) Then, Mr. Ranga Iyer, in his enthusiasm and blind affection for me, has been betrayed into an unfortunate analogy.
('59', 212, 1, 4, 370358) I do not consider myself in any way fit to be compared with the Buddha.
('59', 212, 1, 5, 370430) I regard myself as a very common man—a poor worker, liable to all the errors mankind is prone to make.
('59', 212, 1, 6, 370533) I am merely a humble truth seeker.
('59', 212, 1, 7, 370568) But the analogy is unfortunate for another reason also.
('59', 212, 1, 8, 370624) Sanatanists would say that the Buddha was an atheist, and that he did not accept the authority of the Vedas and did not believe in their divinity—not that as a matter of fact he was an atheist or did not believe in the Vedas.
('59', 212, 1, 9, 370850) But, what he really was, is not pertinent to our point.
('59', 212, 1, 10, 370906) Therefore, if I am also considered an atheist or non believer in the divinity of the Vedas, I am certainly out of court, as a reformer asking Hindus to reject modern untouchability as being wholly against Hindu Shastras regarded as a whole.
('59', 212, 2, 11, 371147) The Hindu, 8 2 1933

('59', 215, 0, 1, 375025) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 215, 1, 2, 375067) I look at today’s, I marvel at the betterment in the condition.
('59', 215, 1, 3, 375131) And yet to prisoners who find themselves in for conscience’s sake, thereshould be no difference whatsoever between that life and this.
('59', 215, 1, 4, 375266) They must be prepared cheerfully to submit to the life of Howard’s days.
('59', 215, 1, 5, 375339) For to them conscience is dearer than the ease of body and the pleasure of communion through physical means with the nearest and dearest ones.
('59', 215, 1, 6, 375482) There should be therefore on the one hand every honest and permissible attempt to keep the body in good condition and to obtain the other amenities, on the other to receive disappointment with perfect detachment.
('59', 215, 1, 7, 375695) You should continue to report the whole of your condition to the Civil Surgeon and give him the history of your previous glands.

('59', 215, 1, 10, 375948) ‘Not a blade moves but by His will.’
('59', 215, 2, 11, 375985) The passage you quote from the Gita refers to moderate habits.
('59', 215, 2, 12, 376048) That is not what I had in mind.
('59', 215, 2, 13, 376080) The passage I had in mind occurs in the last chapter, 52nd verse.
('59', 215, 2, 14, 376146) I should translate it thus.
('59', 215, 2, 15, 376174) “Who prefers solitude, who eats meagre food, who has under perfect control thought, speech and action, who is intent on meditation, who is free always from attachments.”
('59', 215, 3, 16, 376344) You have no reason to complain of the quantity of your food.
('59', 215, 3, 17, 376405) You dare not go by the abstract measurement.
('59', 215, 3, 18, 376450) Double your quantity would be really meagre for many of our friends.
('59', 215, 3, 19, 376519) The condition of your own body should be the sole guide as to the quantity without reference to that taken by others.
('59', 215, 3, 20, 376637) All we should recognize is that voluntary meagre eating is one of the most difficult things in the world.
('59', 215, 3, 21, 376743) It is a perpetual fast much more difficult than the complete periodic fasts.
('59', 215, 3, 22, 376820) Meagre food voluntarily taken must lead to perfect poise, i.e., perfect health of body and mind.
('59', 215, 3, 23, 376917) We can but make the attempt.
('59', 215, 4, 24, 376946) My food and weight remain what I described them to be last week.
('59', 215, 4, 25, 377011) The elbow continues as before.
('59', 215, 4, 26, 377042) I do not think any more about it.
('59', 215, 4, 27, 377076) I thought I told you that I had resumed spinning.
('59', 215, 4, 28, 377126) I did it, I think, Tuesday last week.

('59', 215, 4, 30, 377204) I have fixed no minimum.

('59', 222, 3, 6, 386989) 1 Though I am a devout Hindu, or even because I am a devout Hindu, I have no difficulty in appreciating the devotional hymns of other religions, and having had intimate contact with many Christians I came to appreciate some of the hymns even as a young ster.

('59', 223, 10, 25, 389418) 327. ITS IMPLICATIONS
('59', 223, 11, 26, 389440) Stanley Jones paid me a visit the other day 1 before sailing for America.
('59', 223, 11, 27, 389514) He said that in America he would be asked many questions about the campaign against untouchability and had, therefore, some questions which he wanted me to answer.
('59', 223, 11, 28, 389678) I was glad of the visit and I readily answered his questions.
('59', 223, 11, 29, 389740) I do not propose to rep roduce the whole of our conversation and all his questions and crossquestions, but I propose to give to the readers the main questions
('59', 223, 12, 30, 389899) 1 On February 4, 1933. Mahadev Desai’s report of this meeting appeared in Mahadevbhaini Diary, “Indian Traders in Natal”, 18 11 1899
('59', 224, 0, 1, 390032) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 225
('59', 224, 1, 2, 390077) and the substance of my answers.
('59', 224, 1, 3, 390110) His first question, then, was:
('59', 224, 2, 4, 390141) Why do you restrict the movement to the removal of untouchability only?
('59', 224, 2, 5, 390213) Why not do away with the caste system altogether?
('59', 224, 2, 6, 390263) If there is a difference between caste and caste, and caste and untouchability, is it not one only of degree?
('59', 224, 3, 7, 390373) ANSWER: Untouchability as it is practised in Hinduism today is, in my opinion, a sin against God and man and is, therefore, like a poison slowly eating into the very vitals of Hinduism.
('59', 224, 3, 8, 390559) In my opinion, it has no sanction whatsoever in the Hindu Shastras taken as a whole.
('59', 224, 3, 9, 390644) Untouchability of a healthy kind is undoubtedly to be found in the Shastras and it is universal in all religions.
('59', 224, 3, 10, 390758) It is a rule of sanitation.
('59', 224, 3, 11, 390786) That will exist to the end of time; but untouchability as we are observing today in India is a hideous thing and wears various forms in various Provinces, even in districts.
('59', 224, 3, 12, 390960) It has degraded both the ‘untouchables’ and the ‘touchables’.
('59', 224, 3, 13, 391022) It has stunted the growth of nearly 40 million human beings.
('59', 224, 3, 14, 391083) They are denied even the ordinary amenities of life.
('59', 224, 3, 15, 391136) The sooner, therefore, it is ended, the better for Hinduism, the better for India and, perhaps, better for mankind in general.
('59', 224, 3, 16, 391263) Not so the caste system.
('59', 224, 3, 17, 391288) There are innumerable castes in India.
('59', 224, 3, 18, 391327) They are a social institution.
('59', 224, 3, 19, 391358) They are so many trade guilds, as was well said by the late Sir William Wilson Hunter.
('59', 224, 3, 20, 391445) And at one time they served a very useful purpose, as, perhaps, they are even now doing to a certain extent.
('59', 224, 3, 21, 391554) This institution has superadded to it restrictions which, in my opinion, are undesirable and are bound to go in course of time.
('59', 224, 3, 22, 391682) There is nothing sinful about them.
('59', 224, 3, 23, 391718) They retard the material progress of those who are labouring under them.
('59', 224, 3, 24, 391791) They are no bar to the spiritual progress.
('59', 224, 3, 25, 391834) The difference, therefore, between caste system and untouchability is not one of degree, but of kind.
('59', 224, 3, 26, 391936) An ‘untouchable’ is outside the pale of respectable society.
('59', 224, 3, 27, 391997) He is hardly treated as a human being.
('59', 224, 3, 28, 392036) He is an outcaste hurled into an abyss by his fellow beings occupying the same platform.
('59', 224, 3, 29, 392125) The difference, therefore, is somewhat analogous to the difference between heaven and hell.
('59', 224, 3, 30, 392217) There is one thing more to be remembered about the caste system.
('59', 224, 3, 31, 392282) For me, it is not the same as varnashramadharma.
('59', 224, 3, 32, 392331) Whilst the caste system is an answer to the social need, varnashrama is based upon the Hindu scriptures.
('59', 224, 3, 33, 392436) Not so the caste system.
('59', 224, 3, 34, 392461) While there are innumerable castes (some dying out and new ones coming into being), the varnas are, and have always been, four.
('59', 224, 3, 35, 392589) I am a firm believer
('59', 225, 0, 1, 392610) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 225, 1, 2, 392652) in varnashrama.
('59', 225, 1, 3, 392668) I have not hesitated before now to consider it as a gift of Hinduism to mankind.
('59', 225, 1, 4, 392749) Acceptance of that dharma is, so far as I have been able to see it, a condition of spiritual growth.
('59', 225, 1, 5, 392850) But I may not here elaborate my view of these four famous divisions in Hinduism.
('59', 225, 1, 6, 392931) Their consideration is irrelevant to the present purpose.
('59', 225, 1, 7, 392989) But I may make this admission that today this varnashramadharma is not being observed in its purity.
('59', 225, 1, 8, 393090) There is an utter confusion of varna and if Hinduism is to become a living force in the world, we have to understand its real purpose and revive it; but we cannot do so, unless the canker of untouchability is destroyed.
('59', 225, 1, 9, 393310) The idea of inferiority and superiority has to be demolished.
('59', 225, 1, 10, 393372) The four divisions are not a vertical section, but a horizontal plane on which all stand on a footing of equality, doing the services respectively assigned to them.
('59', 225, 1, 11, 393537) A life of religion is not a life of privileges but of duty.
('59', 225, 1, 12, 393597) Privileges may come, as they do come to all, from a due fulfilment of duty.
('59', 225, 1, 13, 393673) In the book of God, the same number of marks are assigned to the Brahmin that has done his task well as to the Bhangi who has done likewise.
('59', 225, 1, 14, 393814) The second question was:
('59', 225, 2, 15, 393839) Why do you want temple entry for Harijans?
('59', 225, 2, 16, 393882) Are not temples the lowest thing in Hinduism?
('59', 225, 3, 17, 393928) ANSWER: I do not think so for one moment.
('59', 225, 3, 18, 393970) Temples are to Hindus what churches are to Christians.
('59', 225, 3, 19, 394025) In my opinion, we are all idolators; that in Hinduism we have images of stone or metal inside temples makes to me no difference.
('59', 225, 3, 20, 394154) Thousands of Hindus who visit temples in simple faith derive precisely the same spiritual benefit that Christians visiting churches in simple faith do.
('59', 225, 3, 21, 394306) Deprive a Hindu of his temple, and you deprive him of the thing he generally prizes most in life.
('59', 225, 3, 22, 394404) That superstition and even evil have grown round many Hindu temples is but too true.
('59', 225, 3, 23, 394489) That, however, is an argument for temple reform, not for lowering their value for Harijans or any Hindu.
('59', 225, 3, 24, 394594) It is my certain conviction that temples are an integral part of Hinduism.
('59', 225, 3, 25, 394669) His third question was:
('59', 225, 4, 26, 394693) Was not your fast pure coercion?
('59', 225, 5, 27, 394726) ANSWER: If it is agreed that my fast sprang from love, then it was coercion, only if love of parents for their children or of the latter for the former, or love of husband for wife and wife for husband, or to take a sweeping illustration, love of Jesus for those who own Him as their all, is coercion.
('59', 225, 5, 28, 395028) It is the implicit and sacred belief of millions of Christians that love of Jesus keeps them from falling and that it does
('59', 226, 0, 1, 395151) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 227
('59', 226, 1, 2, 395196) so against themselves.
('59', 226, 1, 3, 395219) His love bends the reason and the emotion of thousands of His votaries to His love.
('59', 226, 1, 4, 395303) I know that, in my childhood, love of my parents kept me from sinning, and, even after fifty years of age, love of my children and friends kept me positively from going to perdition, which I would have done most assuredly but for the definite and overwhelming influence of that love.
('59', 226, 1, 5, 395587) And, if all this love could be regarded as coercion, then the love that prompted my fast and, therefore, my fast, was coercion, but it was that in no other sense.
('59', 226, 1, 6, 395750) Fasting is a great institution in Hinduism, as perhaps in no other religion, and, though it has been abused by people not entitled to fast, it has, on the whole, done the greatest good to Hinduism.
('59', 226, 1, 7, 395948) I believe that there is no prayer without fasting and there is no real fast without prayer.
('59', 226, 1, 8, 396040) My fast was the prayer of a soul in agony.
('59', 226, 2, 9, 396083) Harijan, 11 2 1933
('59', 226, 3, 10, 396102) 328. DR.

('59', 226, 4, 12, 396130) The following has just been received from Dr. Ambedkar:
('59', 226, 5, 13, 396186) At the end of our conversation 1 on Saturday last you asked me to send a message for insertion in the first issue of your new weekly Harijan.
('59', 226, 5, 14, 396328) I feel I cannot give a message.
('59', 226, 5, 15, 396360) For I believe it will be a most unwarranted presumption on my part to suppose that I have sufficient worth in the eyes of the Hindus which would make them treat any message from me with respect.
('59', 226, 5, 16, 396555) I can only speak as man to man.
('59', 226, 5, 17, 396587) As such it may be desirable that the Hindus should know my views on the momentous issue of Hindu social organization with which you have chosen to occupy yourself.
('59', 226, 5, 18, 396751) I am, therefore, sending you the accompanying statement for publication in your Harijan.
('59', 226, 6, 19, 396840) STATEMENT
('59', 226, 7, 20, 396850) The outcaste is a bye product of the caste system.
('59', 226, 7, 21, 396901) There will be outcastes as long as there are castes.
('59', 226, 7, 22, 396954) Nothing can emancipate the outcaste except the destruction of the caste system.
('59', 226, 7, 23, 397034) Nothing can help to save Hindus and ensure their survival in the coming struggle except the purging of the Hindu faith of this odious and vicious dogma.
('59', 226, 7, 24, 397187) DAMODAR HALL PAREL, BOMBAY 12
('59', 226, 8, 25, 397217) 7th February, 1933
('59', 226, 9, 26, 397236) B. R. AMBEDKAR
('59', 226, 10, 27, 397251) 1 Vide “Discussion with B. R. Ambedkar”, 4 2 1933
('59', 227, 0, 1, 397301) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 227, 1, 2, 397343) Dr. Ambedkar is bitter.
('59', 227, 1, 3, 397367) He has every reason to feel so.
('59', 227, 1, 4, 397399) He has received a liberal education.
('59', 227, 1, 5, 397436) He has more than the talents of the average educated Indian.
('59', 227, 1, 6, 397497) Outside India he is received with honour and affection, but, in India, among Hindus, at every step he is reminded that he is one of the outcastes of Hindu society.
('59', 227, 1, 7, 397661) It is nothing to his shame, for, he has done no wrong to Hindu society.
('59', 227, 1, 8, 397733) His exterior is as clean as that of the cleanest and the proudest Brahmin.
('59', 227, 1, 9, 397808) Of his interior, the world knows as little as of that of any of us.
('59', 227, 1, 10, 397876) In spite of all this, he believes that ‘it will be a most unwarranted presumption on his part to suppose that he has sufficient worth in the eyes of the Hindus which would make them treat any message from him with respect’.
('59', 227, 1, 11, 398100) This is the caste Hindus’ shame, not his, but I would like him to feel that there are today thousands of caste Hindus who would listen to his message with the same respect and consideration that they would give to that of any other leader and that in their estimation there is no person high and no person low.
('59', 227, 1, 12, 398411) I would like him, too, to know that Harijan is not my weekly.
('59', 227, 1, 13, 398473) So far as the proprietary rights are concerned it belongs to the Servants of Untouchables Society and, therefore, I would like him to feel that it is as much his as of any other Hindu.
('59', 227, 1, 14, 398658) As to the burden of his message, the opinion he holds about the caste system is shared by many educated Hindus.
('59', 227, 1, 15, 398770) I have not, however, been able to share that opinion.
('59', 227, 1, 16, 398824) I do not believe the caste system, even as distinguished from varnashrama, to be an ‘odious and vicious dogma’.
('59', 227, 1, 17, 398936) It has its limitations and its defects, but there is nothing sinful about it, as there is about untouchability, and, if it is a bye product of the caste system it is only in the same sense that an ugly growth is of a body, or weeds of a crop.
('59', 227, 1, 18, 399179) It is as wrong to destroy caste because of the outcastes as it would be to destroy a body because of an ugly growth in it, or a crop because of the weeds.
('59', 227, 1, 19, 399334) The outcasteness, in the sense we understand it, has, therefore, to be destroyed altogether.
('59', 227, 1, 20, 399427) It is an excess to be removed, if the whole system is not to perish.
('59', 227, 1, 21, 399496) Untouchability is the product, therefore, not of the caste system, but of the distinction of high and low that has crept into Hinduism and is corroding it.
('59', 227, 1, 22, 399652) The attack on untouchability is thus an attack upon this ‘high and low’ness.
('59', 227, 1, 23, 399729) The moment untouchability goes, the caste system itself will be purified, that is to say, according to my dream, it will resolve itself into the true varnadharma, the four divisions of society, each complementary of the other and none inferior or superior to any other, each as necessary for
('59', 228, 0, 1, 400021) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 229
('59', 228, 1, 2, 400066) the whole body of Hinduism as any other.
('59', 228, 1, 3, 400107) How it can be and what that varnashrama is, it is not necessary to examine here.
('59', 228, 1, 4, 400188) But, such being my faith, I have always respectfully differed from those distinguished countrymen, Dr. Ambedkar among them, who have held that untouchability will not go without the destruction of varnashramadharma.
('59', 228, 1, 5, 400404) They have made no distinction between caste and varna.
('59', 228, 1, 6, 400459) But that is another story.
('59', 228, 1, 7, 400486) At the present moment, it is the ‘untouchable’, the outcaste, with whom all Hindu reformers, whether they believe in varnashrama or not, have agreed to deal.
('59', 228, 1, 8, 400644) The opposition to untouchability is common to both.
('59', 228, 1, 9, 400696) Therefore, the present joint fight is restricted to the removal of untouchability, and I would invite Dr. Ambedkar and those who think with him to throw themselves, heart and soul, into the campaign against the monster of untouchability.
('59', 228, 1, 10, 400934) It is highly likely that at the end of it we shall all find that there is nothing to fight against in varnashrama.
('59', 228, 1, 11, 401049) If however, varnashrama even then looks an ugly thing, the whole of Hindu society will fight it.
('59', 228, 1, 12, 401146) For this campaign against untouchability is not one of compulsion, but conversion.
('59', 228, 1, 13, 401229) At the end of the chapter, I hope that we shall all find ourselves in the same camp.
('59', 228, 1, 14, 401314) Should it prove otherwise, it will be time enough to consider how and by whom varnashrama is to be fought.
('59', 228, 2, 15, 401421) Harijan, 11 2 1933
('59', 228, 3, 16, 401440) 329. UNTOUCHABILITY
('59', 228, 4, 17, 401460) Untouchability as at present practised is the greatest blot on Hinduism.
('59', 228, 4, 18, 401533) It is (with apologies to sanatanists) against the Shastras.
('59', 228, 4, 19, 401593) It is against the fundamental principles of humanity, it is against the dictates of reason that a man should, by mere reason of birth, be for ever regarded as an untouchable, even unapproachable and unseeable.
('59', 228, 4, 20, 401803) These adjectives do not convey the full meaning of the thing itself.
('59', 228, 4, 21, 401872) It is a crime for certain men, women and their children to touch, or to approach within stated distances, or to be seen by those who are called caste Hindus.
('59', 228, 4, 22, 402030) The tragedy is that millions of Hindus believe in this institution as if it was enjoined by the Hindu religion.
('59', 228, 5, 23, 402142) Happily, Hindu reformers have recoiled with horror from this practice.
('59', 228, 5, 24, 402213) They have come to the conclusion that it has no support in the Hindu Shastras taken as a whole.
('59', 228, 5, 25, 402309) Isolated texts torn from their context and considered by themselves can no doubt be produced in
('59', 229, 0, 1, 402405) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 229, 1, 2, 402447) support of this practice, as of any evil known to mankind.
('59', 229, 1, 3, 402506) But there is abundant authority in the Shastras to warrant the summary rejection, as being un Hindu, of anything or any practice that is manifestly against the fundamental principles of humanity or morality, of ahimsa or satya 1. This movement against untouchability has been daily gathering strength.
('59', 229, 1, 4, 402808) It was in last September that leading Hindus, claiming to represent the whole of Hindu India, met together and unanimously passed a Resolution 2, condemning untouchability and pledging themselves to abolish it by law, if possible even during the existing regime, and, failing that, when India had a Parliament of her own.
('59', 229, 1, 5, 403130) Among the marks of untouchability to be removed was the prohibition against temple entry by Harijans.
('59', 229, 1, 6, 403232) In the course of the struggle, it was discovered that the British Courts in India had recognized this evil custom, so much so that certain acts done by untouchables as such came to be offences under the British Indian Penal Code.
('59', 229, 1, 7, 403462) Thus, the entry by an untouchable into a Hindu temple would be punishable as a crime under the I.P.C Before, therefore, the movement of temple entry can make headway, it has become imperative to have this anomaly removed.
('59', 229, 1, 8, 403684) It is for this purpose that Sjt.
('59', 229, 1, 9, 403717) Ranga Iyer has given notice of two Bills to be introduced in the Central Legislature.
('59', 229, 1, 10, 403803) After ascertaining the opinion of the Provincial Governments, H.E. the Viceroy has sanctioned the introduction of these Bills.
('59', 229, 1, 11, 403930) But, being private Bills, they have a poor chance of becoming the law of the land, unless the Gove rnment and the members of the Assembly refrain from obstructing its consideration.
('59', 229, 1, 12, 404112) It may be argued that, being pledged to neutrality in matters of religion, the Government are bound to facilitate the passage of the first Bill at any rate, inasmuch as it merely seeks to undo the effect produced by the decisions of British Indian Courts, and this it does by withdrawing legal recognition from untouchability.
('59', 229, 1, 13, 404439) There are practices in various religions professed by the inhabitants of this land whose breach is not regarded as criminal, though it would be regarded as very serious by the respective religious codes.
('59', 229, 1, 14, 404643) Thus, beef eating by a Hindu is an offence in the eye of the Hindu religious code, but rightly not punishable as a crime under the
('59', 229, 2, 15, 404774) 1 Truth 2 Vide “Letter to Ramdas Gandhi”, 6 12 1932
('59', 230, 0, 1, 404826) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 231
('59', 230, 1, 2, 404871) Indian Penal Code.
('59', 230, 1, 3, 404890) Is there, then, any reason why the common law of India should punish a breach of the custom of untouchability?
('59', 230, 1, 4, 405001) If there are many Hindus learned in the Hindu scriptures who find support in them for the present practice of untouchability, there are quite a number of equally learned Hindus holding the opposite view.
('59', 230, 1, 5, 405205) Though this opinion of the pandits has already appeared in the Press, it is reproduced elsewhere for ready reference.
('59', 230, 1, 6, 405323) Let it be noted that the signatories are all orthodox Hindus, as much lovers of their faith as are the learned men of the opposite school.
('59', 230, 1, 7, 405462) On the 25th of January 1933 was held the session of the All India Sanatan Dharma Sabha, presided over by Pandit Malaviyaji and attended by over one hundred learned men.
('59', 230, 1, 8, 405631) It passed a resolution to the effect that Harijans were as much entitled to temple entry as the rest of the Hindus.
('59', 230, 1, 9, 405747) If the Bills are not passed, it is obvious that the central part of the reform will be hung up almost indefinitely.
('59', 230, 1, 10, 405863) Neutrality in matters of religion ought not to mean religious stagnation and hindrance to reform.With due regard to the sanatanists, it is difficult to understand the cry of ‘religion in danger’.
('59', 230, 1, 11, 406059) Under neither Bill will a single temple be opened against the will of the majority of temple goers in question.
('59', 230, 1, 12, 406171) The second Bill expressly says so.
('59', 230, 1, 13, 406206) The first Bill takes up a neutral attitude.
('59', 230, 1, 14, 406250) It does not help a Harijan to force his way into a temple.
('59', 230, 1, 15, 406309) The reformers do not seek to compel the opponents to their will.
('59', 230, 1, 16, 406374) They desire, by the fairest means possible, to convert the majority or the minority, as the case may be, to their view of untouchability.
('59', 230, 1, 17, 406512) It is said that the Harijans themselves do not want temple entry and that they want only betterment of their economic and political condition.
('59', 230, 1, 18, 406655) The reformer, too, wants the latter, but he believes that this betterment will be much quicker brought about, if religious equality is attained.
('59', 230, 1, 19, 406800) The reformer denies that the Harijans do not want temple entry.
('59', 230, 1, 20, 406864) But it may be that they are so disgusted with caste Hindus and Hindu religion itself as to want nothing from them.
('59', 230, 1, 21, 406979) They may in sullen discontent choose to remain outside the religious pale.
('59', 230, 1, 22, 407054) Any penance on the part of caste Hindus may be too late.
('59', 230, 1, 23, 407111) Nevertheless, the caste Hindus who recognize that untouchability is a blot on Hinduism have to atone for the sin of untouchability.
('59', 230, 1, 24, 407243) Whether, therefore, Harijans desire temple entry or not, caste Hindus have to open their temples to Harijans, precisely on the same terms as to other Hindus.
('59', 230, 1, 25, 407401) For a caste Hindu with any sense of honour, temple prohibition is a continuous breach of the pledge taken at the Bombay
('59', 231, 0, 1, 407521) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 231, 1, 2, 407563) meeting of September last.
('59', 231, 1, 3, 407590) Those, who gave their word to the world and to God that they would have the temples opened for the Harijans, have to sacrifice their all, if need be, for redeeming the pledge.
('59', 231, 1, 4, 407766) It may be that they did not represent the Hindu mind.
('59', 231, 1, 5, 407820) They have, then, to own defeat and do the proper penance.
('59', 231, 1, 6, 407878) Temple entry is the one spiritual act that would constitute the message of freedom to the untouchables and assure them that they are not outcastes before God.

('59', 231, 3, 8, 408056) 330. TO THE READER
('59', 231, 4, 9, 408075) The English edition of Harijan is being published by and for the Servants of Untouchables Society at my request and, therefore, in accordance with the views I have long held regarding reform journals.
('59', 231, 4, 10, 408276) It is being published on the assumption that 1. unfortunately, the Hindi edition cannot as yet serve the South and probably, Bengal, 2. it is necessary for the people in the different Provinces to know the progress of the reform from week to week in the Provinces other than their own, 3. since the movement, though essentially Hindu, has a world wide significance and seeks the sympathy, if possible, of the whole of humanity, it is necessary to keep the world acquainted with its implica tions and progress.
('59', 231, 4, 11, 408786) If these assumptions are correct, Harijan will supply a felt want and should, therefore, become self supporting.
('59', 231, 4, 12, 408899) If it does not, it must stop publication.
('59', 231, 4, 13, 408941) If it is published at a loss, it will mean so much money taken from the mouths of Harijans.
('59', 231, 4, 14, 409033) An endeavour is being made to expend every pice of subscription received on behalf of the Society for the sole service of Harijans and the advance of the movement for the removal of untouchability.
('59', 231, 4, 15, 409231) You will note that no advertisements are being taken for the upkeep of the paper.
('59', 231, 4, 16, 409313) It has to depend solely upon the subscriptions received.
('59', 231, 4, 17, 409370) You can send the subscription for yourself or your friends, Indian or foreign, or for institutions, such as libraries, or for poor and deserving Harijans.
('59', 231, 4, 18, 409525) Ten thousand copies are being printed for the time being.
('59', 232, 0, 1, 409583) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 233
('59', 232, 1, 2, 409628) copies will be sent free, either by way of compliment or exchange, but the list can only be limited.
('59', 232, 1, 3, 409729) It is possible for you to extend it.
('59', 232, 1, 4, 409766) I would like every English knowing Harijan student and every untouchability worker to have a free copy on a certified application.
('59', 232, 1, 5, 409897) This is possible only through the active co operation of the reader who can afford to pay more than his own subscription.
('59', 232, 1, 6, 410019) The provincial organizations should send and pay for their own copies of which they should send advice in time, accompanying it with cheques or money orders.
('59', 232, 1, 7, 410177) So much for the financial part of this appeal.
('59', 232, 1, 8, 410224) That part of your obligation I know you will fulfil, if you are a reformer.
('59', 232, 1, 9, 410300) But the harder is the necessary consequence of your fulfilment of that part.
('59', 232, 1, 10, 410377) By paying subscriptions for yourself or others, you buy the right of, and recognize the duty of, serving the great cause in every legitimate manner possible for you.
('59', 232, 1, 11, 410543) Thus, you can become an active helper in spreading the message of Harijan among those who are opposing the reform.
('59', 232, 1, 12, 410658) This requires special qualifi cations.

('59', 232, 1, 16, 410862) They imagine much more than the reform means and, therefore, do not hesitate to ascribe motives to reformers.
('59', 232, 1, 17, 410972) You have, by your gentleness and gentlemanliness, to disarm suspicions and enable them to understand what the reform means.
('59', 232, 1, 18, 411096) If you will diligently study Harijan, it will equip you for the delicate task.
('59', 232, 1, 19, 411175) It will give you an epitome of the week’s doings in the various parts of India in connection with the campaign against untouchability.
('59', 232, 1, 20, 411310) It will also tell you what the others are doing and what the opponents are saying.

('59', 233, 0, 1, 411948) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 233, 1, 2, 411990) 331. WHY ‘HARIJAN’
('59', 233, 2, 3, 412009) Several correspondents have asked me why I have adopted the name ‘Harijan’ for ‘untouchable’.
('59', 233, 2, 4, 412103) Some English friends have asked me for its meaning.
('59', 233, 2, 5, 412155) It is not a name of my coining.
('59', 233, 2, 6, 412187) Some years ago, several ‘untouchable, correspondents complained that I used the word asprishya in the pages of Navajivan 1. Asprishya means literally untouchable.
('59', 233, 2, 7, 412350) I then invited them to suggest a better name and one of the ‘untouchable, correspondents suggested the adoption of the name ‘Harijan’, on the strength of its having been used by the first known poet saint of Gujarat.
('59', 233, 2, 8, 412567) Though the quotation he sent me did not exactly fit the case he wanted to make out for the adoption, I thought that it was a good word.
('59', 233, 2, 9, 412703) ‘Harijan’ means ‘a man of God’.
('59', 233, 2, 10, 412735) All the religions of the world described God pre eminently as the Friend of the friendless, Help of the helpless and Protector of the weak.
('59', 233, 2, 11, 412875) The rest of the world apart, in India who can be more friendless, helpless or weaker than the forty million or more Hindus of India who are classified as untouchables?
('59', 233, 2, 12, 413043) If, therefore, any body of people can be fitly described as men of God, they are surely these helpless, friendless and despised people.
('59', 233, 2, 13, 413179) Hence, in the pages of Navajivan, since the correspondence, I have always adopted Harijan as the name signifying untouchables.
('59', 233, 2, 14, 413306) And, when God chose to entrust me with their service even whilst undergoing imprisonment, I could not use any other word for describing them.
('59', 233, 2, 15, 413448) I recoil with horror from that word and all it implies.
('59', 233, 2, 16, 413504) Not that the change of name brings about any change of status, but one may at least be spared the use of a term which is itself one of reproach.
('59', 233, 2, 17, 413649) When caste Hindus have of their own inner conviction and, therefore, voluntarily got rid of the present day untouchability, we shall all be called Harijans, for, according to my humble opinion, caste Hindus will then have found favour with God and may, therefore, be fitly described as His men.
('59', 233, 3, 18, 413944) Harijan, 11 2 1933
('59', 233, 4, 19, 413963) 1 Vide “My Notes”, Harijana
('59', 234, 0, 1, 413991) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 235
('59', 234, 1, 2, 414036) 332. SEEKING OR GIVING?
('59', 234, 2, 3, 414060) Several friends have written to me letters asking me in substance the following question: Why is it that you, who have always sworn by non co operation with the Government and Legislatures, are now carrying on propaganda for the passage of untouchability Bills by the present Legislatures, and are thus co operating with both the Government and the Legislatures?
('59', 234, 2, 4, 414423) Newspaper reporters also have been plying me with the same question.
('59', 234, 2, 5, 414492) I have evaded both by saying that I cannot, consistently with my obligation as a prisoner, deal with this question as fully as I would like to.
('59', 234, 2, 6, 414636) But I can say this much, that there is no doctrine in the world which admits of the same kind of application under every variety of circumstance.
('59', 234, 2, 7, 414782) Different circumstances evoke different applications of the same doctrine.
('59', 234, 2, 8, 414857) Thus, my love for a starving man would require me to feed him.
('59', 234, 2, 9, 414920) My love for my overfed child would require me to starve him, even though he may be crying for food.
('59', 234, 2, 10, 415020) I am today non co operating with sanatanist friends, but I would like my questioners to analyse my non co operation, and they will find that in the very act of non co operation I am seeking their co operation in my campaign.
('59', 234, 2, 11, 415245) Exactly in the same manner, I may non co operate as much as I like with Government or any institution, but I would be a very foolish man, if I did not know that I was non co operating in order to secure co operation from them.
('59', 234, 2, 12, 415472) Thus, I am now seeking the co operation of the Government and the Legislatures in order to further my purpose, which I hold to be very sacred and altogether good.
('59', 234, 2, 13, 415635) Beyond this I may not go, for the reason I have already stated and which the reader should respect.
('59', 234, 3, 14, 415735) Harijan, 11 2 1933
('59', 235, 0, 1, 415754) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 235, 1, 2, 415796) 333. AN OVERDUE CIVIC REFORM
('59', 235, 2, 3, 415825) Hiralal A. Shah writes: 1
('59', 235, 3, 4, 415851) The suggestion made by Sjt.
('59', 235, 3, 5, 415879) Shah is certainly worthy of consideration as well by municipalities and local bodies as by individuals, but particularly by the former.
('59', 235, 3, 6, 416015) Corporate cleanliness can only be ensured, if there is a corporate conscience and a corporate insistence on cleanliness in public places.
('59', 235, 3, 7, 416153) Untouchability has a great deal to answer for the insanitation of our streets and our latrines, whether private or public.
('59', 235, 3, 8, 416276) In its inception, untouchability was a rule of sanitation, and still is in all parts of the world outside India.
('59', 235, 3, 9, 416389) That is to say, an unclean person or thing is untouchable, but immediately his or its uncleanliness is shed, he or it is no longer untouchable.
('59', 235, 3, 10, 416533) Therefore, a person who is to attend to scavenging, whether it is a paid Bhangi or an unpaid mother, they are unclean until they have washed themselves clean of their unclean work.
('59', 235, 3, 11, 416714) If, instead of being regarded as untouchable for ever, the Bhangi was treated as brother and was given an opportunity and even made to become clean after performing an unclean service for society, he should be as acceptable as any other member of that society.
('59', 235, 3, 12, 416975) Corporations can, therefore, lead the way in this matter, but they will not unless the citizens insist.
('59', 235, 3, 13, 417079) It is truly said that Corporations have no souls, that is, apart from the souls of the citizens.
('59', 235, 3, 14, 417176) Whilst, therefore, commending Sjt.
('59', 235, 3, 15, 417211) Shah’s suggestion to all concerned, I would advise him to concentrate his energy upon one single spot and there agitate, both amongst the public and their Corporation, for the much needed reform.
('59', 235, 3, 16, 417407) Let him, therefore, devote every ounce of his spare energy to educating public opinion in Bombay, where he has his habitation, evolve concrete suggestions and get them accepted by the people in the different wards, and he will soon find that his labours are crowned with success.
('59', 235, 4, 17, 417687) Harijan, 11 2 1933

('59', 236, 1, 2, 417895) 334. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('59', 236, 2, 3, 417947) February 11, 1933
('59', 236, 3, 4, 417965) DEAR SIR, On the 8th instant Major Bhandari communicated to me the information that Government had decided to withhold a letter addressed to me by Appasaheb Patwardhan.
('59', 236, 3, 5, 418134) The next morning I saw in The Times of India a paragraph to the effect that Appasaheb had put himself on reduced rations.
('59', 236, 3, 6, 418256) Thereupon the same day I wrote 1 to Col.
('59', 236, 3, 7, 418297) Doyle inquiring about the news and asking to know the orders of the Government of India about conservancy work in the prisons by volunteer prisoners.
('59', 236, 3, 8, 418447) Not having any reply I sent yesterday a reminder.
('59', 236, 3, 9, 418497) 2 Since then I have a copy of the orders of the Government of India, but no reply to my inquiry about Appasaheb.
('59', 236, 3, 10, 418610) For me the matter is of the gravest importance involving my honour.
('59', 236, 3, 11, 418678) As a result of the protracted correspondence between the authorities and me there was a settlement about the subject matter thereof and at the instance of Col.
('59', 236, 3, 12, 418838) Doyle I sent the following wire 3 to Appasaheb Patwardhan on the 6th December last.
('59', 236, 3, 13, 418922) It clearly foreshadows resumption of fast by him in the event of an unfavourable decision.
('59', 236, 3, 14, 419013) The Government will observe that any decision in this matter that affects Appasaheb affects me equally.
('59', 236, 3, 15, 419117) As I read the whole of the transactions between December 1st and now in this matter, the Government have recognized the correctness of my action.
('59', 236, 3, 16, 419263) I hope that they do not now intend to revise their attitude and cut me off from Appasaheb.
('59', 236, 3, 17, 419354) For the moment therefore I ask whether Appasaheb is or very recently had been on a partial fast and whether he and his comrades have been now permitted to do conservancy work.
('59', 236, 3, 18, 419530) Owing to the increasing tension caused by the report of Appasaheb’s partial fast, I am requesting Major Bhandari, if he has authority, or to request Col.
('59', 236, 3, 19, 419684) Doyle, if he has not, to telegraph or

('59', 238, 11, 18, 422004) 339. LETTER TO RAMANANDA CHATTERJEE
('59', 238, 12, 19, 422040) February 11, 1933
('59', 238, 13, 20, 422058) DEAR RAMANANDA BABOO, I thank you for taking so much trouble over my letter of the 20th ultimo about the Yeravda Pact.
('59', 238, 13, 21, 422177) I had read all that appeared in the
('59', 238, 14, 22, 422213) 1 Gandhiji’s co worker in Champaran; vide
('59', 238, 15, 23, 422255) 2 Report of a lecture by Sophia Wadia
('59', 239, 0, 1, 422293) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 239, 1, 2, 422335) Modern Review 1 on the Pact and I wish that I had spared you the trouble of sending me copies by telling you that I had read them and asking you if you had any further comments to offer on the matter in view of the agitation set up in Bengal.
('59', 239, 1, 3, 422578) I am not so bad as I used to be out of prison.
('59', 239, 1, 4, 422625) Then, I had not a moment to read even the Modern Review let alone other magazines and papers.
('59', 239, 1, 5, 422719) Inside the prison hitherto I have had time to read the Modern Review which you have been so kindly and punctually sending me from month to month.
('59', 239, 2, 6, 422865) The argument in your letter 2 is quite clear to me though it does not convince me.
('59', 239, 2, 7, 422948) I was surprised even when I read your note on the Yeravda Pact.
('59', 239, 2, 8, 423012) For I had heard that you had been party to the statement made by Dr. Moonje that so far as Hindu Sabha was concerned he was quite willing that cent per cent seats were given to the depressed classes, and I was glad when I read the statement and still more so when I heard that you had heartily approved of it.
('59', 239, 3, 9, 423322) My own position is fundamentally different from yours.
('59', 239, 3, 10, 423377) If there was to be any reservation at all, and I saw that there had to be, we could not afford to give it in a niggardly spirit.
('59', 239, 3, 11, 423506) We were bound to give as many seats as Harijan representatives desired and certainly up to their numerical strength.
('59', 239, 3, 12, 423623) My action was based on absolute trust.
('59', 239, 3, 13, 423662) If we have to suffer for it no one will be to blame but ourselves.
('59', 239, 3, 14, 423729) We can never suffer if we will be only strictly just to them.
('59', 239, 3, 15, 423791) We can never be generous, for there is no danger for years to come of our giving them too much.
('59', 239, 3, 16, 423887) I wish that I can persuade every caste Hindu as to the measure of the enormity of the wrong done by them to Harijans.
('59', 239, 3, 17, 424005) Nor do I mind many who have hitherto described themselves as caste Hindus rushing to the registering officers to be classified as Harijans.
('59', 239, 3, 18, 424145) I do not mind because daily we must be advancing towards effacement of the vicious distinction between caste Hindus and outcastes, so much
('59', 239, 4, 19, 424284) 1 Of Octobers, 1932 2 Wherein the addressee had written: “My individual opinion is against the Poona Pact, so far as it relates to Bengal .
('59', 239, 4, 20, 424424) Reservation of seats for the depressed will not help the really “depressed” or “untouchable” people.
('59', 239, 4, 21, 424525) The present “depressed” class M.L.C.s generally oppose nationalist parties and side with the pro bureaucracy Mussalmans.
('59', 239, 4, 22, 424646) Giving 30 seats out of 80 to the depressed castes would mean the practical wiping out of a nationalist opposition party in the future Bengal Council.
('59', 239, 4, 23, 424796) .” (S. N. 20155).
('59', 240, 0, 1, 424814) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 241
('59', 240, 1, 2, 424859) so that it would be a privilege for a caste Hindu to be classified as Harijan.
('59', 240, 1, 3, 424938) Indeed, in my opinion Bengal is in a better position than the other Provinces, if it is true that there are very few untouchables in the real sense of the term and I think that it is true but that many are classed as such because they are economically depressed and are suffering from other social disabilities than untouchability.
('59', 240, 1, 4, 425270) So far as I am concerned, let all, everywhere, who are at all economically depressed and are suffering from any social disability get themselves registered as Harijans, if to be registered as Harijans is an optional act.
('59', 240, 1, 5, 425491) That very fact will be a factor in the removal of untouchability instead of, as you fear, in hardening it.
('59', 240, 1, 6, 425598) Lastly, I do not share your fear that in many elections only those who may be called advanced Harijans will be elected.
('59', 240, 1, 7, 425718) That and many other things will undoubtedly happen if the reformer either goes to sleep or is insincere.
('59', 240, 1, 8, 425823) If he is sincere and active, untouchability will be a dying cult and those who are lowest in the social scale and intelligence will get their due.
('59', 240, 1, 9, 425970) And if at the bottom of all your arguments and fears there is the suspicion that the reformer is not all that one would desire it to be, for a moment, but only for a moment, I would be tempted to share that suspicion, but I am a born optimist.
('59', 240, 1, 10, 426214) I have faith in my sincerity and activity.
('59', 240, 1, 11, 426257) Therefore I refuse to suspect my comrades.
('59', 240, 1, 12, 426300) Hence the counter arguments that I have advanced.
('59', 240, 1, 13, 426350) I would invite you to share my faith in the reform and the reformers and believe with me that if we are true the Harijans will be true and all will be well.
('59', 240, 1, 14, 426507) If you find nothing in my letter that appeals to you I would like you to strive with me and tear my argument to pieces.
('59', 240, 1, 15, 426627) You know the regard I have for you.
('59', 240, 1, 16, 426663) If it admits of enhancement it would only be enhanced by your frank and fearless criticism.
('59', 240, 1, 17, 426755) I am anxious that we approach the Yeravda Pact and all it means with perfect confidence in its correctness.
('59', 240, 2, 18, 426863) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 240, 2, 19, 426885) RAMANANDA CHATTERJEE

('59', 242, 1, 2, 428256) 342. LETTER TO P. R. THAKUR
('59', 242, 2, 3, 428284) February 11, 1933
('59', 242, 3, 4, 428302) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of the 6th instant.
('59', 242, 3, 5, 428363) I have never believed that the problem of untouchability can be solved by mere temple entry.
('59', 242, 3, 6, 428456) But I do believe that it can never be solved without temple entry on equal terms with the others, and I further believe that the economic and educational advance can be accelerated by temple entry which is really the mark of the removal of untouchability.
('59', 242, 3, 7, 428712) One may be ever so educated and ever so rich and yet be untouchable, but immediately he has got religious equality through temple entry, untouchability is gone.
('59', 242, 3, 8, 428873) At the same time, I believe with you that the educational and economic advance must not be neglected nor subordinated to temple entry.
('59', 242, 3, 9, 429008) As a matter of fact, that isbeing prosecuted [as] vigorously as it is possible to do.
('59', 242, 4, 10, 429094) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 242, 4, 11, 429116) P. R. THAKUR VICE PRESIDENT ALL BENGAL DEPRESSED CLASSES FEDERATION 127/1 RUSSA ROAD CALCUTTA

('59', 245, 1, 2, 433426) 347. LETTER TO G. M. THAWARE
('59', 245, 2, 3, 433455) February 12, 1933
('59', 245, 3, 4, 433473) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter for which I thank you.
('59', 245, 3, 5, 433528) The idea of a separate university for Harijans is attractive, but it is hardly necessary to create a separate university.
('59', 245, 3, 6, 433650) In the place of that we have Mr. David’s scheme of which you must have already read and of which you will see a little more in last week’s Harijan.
('59', 245, 3, 7, 433798) It is elastic and economical in the sense that every rupee obtained under the scheme goes directly for the tuition of Harijans and it is also the quickest method of giving higher education to selected Harijan students.
('59', 245, 3, 8, 434017) If Mr. David’s scheme proves successful, there should be no difficulty in extending it so as to cover a further selection of students for being sent to foreign countries.
('59', 245, 3, 9, 434188) Industrial education too I should treat precisely in the same manner as I would treat higher education.
('59', 245, 3, 10, 434292) Of cinema shows I understand but little, having never attended any.
('59', 245, 3, 11, 434360) An attempt is already being made to induce the better classes to engage Harijans as domestic servants and I think it is coming.
('59', 245, 3, 12, 434488) As to the caste system, I would commend the last week’s issue of Harijan to your attention for my views.
('59', 245, 3, 13, 434593) I think this answers all your questions.
('59', 245, 3, 14, 434634) I take it that you have sent a copy of your letter to the Central Board or at least a similar letter, if not a copy.
('59', 245, 4, 15, 434751) Yours sincerely G. M. THAWARE ASST.

('59', 246, 1, 2, 434908) 348. LETTER TO N.
('59', 246, 2, 3, 434926) February 12, 1933
('59', 246, 3, 4, 434944) DEAR N., Kumar Diwakar Singh whom you call Devula gave me your note.
('59', 246, 3, 5, 435013) Your way of addressing me as your son is very strange.
('59', 246, 3, 6, 435068) I lost my mother years ago.
('59', 246, 3, 7, 435096) I am fast making daughters and sisters.
('59', 246, 3, 8, 435136) But mother I have not found.
('59', 246, 3, 9, 435165) Age is no bar.
('59', 246, 3, 10, 435180) If you can inspire me with mother worship towards you nothing would please me better.
('59', 246, 3, 11, 435266) But let me say that your letter before me has filled me with misgivings.
('59', 246, 3, 12, 435339) It smells of the hysteric.
('59', 246, 3, 13, 435366) Your judgment of the friend whom you have sent is not confirmed by my talks with him.
('59', 246, 3, 14, 435452) He seems to me to be a youth of unbalanced mind.
('59', 246, 3, 15, 435501) He is not likely to do much in Allahabad.
('59', 246, 3, 16, 435543) But more serious still is the attack upon your character that came to me yesterday from an unexpected source.
('59', 246, 3, 17, 435653) The friend who gave me the warning is a man of great worth and has no end to serve by misleading me.
('59', 246, 3, 18, 435754) He simply warns me against my playing into your hands; of course the friend has no first hand information.
('59', 246, 3, 19, 435861) But it is against my nature to keep such reports from those of whom I have them and in whose welfare I may be interested as I am in yours.
('59', 246, 3, 20, 436000) Your first letters prepossessed me in your favour and I thought that I could use you for the common service of Truth.
('59', 246, 3, 21, 436118) This report coupled with your latest letter have created a doubt in my mind.
('59', 246, 3, 22, 436195) I should hope that it has no solid foundation.
('59', 246, 3, 23, 436242) If you have any care for my opinion, you will lay aside all work and without trumpet come to Poona, leave your luggage at the station and come to me any day after 9 a.m.
('59', 246, 3, 24, 436412) and let me see you face to face and ask you some straight questions.
('59', 246, 4, 25, 436481) Yours sincerely,
('59', 246, 5, 26, 436498) M. K. GANDHI

('59', 248, 8, 13, 438811) An act of expiation for violation of a vow should be directly related to the nature of the vow.
('59', 248, 8, 14, 438907) If one has been guilty of telling a lie, the proper expiation for it should be observance of silence for some time and not a resolution to give up drinking, for the latter is desirable even in itself.
('59', 248, 8, 15, 439108) If drinking was the cause of one’s speaking, untruth, then of course it would be one’s duty to give it up.

('59', 249, 8, 12, 440384) KAKA, I got your letter.
('59', 249, 8, 13, 440409) If we have trouble when we cut teeth, why should we not have it also when we lose them?
('59', 249, 8, 14, 440497) Do you get pure milk?
('59', 249, 8, 15, 440519) Though your experience is that a milk diet brings on weakness and causes diarrhoea, I still think that the experiment is worth making.

('59', 249, 8, 17, 440726) The fact that you require them indicates some weakness in the system.
('59', 249, 8, 18, 440796) I cling to my belief that one can eat wheat only when one is able to digest milk and fruits.
('59', 249, 8, 19, 440889) Some people believe that solid food helps in the digestion of milk.
('59', 249, 8, 20, 440957) But in fact it is not digested, and is retained in the body in some harmful form which gives one the illusion of strength.
('59', 249, 8, 21, 441080) If you get pure and fresh milk, it is worth while trying the experiment of drinking it without heating it.
('59', 249, 8, 22, 441187) These days I drink such milk.
('59', 249, 8, 23, 441217) It has done no harm so far, though I have not carried on the experiment long enough to say that it has benefited me.
('59', 249, 8, 24, 441334) I started it about fifteen days ago.

('59', 250, 7, 13, 442075) BAL, I got your letter.
('59', 250, 7, 14, 442099) You did a very good thing in fasting as a remedy for your fever.
('59', 250, 7, 15, 442164) An innocuous egg is one from which no chick can come out.
('59', 250, 7, 16, 442222) Personally I regard such eggs as acceptable food.
('59', 250, 7, 17, 442272) From a medical point of view, they are beneficial in a variety of conditions.
('59', 250, 7, 18, 442350) They are likely to be harmful in regard to brahmacharya, but not to persons of weak health.
('59', 250, 7, 19, 442442) There are two considerations which can be urged against such eggs.
('59', 250, 7, 20, 442509) From a religious point of view, they are an unnecessary addition to the number of articles which we eat, and from the point of view of vegetarianism they are as objectionable as milk.
('59', 250, 7, 21, 442693) Probably it gives a hen greater pain to carry such eggs and be caged for their sake than it does a cow to be milked.
('59', 250, 7, 22, 442810) However, such eggs are not in the same category as meat, which we regard as forbidden.
('59', 250, 7, 23, 442897) It may be necessary in some cases to recommend innocuous eggs as medicine.
('59', 250, 7, 24, 442972) This fully sums up my view on this subject.
('59', 250, 7, 25, 443016) Keep a diary and do not neglect to spin for yajna.

('59', 255, 0, 1, 449376) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 255, 1, 2, 449418) 364. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('59', 255, 2, 3, 449450) February 13, 1933
('59', 255, 3, 4, 449468) PREMA, It is the morning of the silence day.
('59', 255, 3, 5, 449513) I got up at three and have taken up your letter to reply to it.
('59', 255, 3, 6, 449577) I liked it very much indeed.
('59', 255, 3, 7, 449606) You have given me in it all that I wanted.
('59', 255, 3, 8, 449649) It fully answers to my imagination of what women can give me.
('59', 255, 3, 9, 449711) What it gives seems small and unspectacular, but is very useful to a seeker after truth.
('59', 255, 3, 10, 449800) I learn something from an objective letter like this one, and it helps me to guide you and others.
('59', 255, 3, 11, 449899) The Ashram is indeed a dharmashala.
('59', 255, 3, 12, 449935) But the word has two meanings.
('59', 255, 3, 13, 449966) It means a place where people can stay free, but it also means a place where one can learn dharma and try to follow it.
('59', 255, 3, 14, 450086) The Ashram is a dharmashala in this second sense of the word.
('59', 255, 3, 15, 450148) But dharma means truth.
('59', 255, 3, 16, 450172) The Ashram, therefore, is a place where one may know the truth and try to follow it, that is, show agraha 1 for it, and hence it is Satyagraha Ashram.
('59', 255, 3, 17, 450323) In our quest for truth, we wish to cultivate unity with all living creatures.
('59', 255, 3, 18, 450401) The Ashram, therefore, is an ever growing family.
('59', 255, 3, 19, 450451) But it is something more even than that, for it is the means and dharma is the end, and not vice versa.
('59', 255, 3, 20, 450555) It is also a big school, and yet it is not so; for, since it is a family, we cannot mechanically apply there rules of outward behaviour such as are followed for other types of training.
('59', 255, 3, 21, 450741) The letter of the rule has to be sacrificed in order to save the spirit of the rule.
('59', 255, 3, 22, 450826) I will now apply these observations to some specific cases.
('59', 255, 3, 23, 450886) In bringing up and educating Lakshmi, we, including you, are being tested.
('59', 255, 3, 24, 450961) What would we do to children in our own family?
('59', 255, 3, 25, 451009) What would you do to your own sister?
('59', 255, 3, 26, 451047) If Lakshmi does not observe the rules, the fault is chiefly mine, and then yours.
('59', 255, 3, 27, 451129) I leave out the others.
('59', 255, 3, 28, 451153) I leave out Narandas, too, for if we hold him responsible for the behaviour of every person in the Ashram, he will not be able to attend to his own duties.
('59', 255, 3, 29, 451309) Looking after Lakshmi is a woman’s job, and particularly of the woman to whom it is entrusted.
('59', 255, 3, 30, 451404) The fault is chiefly mine because I am her adopted father and also mother.
('59', 255, 3, 31, 451479) I did my duty as a father but
('59', 255, 4, 32, 451509) 1 Firmness
('59', 256, 0, 1, 451520) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 257
('59', 256, 1, 2, 451565) not as a mother, because I remained away from the Ashram most of the time.
('59', 256, 1, 3, 451640) I feel now that I should not have accepted Lakshmi at all.

('59', 256, 1, 38, 453729) This means that there should be increasing simplicity in our life in the Ashram and the rules should be observed more and more strictly.

('59', 257, 1, 2, 454278) ,protection for ourselves in our inner selves and not outside of us “we” here means all of us who voluntarily stay in the Ashram, you, I and everybody else.
('59', 257, 1, 3, 454435) And one should not observe only as many rules as the other inmates do.

('59', 257, 1, 8, 454916) The ideal for girls is a life of inviolate brahmacharya.

('59', 258, 4, 21, 458019) 365. LETTER TO HINDU CENTRAL COMMITTEE
('59', 258, 5, 22, 458058) February 13, 1933
('59', 258, 6, 23, 458076) DEAR FRIENDS, 1. In continuation of my letter acknowledging yours of 4th instant I have now to say that I have read the statement of the Hindu Central Committee with much attention and when after reading the statement I saw the names of distinguished lawyers amongst other notabilities as the original members of the Committee I was filled with sorrow.
('59', 258, 6, 24, 458429) 2. Take this assertion in the statement:
('59', 258, 7, 25, 458470) We feel that there is no question of inferiority complex in the divi 
('59', 258, 8, 26, 458540) sions of Hindu society and least of all, no sin has been committed all these
('59', 258, 9, 27, 458617) centuries by the orthodox Hindus who have been following the traditions
('59', 258, 10, 28, 458689) established by all the merciful humanitarian sages of this land.
('59', 258, 10, 29, 458754) Is this assertion borne out by the evidence of the senses?
('59', 258, 10, 30, 458813) If the Committee were to contend that there is in the Hindu Shastras no
('59', 259, 0, 1, 458885) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 259, 1, 2, 458927) inferiority or superiority I should at once agree.
('59', 259, 1, 3, 458978) But untouchability as it is practised today with the attendant system of locations and deprivation practically of all the amenities of life for the so called untouchables is surely proof of their inferiority.
('59', 259, 1, 4, 459187) These disabilities have been often enumerated in the public Press.
('59', 259, 1, 5, 459254) The precept of equality therefore seems to have been systematically and cruelly disregarded by modern Hindu society.
('59', 259, 1, 6, 459371) Is the Committee able to point out any act on the part of what it calls the orthodox Hindus for the amelioration of the economic and material condition of the depressed classes?
('59', 259, 1, 7, 459549) And is not the very existence of a class called “depressed” sufficient contradiction of the above quoted assertion?
('59', 259, 1, 8, 459665) 3. The Committee then proceeds and says:
('59', 259, 2, 9, 459706) There are also in many places in the country large sections of the population amongst caste Hindus who are worse than Panchamas both
('59', 259, 3, 10, 459839) economically and culturally.
('59', 259, 3, 11, 459868) I am unaware of any sections of caste Hindus who are both economically and culturally worse than Panchamas, and if there are I should very much like to know their names.
('59', 259, 3, 12, 460038) 4. The third statement of the Committee to which I would invite attention is:
('59', 259, 4, 13, 460116) It will be a travesty of truth to suggest that the orthodox Hindus have not been generous in their dealings with the Panchamas or Harijans in the
('59', 259, 5, 14, 460262) villages.
('59', 259, 5, 15, 460272) Is it a sign of generosity on the part of caste Hindus to give leavings of their dishes to Harijans, to force their labour against a starvation wage, to deny to them the services of physicians, schoolmasters, barbers and practically all the other services to which they, the caste Hindus, are used?
('59', 259, 5, 16, 460571) 5. Another statement of the Committee is:
('59', 259, 6, 17, 460613) Except in the higher classes today, there is no unemployment problem in the country.
('59', 259, 6, 18, 460698) Surely, this is a sweeping statement at complete variance with known facts as found in historical and Government records.
('59', 259, 6, 19, 460820) 6. The Committee then proceeds:
('59', 259, 7, 20, 460852) The first creed of the orthodox Hindu is always the gift of food to the hungry and he has always felt it as a religious duty and his first prayer has been to the Lord to vouchsafe happiness to all human beings.
('59', 259, 7, 21, 461063) The creed is undoubtedly there.
('59', 259, 7, 22, 461095) Has the Committee any
('59', 260, 0, 1, 461117) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 261
('59', 260, 1, 2, 461162) evidence to show any corresponding action on the part of the orthodox Hindus in connection with Harijans?
('59', 260, 1, 3, 461268) 7. Then the Committee goes on to say:
('59', 260, 2, 4, 461306) It cannot be suggested for one moment that though the Congress has thrown itself whole heartedly in favour of this agitation for the removal of untouchability and for temple entry after the announcement of the fast of Mr. Gandhi, it has done any appreciable service for the economic and material uplift of the depressed classes.
('59', 260, 2, 5, 461635) The Committee should know that it is not possible for the Congress “to throw itself whole heartedly into the agitation”.
('59', 260, 2, 6, 461756) It is being carried on by the general Hindu population organized by the recently formed Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 260, 2, 7, 461878) That Society invites all without distinction of party to help it to remove untouchability.
('59', 260, 2, 8, 461969) This Society has planned a wide constructive programme.
('59', 260, 2, 9, 462025) In so far as the Congress itself is concerned, its Hindu members have a record for the service of Harijans which is second to that of no other similar organization.
('59', 260, 2, 10, 462190) 8. But the Committee goes on:
('59', 260, 3, 11, 462220) If the call to join the movement for such uplift comes from persons who are pledged to temple entry, the orthodox Hindus on their part cannot but view it with suspicion, especially when it is preceded by Gandhi’s cry of “Leave the temple entry to me”.
('59', 260, 3, 12, 462472) I fail to see why the orthodox Hindus should view with suspicion the call for joining the movement for uplift because it comes from persons who are openly advocating temple entry, not by compulsion but by conversion.
('59', 260, 3, 13, 462689) And what can be the meaning of emphasis on my statement “Leave the temple entry to me”?
('59', 260, 3, 14, 462777) I am charitable enough to assume that the Committee framed that sentence without knowing the context in which ‘‘Leave the temple entry to me” was first used.
('59', 260, 3, 15, 462935) It was said in answer to correspondents who were impatient to offer satyagraha and adopt energetic measures for opening other temples.
('59', 260, 3, 16, 463070) In order to keep the movement within fixed limits and in order to confine direct action by way of fast for the present at least to Sjt.
('59', 260, 3, 17, 463206) Kelappan and myself I said to the correspondents, “Leave the temple entry to me and go on with the other constructive programme of economic and educational uplift”.
('59', 260, 3, 18, 463371) The Committee can easily verify this from my writings.
('59', 260, 3, 19, 463426) I hope therefore that the Committee will disabuse their minds of the prejudice betrayed against me in the sentence quoted.
('59', 261, 0, 1, 463549) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 261, 1, 2, 463591) 9. The next sentence in the Committee’s statement runs:
('59', 261, 2, 3, 463647) If Mr. Gandhi and his followers will give an undertaking to save temples and other religious institutions from interference by the mixed legislatures of the land, we are willing to whole heartedly co operate with them.
('59', 261, 2, 4, 463866) I have shown repeatedly that the two Bills before the Legislative Assembly imply no interference with temples or other religious institutions.
('59', 261, 2, 5, 464009) They seek to restore the status quo existing before certain decisions of law courts, well known to the legal members of the Committee.
('59', 261, 2, 6, 464144) I can give the assurance on my behalf and on behalf of my co workers that we have no desire whatsoever to invoke interference by the legislatures in matters of religion and if only the Committee will co operate in the prosecution of the general movement for the removal of untouchability, not of the desirable type such as is mentioned in the Shastras in the interests of sanitation, but of the—in my opinion—undesirable type as is being practised today, the Committee will soon discover that there is no cause whatsoever for alarm or suspicion and that if there is anything in the two Bills that can be shown to be an interference with religious liberty, the defect can undoubtedly be remedied without difficulty.
('59', 261, 2, 7, 464859) 10. With the sentiment expressed in the last two sentences of the statement of the Committee I can whole heartedly agree, for so far as I am concerned there is no desire indiscriminately “to import Western ideals of society, civilization and equality”.
('59', 261, 2, 8, 465112) Perhaps, no one has written, and endeavoured as much as possible to act in accordance with the writing, against Western civilization and I have not the slightest desire to destroy the foundations of Hindu caste system, if by that is meant varnashramadharma.
('59', 261, 2, 9, 465370) The movement against untoucha bility is on that very account deliberately circumscribed and restricted to the very things described by the Committee except temple entry, and as to this last, it can be shown conclusively that there is no desire whatsoever to force temple entry but by proper disciplined agitation to bring about a change in Hindu public opinion, a change not inconsistent with the spirit of the Shastras.
('59', 261, 2, 10, 465791) 11. If the Committee will dispassionately read my analysis of the statement, I am not without hope that it will see that whoever has framed the statement has committed the members of the Committee to assertions which cannot be supported by existing facts.
('59', 261, 2, 11, 466047) The statement though sent to me is merely a copy of what has already been sent to
('59', 262, 0, 1, 466129) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 263
('59', 262, 1, 2, 466174) the Press, but on reading the statement I discovered that according to the Committee’s admissions there was a great deal that was common between the Committee and the reformers and that the assertions which were made in order to emphasize differences were mostly if not wholly imaginary and not capable of proof.
('59', 262, 1, 3, 466487) I felt that I would point out to the Committee in a private communication the glaring flaws in the statement and see if there was not any possibility of meeting on a common platform.
('59', 262, 1, 4, 466670) 12. If the Committee however considers that all the assertions made in the statement can be supported and that I am labouring under self delusion, I would be glad to be corrected.
('59', 262, 1, 5, 466850) If the Committee sees any good in my letter, I invite it to send one or more representatives to confer with me with a view to exploring possibilities of common action or at least of understanding the real differences in matters of principle.
('59', 262, 1, 6, 467092) Pending your reply, I am not sending this letter to the Press, but if the Committee finds it to be hopeless, it is at liberty to publish it.
('59', 262, 2, 7, 467233) Yours sincerely, THE HON.
