('59', 264, 4, 7, 469685) 370. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS2
('59', 264, 5, 8, 469721) February 13, 1933
('59', 264, 6, 9, 469739) Asked if permission was given to Appasaheb as a special case, Mr. Gandhi declined to answer.
('59', 264, 6, 10, 469832) But it is learnt that the new orders of the Government of India, while permitting high caste Hindus to do voluntary conservancy work, leave it entirely to the discretion of the Jail Superintendent to permit or not to permit a particular prisoner to do this.
('59', 264, 6, 11, 470090) Asked why he attached such importance to this subject, Mr. Gandhi replied that untouchability had to go everywhere, and more so in jails.
('59', 264, 6, 12, 470228) Untouchability could not exist in jails where prisoners could not insist on high class and low class distinctions, and where they must be willing to perform all services, including those imposed on the so called low castes.
('59', 264, 6, 13, 470452) Asked if he would advise high castes outside also to do conservancy work, Mr. Gandhi replied: I would most decidedly expect high caste men to render voluntarily all useful services which today are reserved to certain classes.
('59', 264, 6, 14, 470678) The idea that the most necessary service in the world will be considered degrading or should carry any sin with it is abhorrent to me.
('59', 264, 6, 15, 470813) Our villages will wear a different appearance altogether when sanitary services begin to be classed among the honourable occupations, nor will the streets of our cities be so dangerously dirty as they are today, when we have ceased to consider it degrading to take a brush, bucket and broom in order to do the necessary cleansing.
('59', 264, 7, 16, 471144) The Hindu, 14 2 1933
('59', 264, 8, 17, 471165) 1 Omission as in the source 2 Gandhiji was interviewed after he had received information of the breaking of partial fast by Appasaheb Patwardhan in Ratnagiri Jail when he was permitted to do conservancy work as a volunteer.

('59', 265, 12, 17, 471912) 372. LETTER TO SRIPRAKASA
('59', 265, 13, 18, 471938) February 14, 1933
('59', 265, 14, 19, 471956) MY DEAR SHRIPRAKASH, Though doleful, the receipt of your letter was a matter of joy for me.
('59', 265, 14, 20, 472048) I have no doubt whatsoever that in the quiet of the village surroundings you will soon recover your lost health and repair your broken spirits.
('59', 265, 14, 21, 472192) You are not an old man but being a man of emotion and possessing a sensitive nature, you imagine all sorts of evil.
('59', 265, 14, 22, 472308) You have many years of active.
('59', 265, 14, 23, 472339) life and service in front of you.
('59', 265, 14, 24, 472373) Many people have gone through much more distress of the body than you have and yet I see them today in possession of sound health and bright spirits.
('59', 265, 14, 25, 472523) Mens sana in corpore sano you learnt in your youth and as soon as the body becomes healthy, the mind is bound to react.
('59', 265, 14, 26, 472643) Meanwhile therefore your first and the last care is to regain your health and not to worry about the future of the family, the country or the world.
('59', 265, 14, 27, 472792) You cannot be the architect of any of these but you can contribute your own share to the advancement of all the three.

('59', 266, 1, 2, 473188) happening around you.
('59', 266, 1, 3, 473210) That must be a sealed book to me except what I can gather through the papers that I am permitted to receive; nor, constituted as I am by nature, have I the slightest desire to know them.
('59', 266, 1, 4, 473397) A prisoner is civilly dead to the outside world, and that is right.
('59', 266, 1, 5, 473465) If he hankers after peeping into the forbidden land he is like the departed ghost which according to our belief misbehaves itself if it hankers after establishing communication with the world he was made by the Angel of Death to leave.
('59', 266, 1, 6, 473701) A prisoner who misbehaves like the ghost fails to establish real communication with the world he has left and in the vain pursuit loses the pleasure, such as it may be, which falls to the lot even of the prisoner.
('59', 266, 1, 7, 473915) Realizing this beautiful truth I have never misbehaved like the ghost.
('59', 266, 1, 8, 473986) I shall remember what you say about the spelling of your name.

('59', 266, 1, 10, 474148) You have now repaid him in his own coin and retort that he is a stickler, not you.
('59', 266, 1, 11, 474231) I have thrown the apple of discord between father and son.
('59', 266, 1, 12, 474290) You will now fight it out amongst yourselves.

('59', 272, 11, 18, 483082) 382. LETTER TO R. D. ATHAVALE
('59', 272, 12, 19, 483112) YERAVDA CENTRAL PRISON, February 14, 1933
('59', 272, 13, 20, 483154) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter of 11th instant.

('59', 272, 13, 23, 483389) It was understood that the amount collected at the meeting should be sent either to me or to you.
('59', 272, 13, 24, 483487) The amount collected in the tour was to be applied to khadi.” Your letter appears to be positive.
('59', 272, 13, 25, 483585) I myself have no recollection whatsoever but it is most unusual for me when I am touring for a specific purpose and with a responsible man like Sjt.
('59', 272, 13, 26, 483734) Gangadharrao Deshpande to leave any collections with anybody and that too without
('59', 273, 0, 1, 483816) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('59', 273, 1, 5, 483992) I must dissent from the proposition you have laid down that a person has no control over the monies entrusted by him to another for disposal even when the amount is unspent.
('59', 273, 1, 6, 484166) But the first thing to determine is what was actually intended by me when the money was left with you.
('59', 273, 1, 7, 484269) I take it that from now you will not make any use of the money till the matter is finally settled as to its control and disposal.

('59', 273, 5, 12, 484535) 383. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 273, 6, 13, 484570) February 14, 1933
('59', 273, 7, 14, 484588) I have most carefully read Dr. Ambedkar’s statement 1 for which I cannot conceal my sorrow, but I must also confess he has a perfect right to make a statement as he has done.
('59', 273, 7, 15, 484763) Harijans have laboured under grievous wrongs for ages, and Dr. Ambedkar and other educated Harijans are fully conscious of these wrongs.
('59', 273, 7, 16, 484900) The marvel to me is that they are not more bitter and more resentful than they are.
('59', 273, 7, 17, 484984) Having therefore excused their position, I cannot travel the same length that Dr. Ambedkar would have me do.
('59', 273, 7, 18, 485093) He has asked me a straight question, and is entitled to an equally straight answer from me.
('59', 273, 7, 19, 485185) I have described myself as a Harijan by adoption and in order to qualify myself for the privilege that it is to me, I have endeavoured to enter the very depths of their feelings.
('59', 273, 7, 20, 485364) I have lived with them, dined with them, and they have always claimed the first place in my thoughts and my prayers.
('59', 273, 7, 21, 485481) I have done so not to do any favour to them, but as a matter of religious duty.
('59', 273, 7, 22, 485561) I am a Hindu not merely because I was born in the Hindu fold,
('59', 273, 8, 23, 485623) 1 Vide “B. R. Ambedkar’s Statement”, 13 2 1933
('59', 274, 0, 1, 485670) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 275
('59', 274, 1, 2, 485715) but I am one by conviction and choice.
('59', 274, 1, 3, 485754) As I know it and interpret it, it gives me all the solace I need, both here and hereafter.
('59', 274, 1, 4, 485845) It solves for me many riddles of life.
('59', 274, 1, 5, 485884) But it also contains, as it is practised today, the big blot of untouchability in the sense in which it is understood today, that is, distinction between man and man, one occupying the topmost rung of the ladder and another the lowest.
('59', 274, 1, 6, 486120) If this doctrine of utmost superiority and utmost inferiority, descending from father to son for eternity, is an integral part of Hinduism without the slightest prospect of a change, then I no more want to belong to it than does Dr. Ambedkar.
('59', 274, 1, 7, 486363) But I am convinced that this doctrine of eternal damnation is a thing utterly foreign to the spirit of Hinduism and the Shastras as I have understood them.
('59', 274, 1, 8, 486519) There is no superiority or inferiority in the Hinduism of my conception.
('59', 274, 1, 9, 486592) Therefore I should go the whole length with Dr. Ambedkar in fighting the arrogation of superiority on the part of any individual or class over any other.
('59', 274, 1, 10, 486746) My fight against untouchability is a fight against this horrid doctrine.
('59', 274, 1, 11, 486819) If untouchability goes from the heart of Hindus, superiority and inferiority are also gone.
('59', 274, 1, 12, 486911) But when Dr. Ambedkar wants to fight varnashrama itself I cannot be in his camp, because I believe varnashrama to be an integral part of Hinduism.
('59', 274, 1, 13, 487058) It is quite evident that the varnashrama of Dr. Ambedkar’s conception is being practised today, but that is not my conception of varnashrama.
('59', 274, 1, 14, 487200) In my opinion, at present both varnadharma and ashramadharma are in abeyance, and if I were asked what varna is in operation at present, I would say Shudra varna, not because it is the lowest, but because it is the only thing that remains, for the divine knowledge, the power behind it and wealth for the support of this knowledge and power are gone.
('59', 274, 1, 15, 487551) Knowledge, power and wealth there certainly are in a way.
('59', 274, 1, 16, 487609) But in the religious conception of varnadharma, these three have to be used not for personal ends, but for spiritual and social advance.
('59', 274, 1, 17, 487746) The only thing that remains open for all today is service, also included in the scheme of varnashramadharma, for a spiritual end.
('59', 274, 1, 18, 487876) Out of that spirit of service, it is possible to revive spiritual knowledge, the power to defend it and the wealth to sustain both.
('59', 274, 1, 19, 488008) Then, those who are in possession of that knowledge, and will use it for society will be Brahmins, those who use that power for the benefit of society will be Kshatriyas, and those who gain wealth and use wealth, also for society, are Vaishyas.
('59', 274, 1, 20, 488253) They will all depend for their very existence on Shudras, the embodiments of real service.
('59', 274, 1, 21, 488344) For me that is true varnashrama, and there is no question
('59', 275, 0, 1, 488402) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 275, 1, 2, 488444) of superiority or inferiority in this conception.
('59', 275, 1, 3, 488494) The Shudra is as necessary for society as the Brahmin.
('59', 275, 1, 4, 488549) Each will have, more or less, all the qualities and privileges of the rest, but people belonging to particular varnas will perform the special service assigned to them.
('59', 275, 1, 5, 488718) There is then, in this conception, no question of privilege, but only duty and service.
('59', 275, 1, 6, 488806) I invite Dr. Ambedkar to shed his bitterness and anger and try to learn the beauties of the faith of his forefathers.
('59', 275, 1, 7, 488924) Let him curse the caste Hindus as much as he likes but let him not curse Hinduism without making an unbiassed study of it, and if it fails to sustain him in the hour of need, by all means let him forsake it.
('59', 275, 1, 8, 489132) Coming to the question of temple entry, I entirely agree with him that Harijans cannot be and must not be beggars for it.
('59', 275, 1, 9, 489254) It is for the caste Hindus to open temples whole heartedly or not at all.
('59', 275, 1, 10, 489328) I would repeat that the opening of temples is one of the duties that caste Hindus owe to Harijans.
('59', 275, 1, 11, 489427) I hope Dr. Ambedkar’s statement is not intended to convey the meaning that Harijans do not feel the deprivation of the right to temple entry, for I know from personal knowledge that for thousands of them, it is a serious deprivation.
('59', 275, 1, 12, 489661) The betterment of their economic and educational conditions is undoubtedly required.
('59', 275, 1, 13, 489746) But no betterment of those conditions will give religious equality.
('59', 275, 1, 14, 489814) That can be attained only by admission into temples and all the religious consolation to which caste Hindus are today entitled.
('59', 275, 1, 15, 489942) This religious equality cannot be attained even by statute, but only when the heart of the caste Hindus is changed.
('59', 275, 1, 16, 490058) The Bills before the Assembly are not intended to force open the temples to Harijans, but only to make it possible for the caste Hindus to throw them open when the hearts of the majority are changed.
('59', 275, 1, 17, 490258) Dr. Ambedkar has confined himself to the criticism of the second Bill (Temple entry Bill on the model of Dr. Subbaroyan’s Bill).
('59', 275, 1, 18, 490387) In my opinion, this Bill is designed to test caste Hindu feelings.
('59', 275, 1, 19, 490454) When the hearts of the majority are changed, temples would be thrown open.
('59', 275, 1, 20, 490529) Surely, Dr. Ambedkar does not want forcible opening of temples.
('59', 275, 1, 21, 490593) I do not, for one moment, hold the opinion, which he does, that the majority of caste Hindus today are not prepared to open temples to Harijans.

('59', 275, 1, 23, 490886) The referendum in Madura too, recently published, points in the same direction.
('59', 275, 1, 24, 490966) There will be time
('59', 276, 0, 1, 490985) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 277
('59', 276, 1, 2, 491030) enough to show dissatisfaction and disappointment when caste Hindus had been given an opportunity of expressing their opinion.
('59', 276, 1, 3, 491157) Dr. Ambedkar, I observe, has remained silent about the first Bill (Untouchability Bill).

('59', 276, 3, 7, 491565) 384. LETTER TO M. G. BHANDARI
('59', 276, 4, 8, 491595) February 15, 1933
('59', 276, 5, 9, 491613) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI, There are two matters that I have discussed with you, with which you have told me you have no authority to deal.
('59', 276, 5, 10, 491747) The first matter relates to the supply of newspapers to me in terms of the orders of the Government of India, giving me special facilities about untouchability propaganda.
('59', 276, 5, 11, 491919) Somehow or other hitherto I have managed to cope with my work in spite of restrictions that you have been exercising about newspapers addressed to me.
('59', 276, 5, 12, 492070) I have already drawn your attention to very important matters escaping my notice owing to the non delivery of these papers.
('59', 276, 5, 13, 492194) However careful your staff may be, they cannot always be sure of having all the cuttings relating to untouchability in the papers received.
('59', 276, 5, 14, 492334) Some papers such as Dr. Ambedkar’s I have to look through fully and carefully.
('59', 276, 5, 15, 492413) So far as I read the Government of India orders they contemplate no restrictions on the prompt receipt by me of correspondence and newspapers.
('59', 276, 5, 16, 492556) It is obvious that I cannot carry on propaganda if I do not get such things in proper time.
('59', 276, 5, 17, 492648) I therefore ask that all the newspapers received for me and which do not come under the heading of “prohibited literature” should be delivered to me as they arrive.
('59', 276, 5, 18, 492813) Of course they may be taken away from me as soon as I have used them.
('59', 276, 5, 19, 492883) I need hardly repeat the assurance that I have no use for them save for the one purpose to which all my energy and attention are being exclusively directed.
('59', 276, 5, 20, 493040) I shall therefore thank you to obtain necessary and early instructions in the matter.
('59', 276, 5, 21, 493126) The second matter is about the new weekly Harijan which is being published in Poona in the interest of the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 276, 5, 22, 493267) Its policy is naturally being controlled by me
('59', 277, 0, 1, 493314) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 277, 1, 2, 493356) as it has been published at my instance.
('59', 277, 1, 3, 493397) It has therefore to deal exclusively with questions relating to untouchability only and therefore it is a purely socio religious weekly.
('59', 277, 1, 4, 493534) I ask you whether copies could be sent to my associates and fellow prisoners whether belonging to ‘B’ class or ‘C’ class.
('59', 277, 1, 5, 493656) I would thank you if you will kindly ask for Government’s instructions on my request.
('59', 277, 1, 6, 493742) I may draw the attention of the Government to the fact that in 1922 when I was admitted into this Prison as a convicted prisoner and when in all other matters except food and sanitary conveniences I had no facilities given to me except what were permitted to other prisoners, there never was any difficulty about my getting newspapers of a purely socio religious character.
('59', 277, 1, 7, 494116) I hope, therefore, there will be none this time about the giving of Harijan to my friends, the fellow prisoners.

('59', 284, 2, 3, 506198) February 16, 1933
('59', 284, 3, 4, 506216) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('59', 284, 3, 5, 506249) I endeavoured to send you as full a reply as the time at my disposal would permit me to send.
('59', 284, 4, 6, 506343) I entirely endorse your suggestion that just as others learn from the Gods and the scriptures what they want to, so must I. Some people learn only by making blunders.
('59', 284, 4, 7, 506510) I have often found myself doing so, but I don’t regret for the simple reason that at the time I made the blunders I was wholly unconscious of them.
('59', 284, 4, 8, 506658) I try to be cautious, but however cautious I may be, unless I become a perfect man, I cannot become proof against unconscious errors.
('59', 284, 4, 9, 506792) But so long as I retain the capacity to own them frankly and fully as soon as I become conscious, it is well with me and well even with those who may be affected by my errors.
('59', 284, 4, 10, 506968) If by fear of blunder I hesitated to act at all I should never succeed in reaching truth.
('59', 284, 5, 11, 507058) I must persist in saying that the Bills before the Assembly are in no way intended to compel anybody to act contrary to his conscience.
('59', 284, 5, 12, 507194) I quite see your own viewpoint.
('59', 284, 5, 13, 507226) It is my misfortune that I cannot make you see mine.
('59', 284, 5, 14, 507279) I can therefore only ask you to be patient with me.

('59', 285, 10, 15, 508199) 398. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 285, 11, 16, 508234) February 16, 1933
('59', 285, 12, 17, 508252) Commenting on the statement in the News Chronicle that untouchability is an
('59', 285, 13, 18, 508328) evil extraordinarily difficult to uproot by legislation alone, Mr. Gandhi said: I am not surprised at the ignorance betrayed by the writer in the News Chronicle when we have in India itself obstinate refusal on the part of many people to see that there is nothing at all in the two Bills in the shape of compulsion.
('59', 285, 13, 19, 508644) I could understand the difficulty, if there was a measure to abolish untouchability by law.
('59', 285, 13, 20, 508736) Again, the writer asks whether the Government ought to regard the abolition of untouchability as a duty imposed on it by consider ations of humanity such as compelled it to abolish suttee.
('59', 285, 13, 21, 508925) Surely, a comparison between the Suttee Suppression Law and the present Bills is most misleading.
('59', 285, 13, 22, 509023) The practice of suttee is a penal offence, whereas the present Bill merely withholds legal recognition from untoucha bility.
('59', 285, 13, 23, 509148) In my opinion, the Government is morally bound to help the reformers to adopt reforms wherever public opinion is ripe for it.
('59', 285, 14, 24, 509274) 1 The addressee had welcomed the opportunity of going to the Ashram provided it was treated by both as an experiment, with no pledge as to the future on either side.
('59', 285, 14, 25, 509440) 2 Vide “Interview to Associated Press”, 14 2 1933
('59', 286, 0, 1, 509490) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 287
('59', 286, 1, 2, 509535) British journalists should recognize the correctness of the reformers’ position.
('59', 286, 1, 3, 509616) They do not seek to bring about reforms by compulsion.
('59', 286, 1, 4, 509671) Not to pass these measures will be a block on the progress of reform, which is being prosecuted by reformers against heavy odds.
('59', 286, 2, 5, 509800) Asked if he was doing anything to persuade the members of the Assembly to facilitate the passage of the Bills, Mr. Gandhi said that he had adopted the most effective step in sending Mr. Rajagopalachariar there to present his case and seek the assistance of every member, Hindu members for supporting the Bills, and non Hindus for facilitating consideration of the Bills in this session itself.

('59', 286, 12, 26, 511166) 1 Vide the following item.
('59', 287, 0, 1, 511193) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 287, 1, 2, 511235) Thursday.
('59', 287, 1, 3, 511245) Hence though I must write on other days as well for Harijan, I must devote Wednesdays and Thursdays entirely to it.
('59', 287, 1, 4, 511361) This is almost as before.
('59', 287, 1, 5, 511387) The extra note that I thought I might have to write I did not and could not have written with but extraordinary effort.
('59', 287, 1, 6, 511507) I gather from your letter that you are not locked for the night.
('59', 287, 1, 7, 511572) You must take the fullest advantage of that liberty.
('59', 287, 1, 8, 511625) The best food you want is the freshest air all day and all night.
('59', 287, 1, 9, 511691) Therefore you should work outdoor during the day, if, as I learn, you have many neem trees in your yard.
('59', 287, 1, 10, 511796) You should sleep all night directly under the sky—not even the shade of the trees—dew or no dew.
('59', 287, 1, 11, 511893) The most direct contact with the stars is absolutely essential.
('59', 287, 1, 12, 511957) Dew causes no mischief so long as you are well covered from toe to neck and the head also if necessary and so long as your lips are tightly closed and you are sure that you are breathing only through the nose—to ensure this at the time of retiring you should take a few deep breaths through the nose whilst you are lying flat on your back with legs fully stretched.
('59', 287, 1, 13, 512323) You should set apart certain fixed time, say, five minutes each time for taking these breaths.
('59', 287, 1, 14, 512418) Then you will acquire the habit of always breathing through the nose.
('59', 287, 1, 15, 512488) Those who, without practice, think that they naturally breathe through the nose, are not always right.
('59', 287, 1, 16, 512591) They do not know when they breathe through the mouth.
('59', 287, 1, 17, 512645) Unfortunately in the majority of cases correct breathing is an acquired habit.
('59', 287, 1, 18, 512724) Tuberculosis is an impossibility with one who takes freshest air, drinks pure water, eats properly the proper quantity of the proper food and has proper exercise.
('59', 287, 1, 19, 512887) I have thanked the Government for removing you from Arthur Road.
('59', 287, 1, 20, 512952) They have done it promptly and well.
('59', 287, 1, 21, 512989) It is true that I had definitely asked for transfer to Yeravda.
('59', 287, 1, 22, 513053) But they must have their good reasons for not transferring you there.
('59', 287, 1, 23, 513123) Sabarmati is undoubtedly the next best, knowing you as I do—Sabarmati should be the best if you realized that though my body dwells in Yeravda, my spirit is to be found in Sabarmati.
('59', 287, 1, 24, 513306) The body without the spirit is like the Taj without Shahjehan a tomb!
('59', 287, 1, 25, 513376) You should have reported all about the glands to the Surgeon at Arthur Road.
('59', 287, 1, 26, 513453) We may not ask for transfers but we are bound to report our condition.
('59', 287, 1, 27, 513524) For the authorities hold our bodies in the expectation that we shall report all about their condition to them.
('59', 287, 1, 28, 513635) If we do not, we commit at least a technical, if not a full breach, of prison discipline.

('59', 297, 1, 2, 526780) 417. AN APPEAL TO M. L. A.S
('59', 297, 2, 3, 526808) A valued friend suggests 1 that I should send personal letters to the members of the Assembly bespeaking their support to the consideration, during the current session, of Sjt.
('59', 297, 2, 4, 526985) Ranga Iyer’s two Bills on untouchability.
('59', 297, 2, 5, 527027) I hope there is no false pride in me.
('59', 297, 2, 6, 527065) Having made up my mind, or, as critics would say, deceived myself into the belief, that in spite of my non co operation there was nothing wrong in asking the members to do what was right, I would not hesitate, if I was free, to go to them personally and show to them why it was necessary for all the members to allow the Bills to be considered without delay and for the Hindu members to back them for the sake of the purity of their religion.
('59', 297, 2, 7, 527508) But I am not free and I have found in Sjt.
('59', 297, 2, 8, 527551) C. Rajagopalachariar a better lobbyist than myself and perhaps better also at the art of wooing obstinate members.
('59', 297, 2, 9, 527666) He is, therefore, in Delhi as my duly authorized agent to plead my cause.
('59', 297, 2, 10, 527740) The public know what confidence I have in him as an exponent of and believer in whatever philosophy there may be in me.
('59', 297, 2, 11, 527860) Therefore, it would be superfluous, and if it was any other agent, even discourteous to him, if I was to write directly to the members who, I hope, will regard Rajagopalachari’s appeal to them as much more than a letter to them individually.
('59', 297, 3, 12, 528102) Harijan, 18 2 1933

('59', 298, 3, 8, 529298) 419. WORK IN CALCUTTA BASTIS
('59', 298, 4, 9, 529327) Vasantlal Morarka writes from Calcutta:
('59', 298, 5, 10, 529367) We have already commenced to do work amongst the Harijans.
('59', 298, 5, 11, 529426) We have taken charge of 20 night and day schools in the bastis.
('59', 298, 5, 12, 529490) Nearly 500 boys and
('59', 298, 6, 13, 529510) girls are receiving instruction in these schools, and we are tackling the problem of having water pipes laid, sanitary conveniences supplied and of carrying on propaganda for the eradication of the drink evil and other evil habits.
('59', 298, 6, 14, 529742) Moreover, we had a meeting and sports organized under the chairmanship of Shrimati Saruprani Nehru.
('59', 298, 6, 15, 529842) Marwadi, Harijan and other boys freely mixed together.
('59', 298, 6, 16, 529897) Men and women also did likewise.
('59', 298, 6, 17, 529930) There was absence of all artificiality about this gathering.
('59', 298, 6, 18, 529991) Nevertheless, I must confess to you that the work in the bastis is very difficult.
('59', 298, 6, 19, 530074) I know what the work in the bastis is like.
('59', 298, 6, 20, 530118) Satis Chandra Das Gupta of Khadi Pratishthan has already described to me in graphic and heart rending terms the condition of the Harijans living in the bastis.
('59', 298, 6, 21, 530278) These difficulties may not daunt workers.
('59', 298, 6, 22, 530320) If removal of untouchability was an easy job, we would have achieved it long ago.
('59', 298, 6, 23, 530402) It is only now that we are having a foretaste of these difficulties.
('59', 298, 6, 24, 530471) But patience and perseverance will overcome even an Everest of them.
('59', 298, 7, 25, 530540) Harijan, 18 2 1933
('59', 298, 8, 26, 530559) 420. IS THIS BROTHERLINESS?
('59', 298, 9, 27, 530587) As sanatanists persist in their statement that untouchability, as we know it, is not a blot upon Hinduism and that Harijans are well treated and are a happy and contented lot, and as I know that some of them, if not many, honestly believe in that statement, it becomes necessary to demonstrate the fallacy of that belief and show that the treatment actually received by Harijans cannot possibly be worse.
('59', 298, 9, 28, 530992) Such demonstration will also give the reformer an idea of the work that is in front of him.
('59', 298, 9, 29, 531084) Even when sanatanists and reformers join hands, as they
('59', 299, 0, 1, 531140) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 299, 1, 2, 531182) undoubtedly will one day, there will be work enough and to spare for several thousand volunteers.
('59', 299, 1, 3, 531280) Though I have written and I shall continue to write with vigour about the necessity of admission of Harijans to temples, I have never given and shall never give a back seat to the constructive work.
('59', 299, 1, 4, 531479) But what I am certain about is that admission of Harijans to temples will automatically quadruple the pace of constructive reform.
('59', 299, 1, 5, 531610) Here is, then, a free translation of a letter from a Gujarati worker among Harijans in parts of Gujarat near Ahmedabad: Harijans suffer great hardships from the so called higher classes.
('59', 299, 1, 6, 531797) In some villages they are not allowed to build verandahs for their houses.
('59', 299, 1, 7, 531872) They may not build houses with an upper storey.
('59', 299, 1, 8, 531920) They may not wear decent clothing, nor ride horses.
('59', 299, 1, 9, 531972) There can, therefore, be no question in these villages of Harijan children receiving any education or having a decent recreation ground.
('59', 299, 1, 10, 532109) The high class people will not even tolerate any discussion about reform.
('59', 299, 1, 11, 532183) The Harijans cannot take advantage of the Government instructions that they should have access to public places on the same terms as other Hindus.
('59', 299, 1, 12, 532330) And now there have sprung among them false sadhus and bavas 1 who under all kinds of pretences cheat them.
('59', 299, 1, 13, 532437) Then, there is the vicious habit they have copied from higher classes of having infant marriages and incurring expenses in connection with these marriages.
('59', 299, 1, 14, 532593) They do not hesitate to pay 30% interest on two or three hundred rupees that they must spend on the marriage of their children, and it often happens that these little children die before they come of age and so the whole of the expense becomes a complete waste.
('59', 299, 1, 15, 532855) These customs have resulted in a perpetuity of debts which continue to increase without the prospect of ever being discharged.
('59', 299, 1, 16, 532982) And, of course, they have untouchability amongst themselves.
('59', 299, 1, 17, 533043) The result is that those who are considered the lowest have to exist on what dirty water they can collect from anywhere.
('59', 299, 1, 18, 533164) This is from one of the latest letters.
('59', 299, 1, 19, 533204) The following is taken from a letter received by Sjt.
('59', 299, 1, 20, 533258) Amritlal Thakkar from one Mr. Simon, M. A., who is a missionary for Children’s Special Service in the West Godavari District.
('59', 299, 1, 21, 533384) 2 He writes from Narsapur and says:
('59', 299, 2, 22, 533420) 1 Mendicants 2 Vide “Letter to Amritlal V. Thakkar”, 15 2 1933
('59', 300, 0, 1, 533483) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 301
('59', 300, 1, 2, 533528) The principal untouchables are Malas and Madigas who live on the outskirts of the main village, far from the habitations of the caste Hindus, and are the worst untouchables in the sense that they live in an appalling environment of dirt and squalour.
('59', 300, 1, 3, 533779) The boys and girls live in huts under the most insanitary conditions and are ragged and dirty, as they have never understood or experienced the joy of being clean.
('59', 300, 1, 4, 533943) Their parents themselves are careless of the cleanliness and the education of their children, not to say of their morality.
('59', 300, 2, 5, 534067) I believe that such a condition is due to their poverty on the one hand, and the dirt to which they have become habituated from ages.
('59', 300, 2, 6, 534201) The Malapalem and the Madiga gudem are on the borders of the caste Hindus’ village, hemmed in, on all sides, by the encroachments of the paddy field owners.
('59', 300, 2, 7, 534358) The Malas are a coolie class employed only for field work and the Madigas are shoemakers.
('59', 300, 2, 8, 534448) The latter class eat the meat of dead animals.
('59', 300, 2, 9, 534495) So, they live outside the pale of decent society, caged like wild animals, treated worse than the most uncared for village dogs.
('59', 300, 2, 10, 534624) It is not possible for me to reject any of these two pieces of evidence as exaggerated, because I have been an eye witness to such things in other places.
('59', 300, 2, 11, 534779) Nor am I disposed to underrate Mr. Simon’s evidence because of his being a foreigner, for the simple reason that his letter has been written for the sake of doing some service through the Servants of Untouchables Society and, therefore, incurs the risk of being utterly discredited if he made an exaggerated report.
('59', 300, 2, 12, 535095) Even from the most selfish point of view, it can be shown that this criminal neglect of the manpower of the country is an economic waste which can never be exaggerated.
('59', 300, 2, 13, 535264) The same people, if they were made honourable and equal members of Hindu society, will add to the material and moral resources of the country to an extent it is difficult to conceive.
('59', 300, 2, 14, 535448) At the present moment they are a burden upon society.
('59', 300, 2, 15, 535502) For, they discredit Hinduism, and the depression of 40 million human beings cannot but drag down the other 260 millions with them.
('59', 300, 3, 16, 535633) Harijan, 18 2 1933

('59', 300, 5, 18, 535678) I observe that Sjt.
('59', 300, 5, 19, 535698) C. Rajagopalachariar and Sheth Ghanshyamdas Birla have, in a statement issued by them, referred to the possibility of another fast by me.

('59', 301, 1, 2, 535989) doing likewise without my knowing it.

('59', 301, 1, 4, 536114) And hereby I warn all friends against copying their example.
('59', 301, 1, 5, 536175) Such exploitation robs a spiritual act of all its value.
('59', 301, 1, 6, 536232) The dreaded event may never come to pass.
('59', 301, 1, 7, 536274) All I know is that there is, so far as I am aware, no present possibility of its coming.
('59', 301, 1, 8, 536363) Pandit Malaviyaji, whom I regard as an elder brother, has sent me a loving message of which the following is the substance: You are in a hurry.
('59', 301, 1, 9, 536507) You must go slow.
('59', 301, 1, 10, 536525) Take care that pride of tapasya does not corrupt you.
('59', 301, 1, 11, 536579) Tapasya without humility is of no avail and may even be harmful.
('59', 301, 1, 12, 536644) There should be no more fasting.
('59', 301, 1, 13, 536677) I prize this warning.
('59', 301, 1, 14, 536699) I know that pride of merit damages a soul like a heinous sin.
('59', 301, 1, 15, 536761) I hope I am not consciously proud.
('59', 301, 1, 16, 536796) What I am, unconsciously and in spite of myself, God only knows fully and, to some extent, those who surround me.
('59', 301, 1, 17, 536910) I am not impatient with anyone.
('59', 301, 1, 18, 536942) I am, however, impatient of untouchability.
('59', 301, 1, 19, 536986) But I know that its destruction is no one man’s work.
('59', 301, 1, 20, 537040) God has suffered the evil to exist all these long years and He will remove it in His own good time.
('59', 301, 1, 21, 537140) Nevertheless, He expects all Hindus to do their duty.
('59', 301, 1, 22, 537194) Suffering even unto death and, therefore, even through a perpetual fast is the last weapon of a satyagrahi.
('59', 301, 1, 23, 537302) That is the last duty which it is open to him to perform.
('59', 301, 1, 24, 537360) Therefore, fast is a part of my being as, I hold, it has been, to a large or small extent, of every seeker of Truth.
('59', 301, 1, 25, 537477) I am making an experiment in ahimsa on a scale perhaps unknown in history.
('59', 301, 1, 26, 537552) That I may be wholly wrong is quite possible, but quite irrelevant to the present purpose.
('59', 301, 1, 27, 537643) So long as I am not conscious of the error, but, on the contrary, am sure, as far as it is humanly possible to be, of being in the right, I must go on with my pursuit to the farthest end.
('59', 301, 1, 28, 537831) And in this manner, but in no other, a fast or a series of fasts are always a possibility in my life.
('59', 301, 1, 29, 537933) I have undergone many before now since childhood.
('59', 301, 1, 30, 537983) There should be no alarm felt if they are undertaken for public causes.
('59', 301, 1, 31, 538055) Nor must anyone exploit them in anticipation.
('59', 301, 1, 32, 538101) When they come, they will produce their own effect and result, whether any body wills or no.
('59', 301, 1, 33, 538194) But it is wrong to speculate over the contingency.
('59', 301, 1, 34, 538245) I, therefore, implore the public to dismiss from their minds, and be unaffected by, the remote possibility of another fast by me in this

('59', 302, 3, 5, 538717) 422. AGREEING TO DIFFER
('59', 302, 4, 6, 538741) There are some whose friendship and co operation I prize beyond measure.
('59', 302, 4, 7, 538814) One of such men is Pandit Malaviyaji, whom from the time that we first met I have recognized as an elder brother.
('59', 302, 4, 8, 538928) Nevertheless, it has been often my misfortune to disagree with him.
('59', 302, 4, 9, 538996) Our disagreement, however, has never in the slightest degree dimi nished our mutual affection.
('59', 302, 4, 10, 539091) The correspondence published below 1 will show the reader how we have again found it necessary to differ.
('59', 302, 4, 11, 539197) Conscience is a hard taskmaster.
('59', 302, 4, 12, 539230) I do not propose to deal with all the points covered in the correspondence.
('59', 302, 4, 13, 539306) I would confine myself to the vital matter referred to in it, viz., the interpretation of the Bombay Resolutions.
('59', 302, 4, 14, 539420) In my opinion, with all the deference that I owe to Malaviyaji, I feel that the Bombay Resolution 2 which I give below has only one meaning.
('59', 302, 4, 15, 539561) Under it, responsible Hindus are bound to give to the Harijans through law that which only law can give.
('59', 302, 4, 16, 539666) This they are bound to do now, if at all possible, and wait for the swaraj Parliament only if the legal relief becomes an impossibility now.
('59', 302, 4, 17, 539807) It cannot be considered an imposs ibility till all effort humanly possible has been made.
('59', 302, 4, 18, 539897) My duty and that of the Hindus who accept my interpretation is quite clear.
('59', 302, 4, 19, 539973) We must ask all the members of the Assembly, and especially the Hindu members, to help us to fulfil the pledge given, not merely to Dr. Ambedkar and cultured Harijans like him, but to the dumb and suffering forty millions whom they seek to represent, and whom it should be the duty and privilege of every caste Hindu to represent equally with the leaders of the Harijans.

('59', 303, 1, 2, 540679) the hundredth time that there is a legal bar against temple entry which cannot be removed by any agreement on the part of all the Hindus combined.
('59', 303, 1, 3, 540826) A legal bar can only be removed by a legislative act.
('59', 303, 1, 4, 540880) What an agreement amongst Hindus can do is to move the Government to give effect to it as was done in connection with the political part of the Yeravda Pact.
('59', 303, 1, 5, 541038) Those caste Hindus who strained themselves to ensure recognition of the political part of the Yeravda Pact are now doubly bound to give effect to the other resolutions which were the direct and natural consequence of the Yeravda Pact; and since in the course of complying with those resolutions it has been discovered that there is a legal difficulty which was not foreseen then, that difficulty has got to be removed at the earliest possible moment.
('59', 303, 1, 6, 541489) Hence the two Bills.
('59', 303, 1, 7, 541510) But, says Malaviyaji, temple entry, the opening of wells, etc., had to be done by persuasion, not by compulsion.
('59', 303, 1, 8, 541623) I quite agree, but to remove a legal bar is not to do the desired thing by compulsion.
('59', 303, 1, 9, 541710) There is the Madura temple.
('59', 303, 1, 10, 541738) If I am correctly informed, the trustees of that temple are elected by the Hindu voters.
('59', 303, 1, 11, 541827) They are pledged to open the temple.
('59', 303, 1, 12, 541864) By an overwhelming majority, the Hindu voters have desired the opening of the temple.
('59', 303, 1, 13, 541950) But, because of the legal bar, the trustees cannot open the temple to the Harijans.
('59', 303, 1, 14, 542034) Will it be compulsion to have that legal bar removed by law?
('59', 303, 1, 15, 542095) I can cite several other instances where willing trustees of public temples are powerless to give effect to the public demand and their own wishes.
('59', 303, 1, 16, 542243) I venture, therefore, to think that there is no escape from permissive and corrective legislation.
('59', 303, 1, 17, 542342) If the Bills are defective, the defect can be remedied.
('59', 303, 1, 18, 542398) I have submitted the Bills to two eminent lawyers for their opinion.
('59', 303, 1, 19, 542467) Jayakar’s the public will learn from another column of this issue of Harijan.

('59', 303, 1, 21, 542802) Dr. Sapru sees no compulsion in it.
('59', 303, 1, 22, 542838) I have invited him to examine the first Bill also.
('59', 303, 1, 23, 542889) Every legitimate difficulty can be easily met if the principle of securing immediate relief from the legal obstacle is admitted.
('59', 303, 1, 24, 543018) Therefore, in my opinion, the way before the reformer is quite clear.
('59', 303, 1, 25, 543088) He must invite the Government to facilitate consideration of the Bills

('59', 305, 1, 2, 545645) do the correct thing.
('59', 305, 1, 3, 545667) The more that he wants is complete destruction of varnashramadharma of his imagination.
('59', 305, 1, 4, 545755) Varnashrama to him means the essence of superiority and inferiority.
('59', 305, 1, 5, 545824) I admit that today varnashrama does mean that, if it also means much more, but the evil of high and low ness is represented by untouchability.
('59', 305, 1, 6, 545967) When, therefore, the latter is demolished, varnashrama will be purged of the very thing for which Dr. Ambedkar abhors it.
('59', 305, 1, 7, 546089) Varnashrama of my conception is a wholly different thing.
('59', 305, 1, 8, 546147) It exists only in name today.
('59', 305, 1, 9, 546177) Let the reader, therefore, be not led astray from the main purpose.
('59', 305, 1, 10, 546245) It will be time enough to look after varnashrama when the doctrine of high and low is demolished.
('59', 305, 1, 11, 546343) It is necessary, too, not to be disturbed over my definition of varnashrama.
('59', 305, 1, 12, 546420) I am aware that it will shock sanatanist friends, but they will permit me to act according to my reading of the Shastras and the whole spirit of Hinduism.
('59', 305, 1, 13, 546575) The letters that I receive from sanatanists do not tell me that they believe in the doctrine of high and low.
('59', 305, 1, 14, 546685) On the contrary, they protest against my statement that caste Hindus have regarded Harijans as inferiors, always to be kept at a distance.
('59', 305, 1, 15, 546824) Therefore, they should join hands in purging Hinduism of the doctrine of inequality of status, irrespective of their conception of varnashrama.
('59', 305, 1, 16, 546968) After all, only that conception which the masses accept will hold the field.
('59', 305, 1, 17, 547045) The scope of the present campaign against untouchability is strictly limited.
('59', 305, 1, 18, 547123) It will be a great pity to befog the public mind by raising before it the cry of ‘Varnashrama in danger’.
('59', 305, 1, 19, 547229) I am convinced that it is more in danger from those who will be blind to what is going on in Hinduism today than from Dr. Ambedkar who courageouly says: ‘I shall have nothing to do with varnashrama that would keep me and mine for ever at the bottom of the social scale.’ If we would find room for such as him in Hinduism, let us show him by our acts that varnashrama is not a vertical line but that it is a horizontal plane on which all the children of God occupy absolutely the same status, though they may be engaged in different pursuits of life and though they may have different qualities and different tastes.
('59', 305, 2, 20, 547845) Harijan, 18 2 1933
('59', 305, 3, 21, 547864) 1 For a discussion on varnashramadharma, vide “Talk with Mathuradas”, 18 2 1933
('59', 306, 0, 1, 547944) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 307

('59', 307, 1, 2, 550131) 425. LETTER TO LOKANATH MISRA February 18, 1933
('59', 307, 2, 3, 550179) DEAR FRIEND, I have your very touching letter, but you must not be bewildered nor be pained.
('59', 307, 2, 4, 550272) My reply was in Gujarati, but the translation you have read is fairly correct.
('59', 307, 2, 5, 550351) What I have said 1 in answer to the questions put by the ex Dewan of Morvi I have said repeatedly in my writings.
('59', 307, 2, 6, 550465) It could not have escaped you if you had followed my writings carefully.
('59', 307, 2, 7, 550538) Nor is it inconsistent with the law of heredity.
('59', 307, 2, 8, 550587) The law cannot be changed but if we know the law we will suit our actions in accordance with it and that is precisely what my answer means.
('59', 307, 2, 9, 550727) Essential qualities are transmitted from father to son.
('59', 307, 2, 10, 550783) If parties having like qualities marry, they carry out the law of heredity and therefore also the law of varna.
('59', 307, 2, 11, 550895) Such marriages have taken place in Hindu society ever since the establishment of varnashrama.
('59', 307, 2, 12, 550989) This ought to give you satisfaction.
('59', 307, 2, 13, 551026) You do not expect me to give you a detailed reply to the conundrums you have raised.
('59', 307, 2, 14, 551111) You will believe me when I tell you that I have not even the time for doing it.
('59', 307, 2, 15, 551191) If you will carefully follow the pages of Harijan, all your doubts will be solved But if they are not, you should dismiss me from your consideration.
('59', 307, 2, 16, 551341) The cause is far superior to me.
('59', 307, 2, 17, 551374) You and I live for the cause and work for it.
('59', 307, 2, 18, 551420) If I err in the common prosecution of the common cause, you will leave me and march forward towards the goal.
('59', 307, 2, 19, 551530) The limits of untouchability work are well defined.
('59', 307, 2, 20, 551582) Never mind my views of extraneous matters, such as caste and varna, intermarriage and interdining.
('59', 307, 2, 21, 551681) I am not presenting my views on these matters for public acceptance at the present moment.
('59', 307, 2, 22, 551772) I give those views for the satisfaction of enquirers, for I would have my friends and the public to know me as I am and not picture me as something they fancy but has no likeness to me.
('59', 307, 2, 23, 551958) If even this does not give you satisfaction, you must find time to come to me and discuss the whole thing with me till you have full satisfaction.
('59', 307, 2, 24, 552105) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 307, 2, 25, 552127) LOKANATH MISRA, M. A., B. L. SECRETARY, ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY COMMITTEE PURI From a microfilm: S.N. 20284

('59', 310, 3, 4, 555583) DEAR FRIEND, I have before me your two letters dated 8th and 14th February respectively.
('59', 310, 3, 5, 555672) I would now ask you to cry a halt.
('59', 310, 3, 6, 555707) I esteem the great pains you are bestowing upon your compositions, but I must tell you that your arguments produce no effect on my mind.
('59', 310, 3, 7, 555844) Some of them I cannot follow at all.
('59', 310, 3, 8, 555881) Some of them are wholly irrelevant to the issue.
('59', 310, 3, 9, 555930) You often beg the question and equally often make assertions as if they were axioms.
('59', 310, 3, 10, 556015) In my opinion that is not the way in which you will drive the truth home to anybody.
('59', 310, 3, 11, 556100) I believe that I am very pervious to argument and that I have the capacity for seeing my critics’ standpoint.
('59', 310, 3, 12, 556210) You have prepossessed me in your favour by your courteous language and by your quietly accepting and acting up to my suggestion about the ornamentation of your letter paper.
('59', 310, 3, 13, 556384) I therefore approach your letter[s] with a desire to find substantial help from them, but you will excuse me for saying that I do not find any.
('59', 310, 3, 14, 556528) I would therefore now ask you to close this correspondence.
('59', 310, 3, 15, 556588) I would be guilty of discourtesy towards you if I left you under the impression that your argument was at all going home and that therefore you could continue your correspondence.
('59', 310, 4, 16, 556768) Yours sincerely

('59', 311, 0, 1, 557381) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 311, 1, 2, 557423) you cannot express the original by puniam.
('59', 311, 1, 3, 557466) Even the ‘n’ does not give the original sound.
('59', 311, 1, 4, 557513) There are five nasal sounds in Sanskrit.
('59', 311, 1, 5, 557554) ‘Narandas’ is quite enough.
('59', 311, 1, 6, 557582) But the bad habit of attaching ‘bhai’ or ‘ji’ has been the vogue and takes the place of ‘Mr.’.
('59', 311, 1, 7, 557677) Strangers would use only the other suffix.
('59', 311, 1, 8, 557720) But you may omit either, if you are older than Narandas.
('59', 311, 1, 9, 557777) If you are younger, ‘bhai’ becomes necessary as a member of the family.
('59', 311, 1, 10, 557849) Being daughter to me, you are as sister to Narandas and every other member in the Ashram.
('59', 311, 1, 11, 557939) ‘Bhai’ means brother as ‘behn’ means sister.
('59', 311, 1, 12, 557984) Here endeth the first lesson.
('59', 311, 1, 13, 558014) You must not be impatient with yourself, if you pick up new things slowly.
('59', 311, 1, 14, 558089) They will all become easy and natural by determined practice.
('59', 311, 1, 15, 558151) Love from us all.

('59', 316, 13, 23, 564610) February 19, 1933
('59', 316, 14, 24, 564628) KAKA, I got your letter.
('59', 316, 14, 25, 564653) If milk, when taken without any other food, is not digested, it does no harm, but the milk which seems to be digested with the help of other food is not really digested but mixes with the food, and remaining in the body in the form of poison, it harms the gums, etc.
('59', 316, 14, 26, 564920) This is the view held by more and more doctors and seems to be correct.
('59', 316, 14, 27, 564992) You can have with milk oranges, grapes, pineapples, pomegranates and other juicy fruits.
('59', 316, 14, 28, 565081) They will prevent milk from causing constipation.
('59', 316, 14, 29, 565131) You should, therefore, start the experiment of milk diet as soon as possible and accustom your body really to digest it.
('59', 316, 14, 30, 565252) I make no distinction between milk and curds.
('59', 316, 14, 31, 565298) Some doctors,
('59', 316, 15, 32, 565312) 1 Literally, ‘by the name of God’
('59', 317, 0, 1, 565346) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 317, 1, 2, 565388) probably most, believe that curds are more easily digested.
('59', 317, 1, 3, 565448) The curds should not taste sour at all—the curds which we used to make by adding drops of lemon juice to milk would be the best.
('59', 317, 1, 4, 565577) You should not drink the milk but sip it slowly.
('59', 317, 1, 5, 565626) It would be better to take a spoonful at a time.
('59', 317, 1, 6, 565675) To start with, you should take a quarter pound every hour.
('59', 317, 1, 7, 565734) Do not mind if you get diarrhoea.
('59', 317, 1, 8, 565768) It will stop in a few days.
('59', 317, 1, 9, 565796) You may drink the fruit juice separately at any convenient time.
('59', 317, 1, 10, 565861) In fruit juice, you should have the juice of six mosambis or of one pound of fresh grapes in two parts.
('59', 317, 1, 11, 565965) You should take about four pounds of milk or curds, and mix with it as much butter as may be necessary.
('59', 317, 1, 12, 566069) If you take milk in sufficient quantity, I doubt the necessity of butter.
('59', 317, 1, 13, 566143) But it will do no harm if it can be digested even in the absence of other food.
('59', 317, 1, 14, 566223) Doctors believe that, like milk, butter too does no harm if taken by itself.
('59', 317, 1, 15, 566300) See how I have described the benefits of milk.
('59', 317, 1, 16, 566347) But I have no choice.
('59', 317, 1, 17, 566369) I can find no plant or herb which can equal milk in food value.
('59', 317, 1, 18, 566433) There is certainly some truth in the belief that milk is a wholesome food even for yogis.
('59', 317, 1, 19, 566523) It is the only substitute for meat.
('59', 317, 1, 20, 566559) Only our vaids 1 could have discovered a vegetable substitute for milk, but, lacking zeal for dharma, they made no such attempt.
('59', 317, 1, 21, 566688) I have failed in my search and given it up.
('59', 317, 1, 22, 566732) We do not know if anybody else will take it up and succeed.
('59', 317, 1, 23, 566792) Perhaps in the West they may succeed.
('59', 317, 1, 24, 566830) Among us there is no one who possesses the necessary medicinal knowledge to make such a discovery.
('59', 317, 1, 25, 566929) We do not regard it as our dharma to acquire such knowledge and to make experiments with that aim.
('59', 317, 1, 26, 567028) Anybody who wishes to undertake the task should be inspired with zeal for the welfare of the cow.
('59', 317, 1, 27, 567126) He should be convinced that no milk other than the mother’s milk can be the proper food of a human being.
('59', 317, 1, 28, 567232) Such a person should then study medicine.
('59', 317, 1, 29, 567274) We do not have at present men with such a spirit.
('59', 317, 1, 30, 567324) If India is destined to discover such a substitute, God will send among us a person with the necessary gifts.
('59', 317, 1, 31, 567434) Till then, let us sing praises of milk and do the duty which lies before us.
('59', 317, 1, 32, 567511) I hope you will feel satisfied that I have replied to your question in greater detail than you had expected.
('59', 317, 1, 33, 567620) I also hope that you will understand the relative importance of the issues involved.
('59', 317, 1, 34, 567705) Think over all this and do what seems right to you, for even in such matters the final decision should be one’s own.
('59', 317, 1, 35, 567822) What I have said is true only about people with weak health.
('59', 317, 1, 36, 567883) Those who are healthy will eat normal food and may even be able to digest it.
('59', 317, 1, 37, 567961) If you want to experiment with
('59', 317, 2, 38, 567992) 1,Physicians practising Ayurvedic system of medicine

('59', 319, 6, 11, 570948) 443. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('59', 319, 7, 12, 570999) February 19, 1933
('59', 319, 8, 13, 571017) To THE SECRETARY HOME DEPARTMENT DELHI
('59', 319, 9, 14, 571056) DEAR SIR, I thank you for the reply 3 to my letter 4 addressed to the Private Secretary to the Viceroy dated the 1st instant.
('59', 319, 9, 15, 571182) There are two things about which I would like to make brief observations.
('59', 319, 9, 16, 571256) The Government have assumed without just cause that “education and the provision of the normal facilities of life” are not considered by me as the vital part of the Resolution referred to therein.
('59', 319, 9, 17, 571453) It was wholly irrelevant to the purpose of my letter to the Private Secretary to the Viceroy to state what was being done by me or through me in connection with these things.
('59', 319, 9, 18, 571628) Indeed I have shown in my writings being published in the course of the controversy that education and the like were being prosecuted with all the vigour possible and that the pace would be quadrupled by the temples being
('59', 319, 10, 19, 571850) 1 Balkrishna D. Kalelkar 2 Satish D. Kalelkar 3 Vide “Letter from Government of India”, 17 2 1933
('59', 319, 11, 20, 571948) 4 Vide “Letter to Private Secretary to Viceroy”, 1 2 1933
('59', 320, 0, 1, 572006) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 321
('59', 320, 1, 2, 572051) opened to the Harijans.
('59', 320, 1, 3, 572075) As to the two measures now before the legislature, I may be permitted to point out that they are not intended to affect religious “customs and usages of the Hindu community”.
('59', 320, 1, 4, 572250) They are specially designed to leave that question to the community itself.
('59', 320, 1, 5, 572326) The law as it stands makes impossible the operation of the Hindu mind on certain religious customs and usages, and the measures are designed to release the Hindu mind from those fetters.
('59', 320, 1, 6, 572513) I would submit that it is the duty of the Government, which is pledged to neutrality in religious matters, to free the reformers from the shackles of, not of religious custom, but of the law.
('59', 320, 1, 7, 572705) For, had it not been for the law, it would have been open to the trustees, with the consent of the temple goers, to change the custom.
('59', 320, 1, 8, 572840) Nor may it be forgotten that the Bills have come before the legislature as a result of the formation of a very strong body of public opinion in favour of the change of custom.
('59', 320, 1, 9, 573016) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI Home Department, Political, File No.

('59', 324, 6, 23, 580437) It may be almost compared to the blind faith of the people whom you have described and who recklessly touch and mingle with smallpox patients.
('59', 324, 6, 24, 580580) But just as you and I cannot copy their blind faith with any prospect of success, so also may nobody copy anybody else’s fanaticism; and since you have such occular demonstration of the success of vaccination, unless you have your own independent faith and conviction that vaccination is bad you ought to be vaccinated and you should encourage your co workers to do likewise.

('59', 325, 4, 8, 581786) 452. LETTER TO SURESH CHANDRA BANERJEE
('59', 325, 5, 9, 581825) February 19, 1933
('59', 325, 6, 10, 581843) MY DEAR SURESH, I have been thinking of you almost every day, and not having heard from you for a long time, in my despair I dictated a message, quite selfish, to you, in my letter to Satisbaboo, and immediately I had finished that letter, Mahadev put your letter of 15th instant in my hands.
('59', 325, 6, 11, 582136) You can better imagine my joy than I can describe it.
('59', 325, 6, 12, 582190) I see you have been near death’s door again.
('59', 325, 6, 13, 582235) It is better perhaps to realize that we are always near death’s door, the healthy looking people no less than the ill looking.
('59', 325, 6, 14, 582362) I know many bed ridden people surviving the loss of dear ones who had looked pictures of health and who they had thought were bound to survive them.
('59', 325, 6, 15, 582511) Pray, do not become impatient.
('59', 325, 6, 16, 582542) Understand thoroughly the distinction I have drawn between caste and varnashrama.
('59', 325, 6, 17, 582624) Caste is a touch me not institution.
('59', 325, 6, 18, 582661) If untouchability goes, you will find that touch me not ism will go.
('59', 325, 6, 19, 582730) According to my meaning of it varnashrama has not the slightest tinge of touch me not ism.
('59', 325, 6, 20, 582821) It is a spiritual law just as valid as any physical law, whether we recognize its existence or whether we do not.
('59', 325, 6, 21, 582935) He who recognizes the existence of this law profits by his knowledge, even as a scientist, knowing the properties of a drop of water and the laws which are responsible for those properties, makes railway trains to move at a speed our ancestors had never thought of.
('59', 325, 6, 22, 583201) So also if we recognize the law of varnashrama
('59', 326, 0, 1, 583248) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 327
('59', 326, 1, 2, 583293) and give effect to it, we can do away with many ills of life.
('59', 326, 1, 3, 583355) I can understand Dr. Ambedkar in his rage against caste Hindus refusing to see the wood for the trees, but you have no excuse whatsoever for not understanding the very clear distinction I have pointed out.
('59', 326, 1, 4, 583561) 1 In any case I am convinced that to precipitate a fight on varnashrama today is to do a great disservice to the cause of the removal of untouchability.
('59', 326, 1, 5, 583714) I must not worry you any more.
('59', 326, 2, 6, 583745) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('59', 326, 2, 7, 583767) SURESH CHANDRA BANERJEE 88 G CORPORATION STREET CALCUTTA

('59', 338, 9, 16, 604419) You will understand what I mean when I tell you what distinction there is between what you think I have said and what I have actually said.
('59', 338, 9, 17, 604559) I do not consider “the Gita to be the only scripture of
('59', 338, 10, 18, 604615) 1 The addressee wanted to publish a supplement in Tamil and Telugu every Monday containing Gandhiji’s articles in Harijan and had therefore requested for advance proofs which he wanted to reach him on Friday or Saturday.

('59', 339, 1, 2, 604899) unquestionable authority which alone should be our true guide”.
('59', 339, 1, 3, 604963) What I have said and what I still hold is that for me in view of the multitude of books claimed to be scriptural and [of] conflicting texts, Gita is the only safe guide, because it contains the concentrated essence of all that the Hindu scriptures have to teach and that I would unhesitatingly reject anything that is in conflict with the spirit of the Gita.
('59', 339, 1, 4, 605322) Thus I would test the validity of every religious precept or code of conduct on the anvil of that teaching.
('59', 339, 1, 5, 605430) Thus you will see that I exclude nothing.
('59', 339, 1, 6, 605472) I take in all the scriptures, but I use the Gita to unlock their meaning.
('59', 339, 1, 7, 605546) I quite agree with your view of the Samhitas, but my difficulty in applying them to daily conduct arises from the fact that there are conflicting statements in the same Samhita and there is conflict among the different Samhitas.
('59', 339, 1, 8, 605775) There again I summon the Gita to my aid.
('59', 339, 1, 9, 605816) Whilst I agree also that rules of conduct will show variation from the ideal and even between man and man, to be true to the ideal they should conform to it and enable one to make a progressive approach to it.
('59', 339, 1, 10, 606026) They must not take one away progressively further from it.
('59', 339, 1, 11, 606085) Examined thus, untouchability, as it is practised today, in my opinion, is clearly contrary to the Hindu scriptures.
('59', 339, 1, 12, 606202) As I read your several propositions, untouchability stands condemned by them.

('59', 339, 1, 14, 606374) If I had believed that current untouchability had its roots in Hinduism and that untouchables were clearly prohibited from entering temples, there would be no question whatsoever of referendum.
('59', 339, 1, 15, 606568) But since there are two schools of opinion, why should not the people decide to which school they will belong?
('59', 339, 1, 16, 606679) Who will decide for the people whether they should belong to the Shaivite sect or Vaishnavite, if not they themselves?
('59', 339, 1, 17, 606798) Is that not what the Hindus have done all through their great history?

('59', 343, 4, 6, 612937) 481. WHY ‘HARIJAN’1
('59', 343, 5, 7, 612957) Many people have asked me why I have used the name ‘Harijans’ for people whom we commit the sin of regarding as untouchables.
('59', 343, 5, 8, 613083) Years ago a Kathiawadi Antyaja had written to me that names like Antyaja, achhoot, asprishya hurt his community.
('59', 343, 5, 9, 613196) I could appreciate their feelings.
('59', 343, 5, 10, 613231) For me they were neither Antyajas nor untouchables.
('59', 343, 5, 11, 613283) It was this correspondent who had pointed out to me that the poet devotee Narasinh Mehta in one of his bhajans had referred to the Antyajas as ‘Harijans’.
('59', 343, 5, 12, 613438) In my view the bhajan he had sent to me to support his contention did not yield the meaning which he thought it did.
('59', 343, 5, 13, 613555) All the same I liked the name ‘Harijan’ immensely.
('59', 343, 5, 14, 613606) ‘Harijan’ means a devotee of God, beloved of God.
('59', 343, 5, 15, 613656) It is God’s promise that He is the Protector of the oppressed, an ocean of compassion, the strength of the weak, the Refuge of the helpless, the Support of the lame and the Eye of the blind.
('59', 343, 5, 16, 613847) One may therefore expect Him to bestow especial grace on the oppressed.
('59', 343, 5, 17, 613919) Looked at from this point of view, I am sure the name ‘Harijan’ is appropriate in every way for the Antyaja brethren.
('59', 343, 5, 18, 614037) Some argue that the Antyajas became untouchables because of their actions in their previous birth.
('59', 343, 5, 19, 614136) Still others say: ‘Let us suppose for a moment that we regard four crores of our brethren as untouchables.
('59', 343, 5, 20, 614243) But what special miseries do they have to suffer that the other crores of people do not?
('59', 343, 5, 21, 614332) The miseries that they suffer because of untouchability must be only mental and there is no remedy for it.
('59', 343, 5, 22, 614439) Being the fruit of a previous birth, it must be regarded as a divine dispensation.
('59', 343, 5, 23, 614522) The privations which the Antyajas suffer because of their poverty and destitute condition are the common lot of all the people of India with the exception of two or three crores of people.
('59', 343, 5, 24, 614711) Why then should not all of them be called Harijans?’ This argument is utterly absurd.
('59', 343, 5, 25, 614797) Untouchability as we observe today is neither the result of actions of previous births nor of God’s making.
('59', 343, 6, 26, 614905) 1 Gandhiji wrote under the same title in the English Harijan, vide “Why ‘Harijan’ ”, “Why Harijan”, 11 2 1933.
('59', 344, 0, 1, 615016) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 345
('59', 344, 1, 2, 615061) untouchability prevalent at the present time is man’s doing.
('59', 344, 1, 3, 615122) The caste Hindus are responsible for it.
('59', 344, 1, 4, 615163) No one can escape the fruit of his action.
('59', 344, 1, 5, 615206) But by accepting the law of karma, we acquire no right to put the blame on others.
('59', 344, 1, 6, 615289) The way of karma is indeed inscrutable.
('59', 344, 1, 7, 615329) No one knows what karma will bear what fruit.
('59', 344, 1, 8, 615375) We are all laden with one or other shortcoming, hence we have no right whatever to judge the shortcomings or sins of others.
('59', 344, 1, 9, 615500) Our right and duty is only to help one another get rid of such shortcomings.
('59', 344, 1, 10, 615577) Compassion is incompa tible with untouchability whether predestined or unavoidable.
('59', 344, 1, 11, 615661) Four crores of Hindus have to face unparalleled hardships because we treat them as untouchables.
('59', 344, 1, 12, 615758) They do not get even food or a place to live in as others do, even though they have the money as well as other means.
('59', 344, 1, 13, 615876) They have no temples, or dharmsalas or hospitals or schools for them as other people have.
('59', 344, 1, 14, 615967) We have crushed them so much that they have almost forgotten that they are human beings.
('59', 344, 1, 15, 616056) These four crore brethren have not even the will to rise from this abject and abominable situation.
('59', 344, 1, 16, 616156) There is no exaggeration in my account of Harijans.
('59', 344, 1, 17, 616208) It may be there in one respect.
('59', 344, 1, 18, 616240) No one knows the exact number of Harijans.
('59', 344, 1, 19, 616283) I have accepted the figure given by Shri Amritlal Thakkar.
('59', 344, 1, 20, 616342) Thakkar Bapa is himself not very sure about the figure After thorough survey all that can be said is that the number of Harijans cannot be more than four crores.
('59', 344, 1, 21, 616504) But irrespective of the fact whether there are four crore Harijans or one, the guilt on the part of the caste Hindus remains the same.
('59', 344, 1, 22, 616639) If there is any fault in my description of Harijans it may be one of understatement and certainly not of exaggeration.
('59', 344, 1, 23, 616758) 1 If this oppressed class were not to have God’s grace or mercy the world would cease to have faith in God.
('59', 344, 1, 24, 616866) The truth is that He exists and He is an ocean of compassion, the Protector of the oppressed, and the Feeder of the hungry.
('59', 344, 1, 25, 616990) Therefore, in India, those who are most unhappy deserve to be called Harijans.
('59', 344, 1, 26, 617069) And it is my firm belief that if we do not remove the untouchability practised against the Harijans and did not treat them as our brethren, Hindu society would perish under their curse.
('59', 344, 1, 27, 617255) As Tulsidas says,
('59', 344, 2, 28, 617273) 1 A Gujarati version of this article which appeared in Harijanbandhu, 12 3 1933, has the following additional sentences: “Whatever I have written can be substantiated.
('59', 344, 2, 29, 617441) The facts therefore must be worse than what I have described.”

('59', 345, 3, 5, 617665) 482. LETTER TO VERRIER ELWIN
('59', 345, 4, 6, 617694) February 23, 1933
('59', 345, 5, 7, 617712) MY DEAREST SON, Son you have become of your own choice.
('59', 345, 5, 8, 617768) I have accepted the responsible position.
('59', 345, 5, 9, 617810) And son you shall remain to the end of time.
('59', 345, 5, 10, 617855) The tie between you and me is much thicker and tougher than blood.
('59', 345, 5, 11, 617922) It is the burning love of Truth at any cost.
('59', 345, 5, 12, 617967) Therefore whatever you may do will not disappoint me.
('59', 345, 5, 13, 618021) But I was sad.
('59', 345, 5, 14, 618036) I am not thinking of superiority of celibacy over marriage.
('59', 345, 5, 15, 618096) I am thinking of what you had intended, almost pledged yourself to be.
('59', 345, 5, 16, 618167) But I know that you had to be true to yourself and appear as you were.
('59', 345, 5, 17, 618238) I showed your letter to Jamnalalji and he too felt the same as I did.
('59', 345, 5, 18, 618308) But whilst I was trying to make time to write to you, in came Ala, tears dropping from her eyes.
('59', 345, 5, 19, 618405) She put into my hands your letter and said, “How can I bear this?
('59', 345, 5, 20, 618471) It was agreed between us that we were both to remain single, or if we could not, we were to marry each other.” I consoled her and advised her to send you her blessings.
('59', 345, 5, 21, 618640) I do not know what she has done or written.
('59', 345, 5, 22, 618684) You will tell me what understanding there was between you and her.
('59', 345, 5, 23, 618751) But taking it for granted that your word was never given to Ala as she imagines it was, you and Mary 1 have my blessings.
('59', 345, 5, 24, 618873) I have met her.
('59', 345, 5, 25, 618889) I have a vivid recollection that the innocence of her face stamped itself upon my mind.
('59', 345, 5, 26, 618977) I know that your joint life will be one of complete dedication to service.
('59', 345, 5, 27, 619052) But if there is the slightest possibility of a breach (moral) of word given to Ala, you must both—you and Mary—be prepared to bear what will be the heaviest cross and sacrifice your cherished hope on the altar of Truth which is God.

('59', 346, 1, 2, 619489) credited you with—have to live single lives in spite of yourselves.

('59', 346, 1, 4, 619666) For this divine marriage we men and women are all women and Truth is the only Lord, Master and Husband.
('59', 346, 1, 5, 619770) I need say no more.

('59', 354, 1, 3, 630524) She is a wonderful mother.

('59', 354, 1, 5, 630597) ‘Gita’ means ‘song’.

('59', 354, 1, 8, 630764) Hence Mother.
('59', 354, 1, 9, 630778) Well, that immortal Mother gives all the milk we need for spiritual sustenance, if we would but approach her as babes seeking and sucking it from her.
('59', 354, 1, 10, 630929) She is capable of yielding milk to her millions of babes from her exhaustless udder.
('59', 354, 1, 11, 631014) In doing the Harijan work in the midst of calumny, misrepresentations and apparent disappointments, her lap comforts me and keeps me from falling into the Slough of Despond.

('59', 355, 2, 3, 632126) [February 24, 1933] 1
('59', 355, 3, 4, 632148) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letter.
('59', 355, 3, 5, 632185) You know what is happening to the Bills.
('59', 355, 3, 6, 632226) It is unfortunate and it is bad.
('59', 355, 3, 7, 632259) The Government have taken up, in my opinion, not an attitude of neutrality but one of partiality.
('59', 355, 3, 8, 632357) I do not know if you have caught the central point of my argument.
('59', 355, 3, 9, 632424) It would be partiality to the reformers and would also be interference with religion if the Government gave facilities for the consideration of a measure compelling temple entry.
('59', 355, 3, 10, 632603) It is partiality to orthodoxy in that the Government will not remove the legal bar to temple entry created by decisions of courts of law, decisions not based on statutory law but on religious usage, thus making untouchability a crime as if it was part of the Penal Code.
('59', 355, 3, 11, 632874) The Government to be neutral should lift this bar and say to either party.
('59', 355, 3, 12, 632949) ‘We cannot take sides in religious matters.
('59', 355, 3, 13, 632993) Untouchability may be for some of you a breach of your religion, but there is no breach in it of common law and therefore there can be no punishment under the common law.’ There are innumerable religious practices in Hinduism not even [as] offensive to the moral sense of the world as untouchability undoubtedly is, and yet their breach is not penal under the common law.
('59', 355, 3, 14, 633365) All that the reformers want is opportunity for progress, opportunity for converting public opinion, and when and where it is converted, opportunity for giving effect to that conversion.
('59', 355, 3, 15, 633551) Today even if cent per cent of Hindus entitled to worship in a particular temple desired the admission of Harijans to that temple, they could not carry out their wish because of the decisions I have referred to.
('59', 355, 3, 16, 633763) The two Bills are designed to remove this anomaly.
('59', 355, 3, 17, 633814) I watch, wait and pray.
