('59', 362, 4, 7, 644217) 509. HIGHER EDUCATION FOR HARIJANS
('59', 362, 5, 8, 644252) I hope all those who are interested in the removal of untouchability are familiar with Mr. David’s scheme for the higher education of selected Harijans by caste Hindus.
('59', 362, 5, 9, 644421) The scheme was published some time ago in the Bombay Press after being enthusiastically accepted by the Servants of Untouchables Society.
('59', 362, 5, 10, 644559) In Mr. David’s words, “It aims at enabling a large number of untouchables to enjoy the benefits of the best higher education (including technical instruction) possible in this country.” Under it, “well to do caste Hindus are expected throughout India each to bear the expenses for such education of at least one Harijan student for a period of five years.
('59', 362, 5, 11, 644915) Scholarships should be given to selected candidates and the expenses imply the provision of educational fees, books and living expenses on a modest scale”.
('59', 362, 5, 12, 645071) Mr. David thinks that Rs. 500 per year per Harijan would be required for college education and half as much for high school education.
('59', 362, 5, 13, 645206) He advises donors to subscribe, wherever it is possible, the whole amount covering five years in one lump sum.
('59', 362, 5, 14, 645317) “In order to build up the self respect of Harijan scholars”, says Mr. David, “it should be laid down that each scholar would be expected to reimburse the amount originally advanced for his education as soon as he is in a position to do so.
('59', 362, 5, 15, 645557) Thus a student under this scheme is provided by means of a loan and not a gift.” And if a large number of students discharge these debts of honour, Mr. David anticipates that a permanent fund will be created.
('59', 362, 5, 16, 645766) Mr. David advises the formation of a committee or committees in Provinces which will frame rules for the selection of candidates, and the disbursements of subscriptions will be subject to the recommendation of such committee or committees.
('59', 362, 5, 17, 646006) He is emphatic that the scheme, if carried out, should “produce important and sustained results”, and make possible within a comparatively short
('59', 363, 0, 1, 646151) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 363, 1, 2, 646193) period the creation of a large number of lawyers, teachers, doctors and engineers from among Harijans.
('59', 363, 1, 3, 646296) The existence of a considerable number of such persons would be of material help in raising the social status of the depressed classes, and, he adds, “it is framed on strictly non controversial lines, thus widening to the maximum its potential field of response.
('59', 363, 1, 4, 646559) It should win the support of even the staunchest sanatanists.
('59', 363, 1, 5, 646621) It is an opportunity at hand for caste Hindus to give concrete expression of their feeling towards untouchables.” Let me hope, with Mr. David, that the scheme will commend itself to the “staunchest sanatanists” and that in any case it would receive liberal support.
('59', 363, 1, 6, 646887) I do not know whether the Central Board or the Bombay Board has received any donations.
('59', 363, 1, 7, 646975) I venture to suggest to the Bombay Board that, if it has not already done so, it should form a small committee getting, if possible, a sanatanist to work on it, frame rules and get scholarships.
('59', 363, 1, 8, 647170) Whilst it would be the most proper thing to get 1,000 donors who would contribute Rs. 2,500 or 1,250, as the case may be, for full five years’ expenses, it is not necessary to confine oneself to the letter of Mr. David’s scheme, so long as its spirit is observed.
('59', 363, 1, 9, 647434) The central point of the scheme is that there should be a decent fund at once collected from caste Hindus for the higher education of a select number of Harijan boys or girls.
('59', 363, 1, 10, 647610) I, therefore, invite subscriptions for the scheme.
('59', 363, 1, 11, 647661) They will be duly acknowledged in these columns.
('59', 363, 1, 12, 647710) Donors should send moneys to the Manager, Sjt.
('59', 363, 1, 13, 647757) A. V. Patwardhan, marking the envelopes ‘the David Scheme’.
('59', 363, 1, 14, 647817) Acknowledgements will be published from week to week, and the money will be handed to the Central Board for their disposal strictly in accordance with the donor’s instructions.
('59', 363, 1, 15, 647994) As soon as the first full subscription is received, I would advise the Central Board to make its selection.
('59', 363, 1, 16, 648102) Donors may make their own choice of the Province from which Harijan boys or girls may be selected, or they may even make their own selection of such boy or girl and hand the donation to the Central Board or Provincial Board for disbursement to, and supervision of, the candidate so selected.
('59', 363, 2, 17, 648394) Harijan, 25 2 1933
('59', 364, 0, 1, 648413) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 365
('59', 364, 1, 2, 648458) 510. DR.
('59', 364, 1, 3, 648467) SAPRU ON UNTOUCHABILITY BILLS
('59', 364, 2, 4, 648497) As the public know, I have been in communication with Dr. Sapru and Sjt.
('59', 364, 2, 5, 648570) Jayakar over the two Bills which have stirred Hindu opinion.
('59', 364, 2, 6, 648631) Jayakar’s opinion I have already published.
('59', 364, 2, 7, 648675) Dr. Sapru’s opinion is now before me on both the Bills.
('59', 364, 2, 8, 648731) In his letter of the 11th instant on the first Bill, he says: 1
('59', 364, 3, 9, 648795) Whatever may be my own personal views, there is no doubt that some eminent Judges (Hindus included) in Madras, Bombay and elsewhere have interpreted the law in such a way that you cannot throw open the temples everywhere to Hindus of the depressed classes except by an Act of the Legislature.
('59', 364, 3, 10, 649088) Now coming to the Bill itself.
('59', 364, 4, 11, 649119) I am afraid the forces of orthodoxy are strong in the Assembly and I am more than doubtful whether the reformers will carry the day.
('59', 364, 4, 12, 649252) I should not, however, feel surprised if dilatory tactics are adopted and the motion to circulate the Bill is carried.
('59', 364, 4, 13, 649371) Framed as the Bill is, I should strongly oppose the motion to circulate the Bill and should enlist the sympathy and support of the members of the Legislature to go ahead with the consideration of the Bill.
('59', 364, 4, 14, 649577) I appreciate the moderation of the Bill, though, speaking for myself, I should not hesitate to go much further than the Bill.
('59', 364, 4, 15, 649703) In my individual capacity I can be of very little use, so far as the Assembly is concerned, but I can assure you of my support, even though I feel that the Bill is a very mild measure.
('59', 364, 5, 16, 649888) On this I telegraphed for his opinion also on the shorter Bill of the two.
('59', 364, 5, 17, 649963) His reply dated 18th instant (omitting the immaterial or personal matters) is as follows: 3
('59', 364, 6, 18, 650055) As I read this clause, it seeks to remove disabilities from which the untouchables are suffering under the existing law, but it does notseek to impose any disability on caste Hindus.
('59', 364, 6, 19, 650238) So far as the latter are concerned, there does not seem to me to be anything like an element of compulsion contemplated by the Bill.
('59', 364, 6, 20, 650371) If they do not wish to associate with the untouchables in the temples, they are not, by this Bill, compelled to do so.
('59', 364, 6, 21, 650490) All that it requires them to do is that they must not stand in the way of the untouchables.
('59', 364, 6, 22, 650582) It also lays down a rule of law for the courts which are required
('59', 364, 7, 23, 650648) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('59', 364, 7, 24, 650685) 2 For Gandhiji’s reply, “Letter to Tej Bahadur Sapru”, 16 2 1933 3 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('59', 365, 0, 1, 650787) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 365, 1, 2, 650829) not to recognize any custom of untouchability for judicial purposes.
('59', 365, 1, 3, 650898) I, therefore, fail to discover any element of compulsion in this Bill.
('59', 365, 1, 4, 650969) I have read in this morning’s papers the telegram of Malaviyaji to you and your reply to him.
('59', 365, 1, 5, 651063) Personally I am in complete agreement with you, both as a lawyer and as a public man.
('59', 365, 1, 6, 651149) I think I owe it to you to say frankly that I look upon both these Bills as being essentially very moderate.
('59', 365, 1, 7, 651258) Left to myself, I should be prepared to go much further and I have not the same horror of compulsion in a matter of this character as some others have.

('59', 367, 1, 2, 655513) Similarly with reference to the Code of Manu, I never rejected the whole of it on “the mere suspicion of interpolation”; and as to interpolations, they are more than a suspicion, for what I consider as interpolations are clearly in contravention of the fundamentals laid down in the Gita and, for that matter, in Manu’s Code itself.
('59', 367, 1, 3, 655846) The following is Manu’s touchstone of religion:
('59', 367, 2, 4, 655894) : : : |
('59', 367, 4, 5, 655902) Whatever is always followed by the learned, the good and those who are free from anger and attachment and whatever is experienced in the heart, know that to be religion.
('59', 367, 5, 6, 656072) Another text is, again, from the same Code:
('59', 367, 8, 7, 656116) Steadfastness, forgiveness, restraint, non stealing, purity, control of the senses, intelligence, learning, truth, freedom from anger, these ten are the touchstone of religion.
('59', 367, 9, 8, 656293) Accordingly, whatever is clearly contrary to this touchstone must be rejected as an interpolation.
('59', 367, 9, 9, 656392) The Pandit has summarilÁŸy dismissed the ideals of Hinduism about equality and justice, by regardiÁfng them as the private property of the saints, forgetting that ideals and saints become perfectly useless if the practice of the poor sinners can never approach the ideals and their repositories, the saints.
('59', 367, 9, 10, 656700) What is that justice “which will not condone invidious distinction between man and man but will make us face the stern reality and admit the necessity of differential treatment between different castes and classes of people”?
('59', 367, 9, 11, 656926) Who are the different castes and what is the differential treatment between them?
('59', 367, 9, 12, 657008) For instance, among the Banias, whom I should know best, there are about 50 castes.
('59', 367, 9, 13, 657092) I know of no differential treatment between them.
('59', 367, 9, 14, 657142) Nor do I find any authority for the formation of these castes in the Smritis.
('59', 367, 9, 15, 657220) There are as many castes among the Brahmins as there are leaves in the little tree under which I am sitting, but I do not find any Smriti which enumerates these castes and the differential treatment.

('59', 368, 1, 3, 657805) The Pandit says:

('59', 368, 2, 11, 658888) Then only will he vindicate the glory of varnadharma and the true message of Hinduism, for which he is supposed ‘‘to live, move and have his being”.
('59', 368, 2, 12, 659037) I invite the Pandit to appreciate this very simple prescription.

('59', 373, 1, 2, 669477) is first a free translation of the Tamil report:
('59', 373, 2, 3, 669526) GANDHI: Should a pure woman consort with her husband when he is given up to sinful ways?
('59', 373, 3, 4, 669615) THE PANDIT: Yes.
('59', 373, 3, 5, 669632) The sinful husband will be metamorphosed into a virtuous man by the chastity of the wife.
('59', 373, 4, 6, 669722) GANDHI: Are there chaste women in these days?
('59', 373, 5, 7, 669768) PANDIT: How can we say there are none?
('59', 373, 5, 8, 669807) There may be virtuous women for all we know.
('59', 373, 5, 9, 669852) But why wander from our topic of conversation?
('59', 373, 5, 10, 669899) Let us go on with our discussion.
('59', 373, 5, 11, 669933) Be it noted that the Madura Pandit or his friend took no notes.
('59', 373, 5, 12, 669997) Here is the relevant portion of Mahadev Desai’s notes:
('59', 373, 6, 13, 670052) PANDIT: The temples are intended for women and Shudras.
('59', 373, 6, 14, 670108) According to Shastras, Shudras only can enter the temples today, because they alone are observing their swadharma 1‘ viz., service, and chaste women have the same right.
('59', 373, 6, 15, 670278) The others are burdened with karmas and duties, which now they have ceased to perform and, therefore, not entitled to enter a temple.
('59', 373, 7, 16, 670412) GANDHI: So whilst a Brahmin may be a karma Chandala 2‘ his chaste wife may be entitled to enter a temple.
('59', 373, 8, 17, 670518) PANDIT: The wife because of her chastity purifies her husband.
('59', 373, 9, 18, 670581) GANDHI: Then, the moment a man has a wife who is pure, he becomes pure, no matter what sort of life he lives.
('59', 373, 10, 19, 670691) PANDIT: Yes; his wife saves him.
('59', 373, 11, 20, 670724) GANDHI: A man may go to the dogs, and yet if his wife is chaste, he becomes pure?
('59', 373, 12, 21, 670806) PANDIT: Yes, his wife saves him; though what he does is wrong, his sins will be neutralized.
('59', 373, 12, 22, 670899) GANDHI: So, if a man wants to remain immune from the consequences of his acts, all that he has to do is to be armed with a chaste wife.
('59', 373, 13, 23, 671035) PANDIT: Quite so.
('59', 373, 14, 24, 671053) GANDHI: Well, then, since we are not going to impute bad character to a single woman in India, for we must assume every one of them to be pure, unless, of course, she admits that she is impure or she has been found to be impure—every married man is pure and there should be no untouchability.
('59', 373, 15, 25, 671346) PANDIT: She should be a true pativrata, a genuinely chaste woman, described
('59', 373, 16, 26, 671422) 1 Duty of oneself 2 Untouchable for one’s actions
('59', 374, 0, 1, 671472) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 375
('59', 374, 1, 2, 671517) in our religious books like Ramayana.
('59', 374, 2, 3, 671555) GANDHI: How are you to determine that a particular woman satisfies that definition?
('59', 374, 3, 4, 671639) PANDIT: Agni pariksha.
('59', 374, 3, 5, 671662) She must prove her chastity by undergoing the ordeal
('59', 374, 4, 6, 671715) through fire, as Sita did.
('59', 374, 5, 7, 671742) GANDHI: And so, those who cannot come scatheless out of it must be declared to be impure?
('59', 374, 6, 8, 671832) PANDIT: Indeed.
('59', 374, 7, 9, 671848) GANDHI: I have done.
('59', 374, 7, 10, 671869) Enough, however, about the Tamil sheet.
('59', 374, 7, 11, 671909) A Gujarati sheet published by one claiming to be a sanatanist Shastri and now distributed broadcast in Hindi by sanatanist papers in North India professes to publish excerpts from my writings, sixty in all, which have the effect of proving me to be the very embodiment of everything anti Hindu.
('59', 374, 7, 12, 672204) Excerpts are torn from their context and made to bear a meaning the opposite of what they have when read in their context.
('59', 374, 7, 13, 672327) Here is a sample of statements attributed to me:
('59', 374, 8, 14, 672376) My parents and Sita were Bhangis.
('59', 374, 9, 15, 672410) The Shastras are the productions of hypocrites, and the sages are so many Satans.
('59', 374, 10, 16, 672492) I regard a Bhangi to be superior to a Brahmin.
('59', 374, 11, 17, 672539) I am an iconoclast.
('59', 374, 11, 18, 672559) Now my correspondents, some of them frankly puzzled, invite me to deal with these charges.
('59', 374, 11, 19, 672650) I must respectfully but resolutely decline the invitation.
('59', 374, 11, 20, 672709) If there are people who will believe of me the things that are said in the writings sent to me, no refutation will save me.
('59', 374, 11, 21, 672833) The public must take me as I am.
('59', 374, 11, 22, 672866) What is more, the cause is everything, I am nothing..
('59', 374, 11, 23, 672920) If the campaign against untouchability is just and necessary for the very existence of Hinduism, it will survive the reputation of a thousand Gandhi.
('59', 374, 11, 24, 673070) What is, however; sad, almost tragic, about these libellous statements is that they are made by responsible sanatanists reported to be learned men and presumed to be holy men fit to be religious teachers of unsophisticated simple folk.
('59', 374, 11, 25, 673306) Their curious interpretations of the Shastras, their refusal to read the signs of the times, their defence of obviously superstitions and even inhuman beliefs and customs, one can understand as being honestly held.
('59', 374, 11, 26, 673521) What may appear as superstitious and inhuman to the reformer may not appear so to
('59', 375, 0, 1, 673603) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 375, 1, 2, 673645) But the resort by responsible pandits to untruths, distortions and suppression of truth is bound to do incalculable harm to Hindus and Hinduism.
('59', 375, 1, 3, 673790) Let sanatanists put up as stubborn a fight as they like in defence of what they regard as a good cause.
('59', 375, 1, 4, 673894) But I implore them to weed it of untruth.
('59', 375, 2, 5, 673936) Harijan, 25 2 1933
('59', 375, 3, 6, 673955) 514. ‘WE DO NOT HATE’
('59', 375, 4, 7, 673977) One who is a Vedanta Shastri and Secretary of a branch Brahmin Sabha writes:
('59', 375, 5, 8, 674054) Sanatanists do not hate untouchables but hate their customs and daily
('59', 375, 6, 9, 674124) actions.
('59', 375, 6, 10, 674133) They are always ready to give all the Hindus, whether touchables or
('59', 375, 7, 11, 674201) untouchables, every help they can.
('59', 375, 7, 12, 674236) They give the untouchables priests,
('59', 375, 8, 13, 674272) preceptors, Shastras with Ramnam, etc.

('59', 375, 9, 15, 674349) persons who always hate those untouchables.

('59', 375, 10, 17, 674423) from them and they want to pollute the sanatanists with the impurity brought
('59', 375, 11, 18, 674500) by them from non Hindus.
('59', 375, 11, 19, 674525) The foregoing I have taken from a fairly long letter and I have taken it as a sample from many such letters.
('59', 375, 11, 20, 674634) ‘Hate, is perhaps the wrong word.
('59', 375, 11, 21, 674668) I should use the word ‘despise’.
('59', 375, 11, 22, 674701) And if to relegate a body of people to distant locations, to regard their touch, approach or sight as pollution, to throw at them the leavings of one’s food, to deny to them the use of public roads and institutions, even the use of public temples, is not to despise them, I do not know what the word ‘despise, means.
('59', 375, 11, 23, 675018) The writer says that the untouchables have priests and preceptors.
('59', 375, 11, 24, 675085) My own experience and the experience of numerous reformers is to the contrary.
('59', 375, 11, 25, 675164) Despairing of real priests, they have raised from among themselves what must be called ‘an apology for priests’.
('59', 375, 11, 26, 675277) The writer betrays the secret when he says that untouchables have the “Shastras with Ramnam”, implying that they can have no access to any other Shastras.
('59', 375, 11, 27, 675432) What are their daily customs and daily actions which evoke hatred?
('59', 375, 11, 28, 675499) Their daily action was described in graphic terms by the Poet in his message 1 for our first issue.
('59', 375, 11, 29, 675599) Save for carrion eating, their customs are the same as those of innumerable caste Hindus.
('59', 375, 11, 30, 675689) And carrion eating is by no means common to all the
('59', 375, 12, 31, 675741) 1 Vide “The Cleanser”
('59', 376, 0, 1, 675763) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 377
('59', 376, 1, 2, 675808) untouchables so called.
('59', 376, 1, 3, 675832) If a census were taken, we would be astonished to find that there are so few.
('59', 376, 1, 4, 675910) I hope to present the readers of Harijan with reliable statistics in this matter.
('59', 376, 1, 5, 675992) And I have not a shadow of a doubt that caste Hindus are responsible for this habit of carrion eating and that, immediately they are welcomed as brothers and sisters and are offered the ordinary amenities of life on the same terms as caste Hindus, that habit will automatically drop out.
('59', 376, 1, 6, 676280) Lastly, the common experience is that whatever has been done for the Harijans by caste Hindus has been done by those who have received education or who are otherwise ranked as reformers.
('59', 376, 1, 7, 676467) It will give me pleasure to know that sanatanists as such have done much or anything for Harijans.
('59', 376, 1, 8, 676566) I would gladly publish the list of their charities or other acts of service rendered to Harijans.

('59', 376, 3, 10, 676683) 515. “HARIJAN” IN THE VERNACULARS
('59', 376, 4, 11, 676717) Some readers are anxious to know when, if at all, Harijan will be published in Hindi and other languages of the country.

('59', 377, 1, 5, 678348) I can prevent no one, I can only plead with everyone to follow the advice which I have tendered and which is based on considerable experience.

('59', 384, 6, 11, 688588) DEAR FRIEND’ I thank you for your two letters, one of which is unsigned, of the 14th instant.

('59', 384, 6, 13, 688933) About the other letter, I am unable to say anything definite in the absence of fuller information, but this I can say that if the rites are intended as a condition precedent to their admission to varnashramadharma, I am wholly opposed to the performance of the rites; if on the other hand, they are meant for their betterment and as part of a spiritual instruction, they might be quite harmless and even beneficial, if the selection is properly made and the rites are performed by men, qualified both by their character and learning.

('59', 387, 9, 19, 693114) 536. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('59', 387, 10, 20, 693143) February 25,1933
('59', 387, 11, 21, 693160) RAMDAS’ Khushaldas has passed away.
('59', 387, 11, 22, 693196) I received both the accompanying letters yesterday evening.
('59', 387, 11, 23, 693256) I have written to Shantilal and informed him.
('59', 387, 11, 24, 693302) Khushaldas has indeed been released from the suffering of this life.
('59', 387, 11, 25, 693371) The truth is that everybody who goes on a journey along that royal road is released from this life.
('59', 387, 11, 26, 693471) For this life is given to us for repaying our debts, and nobody can leave before he has paid off his.
('59', 387, 11, 27, 693573) If this idea is correct, death means that the person has paid off his debt
('59', 388, 0, 1, 693648) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 389
('59', 388, 1, 2, 693693) partially at least.
('59', 388, 1, 3, 693713) He who knows with perfect conviction that this life is given to us for repaying our debts can repay his debts to all, and the ancients described that as attaining moksha.
('59', 388, 1, 4, 693884) Moksha means complete freedom from debt and, consequently, end of the cycle of births for the person.
('59', 388, 1, 5, 693986) I was pained to see your condition yesterday, your broken health and your mental suffering.
('59', 388, 1, 6, 694078) I had no remedy for either, and was pained because you attributed to your father more power than he possessed.
('59', 388, 1, 7, 694189) I felt as Harishchandra had done.
('59', 388, 1, 8, 694223) He had become ready to sell his only son for the sake of dharma.
('59', 388, 1, 9, 694288) I have been doing very much the same thing.
('59', 388, 1, 10, 694332) Though I know the remedy for your poor health, I cannot adopt it because of my concern for dharma, nor can end your mental suffering for the same reason If you follow the rule that you cannot avail yourself of facilities which other prisoners who keep bad health would not get, you can do nothing to improve your health.
('59', 388, 1, 11, 694653) I can understand that you would not like to ask for special facilities for yourself but it does not seem right to me that you should not avail yourself of facilities which may be offered to you when you explain to the authorities the condition of your health.
('59', 388, 1, 12, 694913) When you are outside, you enjoy more facilities than the countless millions and never think about the matter.
('59', 388, 1, 13, 695023) I ask for and enjoy, both in jail and outside, facilities which they can never hope to get, and am fully aware that I do so.
('59', 388, 1, 14, 695148) But I do not feel that I violate dharma thereby.
('59', 388, 1, 15, 695197) If an elephant tries to crawl like an ant, he will not succeed in becoming an ant thereby and will cease to be an elephant, which means that he will have lost his true nature.
('59', 388, 1, 16, 695373) An elephant like me, however, would humbly accept his big size and consume food weighing more than thousands of ants and would also draw, without the least effort, loads which those ants could never draw.
('59', 388, 1, 17, 695578) An elephant is entitled to consume food which the size of his body requires.
('59', 388, 1, 18, 695655) Only, he must not waste that food by not giving proportionate service in return.
('59', 388, 1, 19, 695736) That is, he should carry loads proportionate to his strength.
('59', 388, 1, 20, 695798) If he does that, he will have consumed as much food and given as much service as an ant.
('59', 388, 1, 21, 695887) This is communism.
('59', 388, 1, 22, 695906) If, therefore, you can secure the food which your body requires by legitimate means and without humiliating yourself for the purpose, you should do so and improve your health, and then serve other people to the best of your ability.
('59', 388, 1, 23, 696139) But even in trying to serve other people and securing facilities for yourself by legitimate means, you should know and understand
('59', 389, 0, 1, 696269) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 389, 1, 2, 696311) your duty as a prisoner.
('59', 389, 1, 3, 696336) A prisoner has no right except that of preserving his self respect, for he ceases to be the master of his body as soon as he becomes a prisoner and the jail superintendent becomes its master.
('59', 389, 1, 4, 696528) Even if the latter does not give the prisoner enough to eat or to drink or sufficient clothes to wear, the prisoner should remain contented and cheerful.
('59', 389, 1, 5, 696682) Anybody who cannot do so is not a true prisoner.
('59', 389, 1, 6, 696731) We must admit that in this age the British policy towards prisoners is comparatively more liberal than that of any other government.
('59', 389, 1, 7, 696864) It is improving day by day.
('59', 389, 1, 8, 696892) There is certainly room for much more improvement still, but that is another matter.
('59', 389, 1, 9, 696977) A prisoner may fight to bring about such improvement.
('59', 389, 1, 10, 697031) If, however, he remembers the general principle stated above, he will not be disappointed if he fails in his attempt—for he has no absolute right to enjoy any facility.
('59', 389, 1, 11, 697200) If you understand this reasoning fully, I shall be relieved and you will be able to overcome your mental unrest.
('59', 389, 1, 12, 697313) I will certainly try to do what I can in regard to everything which you mentioned—but in my own way, and that is bound to take time.
('59', 389, 1, 13, 697446) The delay will not make me impatient, and I wish that you also should not be.
('59', 389, 1, 14, 697524) What can you or I do?
('59', 389, 1, 15, 697546) Certainly we are not masters of the result.
('59', 389, 1, 16, 697590) We can only try the best that we can.
('59', 389, 1, 17, 697628) You have been doing what you can, and I also will do what I can.
('59', 389, 1, 18, 697693) Even if we don’t succeed, you should dance with joy, and so will I.
('59', 389, 2, 19, 697761) Be not moved by joy or sorrow; with the body were they created;
('59', 389, 3, 20, 697825) None can escape them for by the Lord of Raghu were they decreed.
('59', 389, 3, 21, 697890) Do you follow all this?
('59', 389, 3, 22, 697914) Read the letter three or four times, and if you do not follow any point ask me to explain it again.
('59', 389, 3, 23, 698014) Keep me informed about the condition of your health.
('59', 389, 4, 24, 698067) Blessings from
('59', 389, 6, 25, 698082) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 20366

('59', 393, 0, 1, 702935) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 393, 1, 2, 702977) examined by Haribhai 1. If Mathuradas remains firm in his resolve, Motibehn will give up her opposition.
('59', 393, 1, 3, 703082) It has been my unfailing experience that if one of the two parties is firm and the other party knows that he or she cannot be shaken from his or her resolve, the latter resigns herself or himself to the situation.
('59', 393, 1, 4, 703296) As we forget in time our grief even over the death of one who was dearest to us, so also this folly leaves us by and by.
('59', 393, 1, 5, 703417) The truth is there is some weakness in both parties and that is why they need each other’s support.

('59', 396, 0, 1, 708150) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 397
('59', 396, 1, 2, 708195) 548. RESIST UNTRUTH WITH TRUTH
('59', 396, 2, 3, 708226) February 26,1933
('59', 396, 3, 4, 708243) It is unfortunate that untruth is being preached these days in the name of the sanatana dharma.
('59', 396, 3, 5, 708339) I am receiving many new sanatanist newspapers which abound in untruth and indecency.
('59', 396, 3, 6, 708424) I have been severely attacked in them.
('59', 396, 3, 7, 708463) Many correspondents ask me to write something in reply to them.
('59', 396, 3, 8, 708527) What can I write?
('59', 396, 3, 9, 708545) Some say I do not believe in religion.
('59', 396, 3, 10, 708584) In answer to that, except for me to say that religion is my life breath what other reply can I give?
('59', 396, 3, 11, 708685) A learned religious propagandist has written in the same vein.
('59', 396, 3, 12, 708748) I can only give this reply to it that every word of it is almost entirely untrue.
('59', 396, 3, 13, 708830) His words are not proved untrue because I say so, just as, his mere saying so does not establish what he says as truth.
('59', 396, 3, 14, 708950) Still untruth can be resisted by truth alone.
('59', 396, 3, 15, 708996) It is necessary to understand this great saying.
('59', 396, 3, 16, 709045) The root of all actions is in thought.
('59', 396, 3, 17, 709084) False thoughts result in false utterances; and after that, or along with it or without the utterances, action follows.
('59', 396, 3, 18, 709203) In the same way right action has its roots in right thoughts.
('59', 396, 3, 19, 709265) If the thought is not true then that action or utterance which seems true is only false, is erroneous.
('59', 396, 3, 20, 709368) That is to say, if I am entirely truthful even in my thoughts falsehood will be warded off automatically.
('59', 396, 3, 21, 709474) People will not believe these canards.
('59', 396, 3, 22, 709513) This firm faith keeps me unperturbed, and my friends also should be unperturbed.
('59', 396, 3, 23, 709594) This false propaganda cannot last long.
('59', 396, 3, 24, 709634) It is that for a short while the atmosphere will be contaminated by it.
('59', 396, 3, 25, 709706) In every agitation such things always happen.
('59', 396, 4, 26, 709752) Let the reformer remember one thing.
('59', 396, 4, 27, 709789) Let him never even contemplate untruth.
('59', 396, 4, 28, 709829) We have a great religious mission before us.
('59', 396, 4, 29, 709874) The abolition of untouchability is the great religious task before me, an onerous duty.
('59', 396, 4, 30, 709962) To eradicate untouchability is the supreme duty of every Hindu.
('59', 396, 4, 31, 710026) We can never accomplish this religious task with untruth.
('59', 396, 4, 32, 710084) Ultimately anger or violence is also untruth.
('59', 396, 4, 33, 710130) For this reason, it is necessary for those who serve Harijans never to be angry with their opponents; never to utter lies; but to overcome anger with affection, rudeness with courtesy, falsehood with truth, and violence with non violence.
('59', 396, 4, 34, 710369) And since we cannot control the outcome but can certainly practise truth and other virtues, God has said, “You have
('59', 397, 0, 1, 710485) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 397, 1, 2, 710527) only the right to action; and not to the fruit thereof.” 1 If all those who serve Harijans will stick to truth, then the result will only be good.
('59', 397, 1, 3, 710674) There is no doubt whatever in this.
('59', 397, 2, 4, 710710) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 1068; also Harijan Sevak, 10 3 1933
('59', 397, 3, 5, 710782) 549. KEEPING THE WORD
('59', 397, 4, 6, 710804) February 26, 1933
('59', 397, 5, 7, 710822) A gentleman writes:
('59', 397, 6, 8, 710842) You are very hasty.
('59', 397, 6, 9, 710862) Although a non co operator, you even seek help
('59', 397, 7, 10, 710909) from the Assembly.
('59', 397, 7, 11, 710928) Why such weakness?
('59', 397, 7, 12, 710947) Negotiate with the sanatanists and
('59', 397, 8, 13, 710982) have the temples thrown open.
('59', 397, 8, 14, 711012) I replied to this gentleman on these lines: I am not hasty.
('59', 397, 8, 15, 711072) I am striving to fulfil my pledge.
('59', 397, 8, 16, 711107) In Bombay, at the end of September, this large conference of Hindus leaders on behalf of the Hindus resolved to strive to get the temples thrown open to Harijans in as peaceful a manner as possible.
('59', 397, 8, 17, 711306) Now this difficulty has cropped up in our way, namely, the British courts have decided that Harijans cannot enter many temples.
('59', 397, 8, 18, 711434) Even a consensus among Hindus cannot abolish the law.
('59', 397, 8, 19, 711488) Law can be abrogated by law alone.
('59', 397, 8, 20, 711523) So legislation has become necessary and Shri Ranga Iyer has presented the Bill.
('59', 397, 8, 21, 711603) It does not have even a hint of force or of interference with religion.
('59', 397, 8, 22, 711675) According to the Bill, if the Hindu public wish so, temples can be thrown open to the Harijans.
('59', 397, 8, 23, 711771) The temples will be thrown open when Hindu public decide to do so; never by the Bills.
('59', 397, 8, 24, 711858) There is no question of co operation or non co operation in this.
('59', 397, 8, 25, 711924) But this matter is outside my province today.
('59', 397, 8, 26, 711970) People should have this much faith that if I, the author of the principle of non co operation, am a partisan to the passing of these Bills, the possibility of the principle being violated is very little.
('59', 397, 8, 27, 712174) The important thing is that it is the duty of those who made the solemn declaration in Bombay to do their utmost to remove the legal obstruction.
('59', 397, 8, 28, 712320) Only then can they say:
('59', 397, 9, 29, 712344) Rather die than go back upon one’s word.
('59', 397, 10, 30, 712385) From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 1070; also Harijan Sevak,10 3 1933
('59', 397, 11, 31, 712456) 1 Bhagavad Gita, II.

('59', 402, 2, 3, 718586) February 28,1933
('59', 402, 3, 4, 718603) DEAR DR.
('59', 402, 3, 5, 718612) KATJU, I thank you for your valuable letter.
('59', 402, 3, 6, 718657) 1 I am glad that yourdaughter is happy with her husband.
('59', 402, 3, 7, 718714) I know you will do all you can for the Harijan.
('59', 402, 3, 8, 718762) I appreciate your argument about temple entry.
('59', 402, 3, 9, 718809) In my opinion, based even upon the present experience of new temples which are being opened, the donors have no fixed ideas.
('59', 402, 3, 10, 718934) They simply build temples for Hindus without a rigid definition for the class of Hindus to be admitted to the temples.
('59', 402, 3, 11, 719053) Hinduism has never been a rigid faith.
('59', 402, 3, 12, 719092) It has kept abreast of the times.
('59', 402, 3, 13, 719126) Untouchables of today were not the untouchables, say, a hundred years ago, and those who were untouchables a thousand years ago are undoubtedly not untouchables today.
('59', 402, 3, 14, 719294) Would you say that the English law of Trusts is applicable to Hindu usage?
('59', 402, 3, 15, 719369) Some of the most learned Shastris who are no reformers of the Western style do not hesitate to give the opinion that Hindu public temples should never have been closed to untouchables.
('59', 402, 3, 16, 719554) According to your argument, our ancestors could stop the march of Hinduism by opening temples in accordance with the usage then in existence.
('59', 402, 3, 17, 719696) I would like you therefore to re consider your position, and if there is a flaw in my deductions from your argument, I would like you to strive with me.
('59', 402, 3, 18, 719849) For I have no desire to see any injustice done to any party or person.
('59', 402, 4, 19, 719920) Yours sincerely, SJT.

('59', 406, 8, 18, 724711) 565. LETTER TO DUNCAN GREENLEES
('59', 406, 9, 19, 724743) March 1,1933 Newcomers do find the routine a stiff business.
('59', 406, 9, 20, 724804) But we are trying to live the life of the billions of the earth.
('59', 406, 9, 21, 724869) They are toilers all the day long.
('59', 406, 9, 22, 724904) They have to do their thinking whilst their bodies are working.
('59', 406, 9, 23, 724968) When the routine becomes natural, it becomes pleasant and does not interfere with hard thinking.
('59', 406, 9, 24, 725065) All thinking is not useful.
('59', 406, 9, 25, 725093) Clear thinking is the need.
('59', 406, 9, 26, 725121) That can only come through continuous sacrifice, i.e., toiling for the service of others.
('59', 406, 10, 27, 725211) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('59', 407, 1, 2, 725646) 566. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('59', 407, 2, 3, 725677) March 1,1933
('59', 407, 3, 4, 725690) NARANDAS, I got your mail (a big packet).
('59', 407, 3, 5, 725732) I think it would be best to serve rice to Maitri and others who insist on it.
('59', 407, 3, 6, 725810) We may only explain the properties of the different classes of grain and not press anybody to follow our advice.
('59', 407, 3, 7, 725923) These properties are a matter of direct experience.
('59', 407, 3, 8, 725975) I see from experience every day that we should consume a minimum of starches.
('59', 407, 3, 9, 726053) Rice is pure starch, and so it is served to people who cannot digest any other grains.
('59', 407, 3, 10, 726140) The derogatory use of the term “rice eater’, is perfectly justified.
('59', 407, 3, 11, 726209) But this argument will convince only those who use their reason.
('59', 407, 3, 12, 726274) It is not at all likely to appeal to a person whose stomach will not tolerate anything but rice.
('59', 407, 3, 13, 726371) I could write a great deal more on this subject, but I have no time for that.
('59', 407, 3, 14, 726449) Ramabehn saw me yesterday.
('59', 407, 3, 15, 726476) You have not won her trust.
('59', 407, 3, 16, 726504) Try harder.
('59', 407, 3, 17, 726516) She wishes to learn English.
('59', 407, 3, 18, 726545) She wishes to do so in spare time after doing her work for the Ashram.
('59', 407, 3, 19, 726616) Go and meet her.
('59', 407, 3, 20, 726633) Listen to what she has to say and request Mathew or Mary or Duncan to give her one hour daily.
('59', 407, 3, 21, 726728) Do all you can to satisfy her desire to learn English.
('59', 407, 3, 22, 726783) If any of the women who are old inmates of the Ashram wish to learn English, their desire is natural.
('59', 407, 3, 23, 726885) We feel the necessity of its knowledge every hour, and also observe that as soon as a person learns English he or she goes up in the esteem of others.
('59', 407, 3, 24, 727036) We cannot check this tide.
('59', 407, 3, 25, 727063) There is no harm in knowing the language itself.
('59', 407, 3, 26, 727112) The harm comes from the misuse of the language, from its blind worship.
('59', 407, 3, 27, 727184) Women are not likely to cultivate such an attitude soon.
('59', 407, 3, 28, 727241) If you see any flaw in this reasoning, point it out to me.
('59', 407, 5, 29, 727300) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I

('59', 408, 1, 2, 727388) 567. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('59', 408, 2, 3, 727419) Morning, March 2, 1933
('59', 408, 3, 4, 727442) NARANDAS, You must have received the letter which I wrote to you yesterday.
('59', 408, 3, 5, 727518) Make careful preparations for Lakshmi’s marriage and see that everything goes well.
('59', 408, 3, 6, 727602) Jamna and you should give away the bride, and Velanbehn should offer the bridegroom.
('59', 408, 3, 7, 727687) If possible, I will send Lakshmidas there.
('59', 408, 3, 8, 727730) As usual, keep a dhoti, shirt, cap, takli and a copy each of the Gita and the Bhajanavali ready for the bridegroom.
('59', 408, 3, 9, 727846) Tie the marriage knot with the ends.
('59', 408, 3, 10, 727883) Give a translation of the vows 1 to both the bride and the bridegroom.
('59', 408, 3, 11, 727954) And they should fast on that day and eat nothing till after the ceremony is over.
('59', 408, 3, 12, 728036) You, Jamna and Velanbehn also should fast.
('59', 408, 3, 13, 728079) Both the bride and the bridegroom should perform the ceremonial worship of the cow and the tree and recite Chapter XII of the Gita.
('59', 408, 3, 14, 728211) It is not necessary to invite any friends except Anasuyabehn.
('59', 408, 3, 15, 728273) We don’t want the marriage to be published in newspapers, though we do not wish to keep it a secret either.
('59', 408, 3, 16, 728381) The bride and the bridegroom may leave for home by the night train and start working immediately.
('59', 408, 3, 17, 728479) Velanbehn will arrange for the sari on behalf of Maruti.
('59', 408, 3, 18, 728536) If you wish to ask any other question, you may do so.
('59', 408, 3, 19, 728590) Invite all Harijan friends to attend the wedding.
('59', 408, 3, 20, 728640) If you wish, you may serve them refreshments.
('59', 408, 3, 21, 728686) In that case, I believe fruit will be the best.
('59', 408, 3, 22, 728734) But consult your own convenience in all this, and make any changes which you feel necessary.
('59', 408, 3, 23, 728827) Let the members of the Committee come together and plan the arrangements.
('59', 408, 3, 24, 728901) Invite the senior women inmates also to the meeting of the Committee.
('59', 408, 3, 25, 728971) Let the day of marriage be for us a sacred day of tapascharya and self purification and one to be celebrated in keeping with our ideal of simplicity and self control.
('59', 408, 3, 26, 729138) Let all present shower their blessings on the bride and the bridegroom.
('59', 408, 3, 27, 729210) Maruti’s letters simply fill me with admiration for him.
('59', 408, 3, 28, 729267) If he remains true to the aspirations which he expresses in them, we shall believe that he must have become a member of Lakshmidas’s family blessed with the holy merit of his good deeds in previous lives.
('59', 408, 3, 29, 729472) Lakshmidas’s love for him, too, must be wonderful beyond words.
('59', 408, 4, 30, 729536) 1 The marriage vows, called saptapadi, which form the essential part of the Hindu marriage ceremony.

('59', 412, 1, 2, 734142) 573. LETTER TO NELLIE BALL
('59', 412, 2, 3, 734169) March 2, 1933
('59', 412, 3, 4, 734183) MY DEAR NELLIE1, Next time when you feel like writing you should trace the spelling of your name.
('59', 412, 3, 5, 734281) As I read your signature I can only make out ‘Mell Bull’.
('59', 412, 3, 6, 734339) I can easily read ‘Bull’ as ‘Ball’, but Esther confounds me.
('59', 412, 3, 7, 734400) She has clearly spelt your name as ‘Nellie Ball’.
('59', 412, 3, 8, 734450) I have therefore adopted her clear spelling in preference to your doubtful ‘Mell’.
('59', 412, 3, 9, 734533) If therefore I have made any mistake you must go for Esther.
('59', 412, 3, 10, 734594) But I see that you are a little philosopher with a big heart.
('59', 412, 3, 11, 734656) Therefore you will exclaim, ‘What is in a name?
('59', 412, 3, 12, 734704) It is the spirit that matters’.
('59', 412, 3, 13, 734736) And whether I trace Mell or Nellie my spirit goes out to you, the little invalid daughter.
('59', 412, 3, 14, 734827) But I propose a peremptory change in the way you describe yourself.
('59', 412, 3, 15, 734895) Your body is no doubt shattered, but your spirit seems to have risen triumphant over the body.
('59', 412, 3, 16, 734990) I do not want to think of you therefore as my ‘little invalid daughter’, but my ‘little daughter strong with the faith in God’.
('59', 412, 3, 17, 735118) Now that C. F. Andrews is there you will certainly have the joy of receiving visits from him frequently and not only rarely.
('59', 412, 3, 18, 735243) He is a genius for seeking out persons like you and going to them as often as he can.
('59', 412, 3, 19, 735329) To visit people in power is a tax upon his mind.
('59', 412, 3, 20, 735378) To visit people like you and me is a matter of perennial joy to him.
('59', 412, 3, 21, 735447) He derives his strength from his association with those whom the world calls weak and helpless and who often but wrongly feel so themselves.
('59', 412, 3, 22, 735588) But I must now stop.
('59', 412, 3, 23, 735609) You should give my love to your doctor and ask him to write to me about you.
('59', 412, 4, 24, 735686) From a photostat: S.N. 20427

('59', 417, 4, 7, 742567) 581. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS
('59', 417, 5, 8, 742602) March 2,1933
('59', 417, 6, 9, 742615) Gandhiji stated in reply to a question that, if the necessary permission was given, he would, after duly examining the terms of the permission, quite willingly make a declaration of his policy on political questions.
('59', 417, 6, 10, 742832) But just now he was not thinking about it at all.
('59', 417, 6, 11, 742882) Politics was excluded from his thoughts.
('59', 417, 6, 12, 742923) He was deliberately practising and doing this for two reasons, firstly, that he might not be burdened with its weight when he had another subject in hand to which he had been permitted to devote attention, and secondly nothing might escape his lips, even inadvertently, which would be tantamount to a breach of faith with the Government.
('59', 417, 6, 13, 743261) He was now so constituted that he could not discuss politics.
('59', 417, 6, 14, 743323) He added: It is a wonderful gift God has given me.
('59', 417, 7, 15, 743374) Did it mean he was not interesting himself in contemporary political events?
('59', 417, 7, 16, 743451) Gandhiji replied: Oh yes, but only as a foreigner would.
('59', 417, 7, 17, 743508) I note them in passing, but I bestow little thought on them.
('59', 417, 7, 18, 743569) Of course, if the ban is lifted, and I am permitted to speak, I can, without any difficulty, speak on questions of policy and fundamental principles.
('59', 417, 8, 19, 743719) He added that those agents in his brain who were now on leave would then begin to work.
('59', 417, 9, 20, 743807) Asked if in his own opinion, the Harijan movement had not diverted attention from civil disobedience, Gandhiji replied: Surely, it is a matter which everyone can decide for himself, because, all the materials are before him.
('59', 417, 9, 21, 744032) One might as well ask me what is the height of the Himalayas when both he and I are seeing it.
('59', 417, 9, 22, 744127) one will say it is 23,000 feet, another 25,000.
('59', 417, 10, 23, 744175) Asked as to what was his estimate of the height, Gandhiji replied at once.
('59', 417, 11, 24, 744250) The Hindu, 3 3 1933

('59', 420, 15, 20, 747092) 589. ‘NO INFRINGEMENT’
('59', 420, 16, 21, 747115) The following important opinion 1, on the question of temple entry, of Sjt.
('59', 420, 16, 22, 747191) T. R. Venkatarama Sastri, ex Law Member of the Madras Government, is taken from the daily Press.
('59', 420, 17, 23, 747288) KELKAR’S COMPROMISE
('59', 420, 18, 24, 747308) N. C. Kelkar was good enough to pay me a visit at my request to discuss the question of temple entry.
('59', 420, 18, 25, 747410) I was anxious to know what he thought of the proposed legislation.
('59', 420, 18, 26, 747477) He said that
('59', 420, 19, 27, 747490) 1 Not reproduced here.
('59', 420, 19, 28, 747513) It said that temple entry legislation did not infringe the property rights of anyone.
('59', 421, 0, 1, 747599) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 421, 1, 2, 747641) he had for years held that there was no way out of legislation in matters, even affecting religion, where a law alone could set them right, as in the case of temple entry.
('59', 421, 1, 3, 747813) Judge made law had ordained that trustees of public Hindu temples were bound to pre vent Harijans from entering them.
('59', 421, 1, 4, 747931) No amount of public opinion could undo that law.
('59', 421, 1, 5, 747980) It could demand the passage of a law but could not make the law permitting temple entry.
('59', 421, 1, 6, 748069) Whilst, therefore, Sjt.
('59', 421, 1, 7, 748093) Kelkar agreed that measures like Sjt.
('59', 421, 1, 8, 748131) Ranga Iyer’s were necessary, he said that actual temple entry would only be effected by amicable settlement.
('59', 421, 1, 9, 748240) He had no doubt that Harijans should enter temples on precisely the same terms as caste Hindus.
('59', 421, 1, 10, 748336) But public opinion might not be ripe for the former’s admission to the sanctuaries.
('59', 421, 1, 11, 748420) If so, the caste Hindus should forgo the rights which Harijans could not have.
('59', 421, 1, 12, 748499) He, therefore, suggested that in all the public temples there should be a common barrier set up, beyond which nobody but the priest actually in charge of the ceremonial could go.
('59', 421, 1, 13, 748678) This would mean that, in some temples where now caste Hindus are able to enter the sanctuary and touch the idol, they would have to deny themselves that right, if they were not prepared to let Harijans enjoy it equally with them.
('59', 421, 1, 14, 748908) I said I should have no objection whatsoever to such a compromise, provided, of course, that it was honestly carried out in practice.
('59', 421, 1, 15, 749042) Nothing would please me better than to see this unseemly domestic wrangle close at the earliest moment.
('59', 421, 1, 16, 749146) HARIJAN, 4 3 1933
('59', 421, 2, 17, 749164) 590. A WAIL FROM KUMAON
('59', 421, 3, 18, 749188) A Harijan correspondent from Haldvani writes complaining that nothing is being done by caste Hindus on their behalf in his district.
('59', 421, 3, 19, 749321) This complaint is a sign that the message of the September resolutions has reached the Harijan masses and that, therefore, they are expecting great things.
('59', 421, 3, 20, 749477) Provincial Boards of the Servants of Untouchables Society will have to organize their work so as to penetrate the remotest village and let the Harijans know that every attempt is being made to fight the monster of untouchability.
('59', 421, 3, 21, 749707) Harijan, 4 3 1933
('59', 422, 0, 1, 749725) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 423
('59', 422, 1, 2, 749770) 591. JOINT OR SEPARATE?
('59', 422, 2, 3, 749794) Correspondents suggest that there should be separate temples, schools, wells, etc., for Harijans for the time being.
('59', 422, 2, 4, 749911) A general adoption of the suggestion may easily be the way to perpetuate untouchability, and we might as well have had separate electorates and elections for them, if we are to have everything else separate for them.
('59', 422, 2, 5, 750128) I would certainly not have staked my life just to avoid separate electorates.
('59', 422, 2, 6, 750206) I staked it, and it is still at stake, for the purpose of eradicating the present unnatural untouchability from the religion itself.
('59', 422, 2, 7, 750339) I rose against separate electorates, because it would have spelt an end to the effort for the destruction of the canker.
('59', 422, 2, 8, 750460) They would have meant an end to effective penance by the penitent caste Hindu.
('59', 422, 2, 9, 750539) With the Yeravda Pact, such penance is a possibility, whether the penitents are in the majority or the minority.
('59', 422, 2, 10, 750652) That there is a mighty upheaval in Hinduism and that we have two well defined divisions working actively for their respective objectives is the surest justification for the Yeravda Pact.
('59', 422, 2, 11, 750839) As a result of it, the religious untouchability goes or the reformer.
('59', 422, 2, 12, 750909) If he is to be true to his pledge, the reformer has no other choice.
('59', 422, 2, 13, 750978) Therefore, separate temples and separate other services must be regarded with suspicion.
('59', 422, 2, 14, 751067) Let us consider the limitations of the suggestion.
('59', 422, 2, 15, 751118) Till the legal obstacle in the way of opening public temples to untouchables is removed, the opening of existing temples on a large scale comes to a standstill.
('59', 422, 2, 16, 751279) But the march of reform cannot be stayed.
('59', 422, 2, 17, 751321) There are three ways of doing the thing.
('59', 422, 2, 18, 751362) (a) Where public opinion and trustees are quite demonstrably in favour of opening temples, trustees may open the temples under their charge and may take the risk of an injunction being issued against them.
('59', 422, 2, 19, 751568) (b) Private temples should be opened where the owners are willing to open them.
('59', 422, 2, 20, 751648) (c) Wealthy and spiritually minded people may open new temples under pure methods of consecration.
('59', 422, 2, 21, 751747) (I add the adjective advisedly because I believe that all is not well with the existing temples.) These temples will be purposely designed for the Harijans as well as for the other Hindus.
('59', 422, 2, 22, 751936) These must, therefore, be situated in such
('59', 423, 0, 1, 751979) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 423, 1, 2, 752021) localities as are easily accessible to Harijans.
('59', 423, 1, 3, 752070) Common schools and wells should be opened where the existing ones are not available for Harijans either owing to the violent and successful opposition of the neighbours or some other unavoidable cause.
('59', 423, 1, 4, 752272) Harijans cannot be left uncared for in matters of necessary services till public opinion has ripened.
('59', 423, 1, 5, 752374) If there is a clearly awakened body of Hindus who have the same feeling towards Harijans as if they were their own kith and kin, they will not wait for public opinion to consolidate itself before taking action.
('59', 423, 1, 6, 752585) They will do their best to supply pure water and good education to their own newly found kith and kin.
('59', 423, 1, 7, 752688) There is one special consideration in favour of opening what may be called preparatory schools for Harijan children.
('59', 423, 1, 8, 752805) I cannot do better than quote the reason in the words of a co worker who has gone to live in their midst and who writes: 1
('59', 423, 2, 9, 752928) My school is conducted in a Harijan verandah.
('59', 423, 2, 10, 752974) Some of my scholars are .
('59', 423, 2, 11, 753000) full of dirt.
('59', 423, 2, 12, 753014) My lesson, therefore, begins with telling them how to keep clean, and behave.
('59', 423, 2, 13, 753092) They are bad liars.
('59', 423, 2, 14, 753112) Some of them are industrious and wise.
('59', 423, 2, 15, 753151) I play with them and perhaps learn more than I teach.
('59', 423, 2, 16, 753205) I begin my class in the early morning.
('59', 423, 2, 17, 753244) I sleep in a Harijan dharmasala about a furlong from the school.
('59', 423, 2, 18, 753309) I naturally sometimes enter their homes when they do not mind.
('59', 423, 2, 19, 753372) Many of them are dark holes with inmates packed like matches.
('59', 423, 2, 20, 753434) But I am a novice.
('59', 423, 2, 21, 753453) I know my limitations.
('59', 423, 2, 22, 753476) I long to fulfil God’s conditions for becoming a true Vaishnav.
('59', 423, 2, 23, 753540) This is but a sample of the condition of raw Harijan children.
('59', 423, 2, 24, 753603) We want every one of these children to learn to live in a clean and decent manner.
('59', 423, 2, 25, 753686) We want them all to attend the common public schools.
('59', 423, 2, 26, 753740) Therefore, preparatory schools for them are an absolute essential if we mean honest business.
('59', 423, 3, 27, 753834) Harijan, 4 3 1933
('59', 423, 4, 28, 753852) 592. CONFUSING THE ISSUE
('59', 423, 5, 29, 753877) The Secretary of the Jat Pat Torak Mandal, i.
('59', 423, 5, 30, 753923) e., Society for the Abolition of Caste, has published in the daily Press his letter to me of the 18th ultimo.
('59', 423, 5, 31, 754033) He does me the honour of calling me a ‘deep thinker’ and in the same breath withdraws it by saying:
('59', 423, 6, 32, 754133) You have failed to see that the caste system is the origin of
('59', 423, 7, 33, 754195) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here
('59', 424, 0, 1, 754231) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 425
('59', 424, 1, 2, 754276) untouchability and that one cannot do without the other.
('59', 424, 1, 3, 754333) I venture to suggest to the Secretary that, if he is really honest in his paying me the compliment, he must suspend his judgement about the caste system and follow out the reasoning of the ‘deep thinker’ of his imagination; whereas if he has called me a ‘deep thinker’ in order to increase the height from which I have fallen, I fear that no reasoning of mine will affect him.
('59', 424, 1, 4, 754710) However, according to my wont, I propose to give the Secretary credit for honesty and shall, therefore, strive with him.
('59', 424, 1, 5, 754831) I am one of those who think that the caste system, in so far as it is the English equivalent for varnashrama, is nothing but a division of labour or duty.
('59', 424, 1, 6, 754986) Anyone who will take the trouble of looking at any religious book must find this out for himself.
('59', 424, 1, 7, 755084) In that sense the divisions or classes are four and no more, and these classes are known all the world over.
('59', 424, 1, 8, 755193) One is the repository of knowledge, the other is that of power, the third is that of wealth and the fourth is that of service.
('59', 424, 1, 9, 755320) All these four labours are regarded as duties to be discharged by every one of them for the protection and advancement of dharma, and everyone who performs his duty to the best of his knowledge and ability gains equal merit with the rest, if the latter, too, do likewise.
('59', 424, 1, 10, 755592) The merit, therefore, consists not in being one or the other, but in the performance of the duty assigned to it.
('59', 424, 1, 11, 755705) Here, there is no untouchability.
('59', 424, 1, 12, 755739) There is no superiority.
('59', 424, 1, 13, 755764) And this is the essence of varnadharma.
('59', 424, 1, 14, 755804) It may be non existent today and it is so.
('59', 424, 1, 15, 755847) That, however, in no way diminishes the force of my argument that there is no superiority and inferiority in the original conception of varnadharma and that untouchability can never be a necessary outcome of this pure division of duties.
('59', 424, 1, 16, 756085) If this varnashrama cannot be revived in its original simplicity and purity, persons like me would consider it to be a calamity.
('59', 424, 1, 17, 756214) Others may welcome it, but let varnadharma and untouchability stand or fall on their own merits or demerits.
('59', 424, 1, 18, 756323) Confusing the two can only add to the difficulty of removal of untouchability, which all reformers and even many sanatanists desire.
('59', 424, 1, 19, 756456) The caste abolitionists must, therefore, hold their souls in patience and join the battle against the common and admitted evil of untouchability.
('59', 424, 1, 20, 756602) Varnashrama, as I interpret it, satisfies the religious, social and economic needs of a community.
('59', 424, 1, 21, 756701) It satisfies the religious needs, because a whole community, accepting the law, is free to devote ample
('59', 425, 0, 1, 756805) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 425, 1, 2, 756847) time to spiritual perfection.
('59', 425, 1, 3, 756877) Observance of the law obviates social evils and entirely prevents the killing economic competition.
('59', 425, 1, 4, 756977) And if it is regarded as a law laying down, not the rights or the privileges of the community governed by it, but their duties, it ensures the fairest possible distribution of wealth though it may not be an ideal, i.e., strictly equal, distribution.
('59', 425, 1, 5, 757227) Therefore, when people in disregard of the law mistake duties for privileges and try to pick and choose occupations for self advancement, it leads to confusion of varna and ultimate disruption of society.
('59', 425, 1, 6, 757432) In this law, there is no question of compelling any person to follow the parental occupation against his or her aptitude; that is to say, there can be no compulsion from without as there was none for, perhaps, several thousand years, during which the law of varnashrama worked without interruption.
('59', 425, 1, 7, 757731) By training, the people had recognized the duty and the justice of the law, and they voluntarily lived under it.
('59', 425, 1, 8, 757844) Today, nations are living in ignorance and breach of that law and they are suffering for it.
('59', 425, 1, 9, 757937) The so called civilized nations have by no means reached a state which they can at all regard with equanimity and satisfaction.
('59', 425, 1, 10, 758065) It is easy enough to see that this conception of varnashrama has nothing to do with restrictions as to inter dining and intermarriage.
('59', 425, 1, 11, 758200) The Vedas and the Mahabharata are filled with illustrations both of inter dining and intermarriage.
('59', 425, 1, 12, 758300) But these are matters of choice, not a matter of religious regulation.
('59', 425, 1, 13, 758371) No one can be compelled or required to dine with any other or contract marital relations.
('59', 425, 1, 14, 758461) No doubt social habits will grow up and regulate these things more or less rigidly.
('59', 425, 1, 15, 758545) But it would be wrong to dignify them by the name of religious observances.
('59', 425, 1, 16, 758621) Therefore, inter dining and intermarriage can form no part of the campaign against untouchability.
('59', 425, 1, 17, 758720) In so far as they are a matter for reform, they must be treated, in my opinion, as an absolutely separate subject, unconnected either with untouchability or even with varnashrama reform.
('59', 425, 1, 18, 758907) So far as the multiplicity of castes apart from varnadharma are concerned, they are essentially trade guilds or societies, with intermarriage and inter dining restrictions of a more or less rigid character superimposed upon them.
('59', 425, 1, 19, 759137) Castes are as numerous as the leaves of the famous banana tree whose every branch becomes a trunk for shooting out more branches.
('59', 425, 1, 20, 759267) They are undergoing a perpetual transformation.
('59', 425, 1, 21, 759315) Many have disappeared and new ones are appearing.
('59', 425, 1, 22, 759365) Surely they have nothing to do with varnashrama; nor have they anything to do with religion.
('59', 425, 1, 23, 759458) That today they are regarded by sanatanists as an integral part of Hinduism arises,
('59', 426, 0, 1, 759542) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 427
('59', 426, 1, 2, 759587) in my opinion, from an utter ignorance of the working of these trade guilds.
('59', 426, 1, 3, 759664) There are undoubtedly many undesirable practices that have crept into these corporations, but that is only because Hinduism as a religion has ceased to be a living, vitalizing force.
('59', 426, 1, 4, 759847) We are today living upon capital which is itself being fast exhausted.
('59', 426, 2, 5, 759918) Harijan, 4 3 1933

('59', 429, 1, 12, 766950) It is a tremendous task, but as we progress towards the goal, the truth must dawn upon every caste Hindu that there is no half way house between abject slavery and perfect religious equality.

('59', 430, 2, 17, 769314) 598. IS IT LOSS OF FAITH?
('59', 430, 3, 18, 769340) A co worker writes:
('59', 430, 4, 19, 769360) Some of us feel that your ‘fasting unto death’ may mean a conscious or unconscious loss of faith in the efficacy of non violence.
('59', 430, 4, 20, 769490) Can you enlighten us, who have derived our faith in non violence from you?
('59', 430, 4, 21, 769565) It is a flattering thought that some people have derived their faith in non violence from me.
('59', 430, 4, 22, 769659) But I would warn them that I may prove a broken reed at a critical juncture, if they have not assimilated the spirit of non violence and if it has not become an integral part of their life.
('59', 430, 4, 23, 769849) Faith in a man is a perishable quantity, for it vanishes like smoke when their idol does not come up to their expectations; but what gives us hope and courage in the nick of time is an undying faith in a cause or a principle, irrespective of persons from whom it is derived.
('59', 430, 4, 24, 770124) Having uttered this warning, let me say that my ‘fast unto death, was not due to loss of faith in non violence, but it was, as I have
('59', 431, 0, 1, 770258) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 431, 1, 2, 770300) already said on more than one occasion, the last seal upon that faith.
('59', 431, 1, 3, 770371) Sacrifice of self even unto death is the final weapon in the hands of a non violent person.
('59', 431, 1, 4, 770463) It is not given to man to do more.
('59', 431, 1, 5, 770498) I, therefore, suggest to this co worker and all the others that in this religious battle against untouchability they must be prepared joyously even to ‘fast unto death, if such an urgent call comes to them.
('59', 431, 1, 6, 770705) If they feel that they are party to the September pledge 1 given unsolicited to the Harijans and if they cannot make good the pledge in spite of ordinary effort, how else, being non violent, will they propose to deliver the goods except by laying down their lives?
('59', 431, 1, 7, 770970) The Shastras tell us that, when people in distress prayed to God for relief and He seemed to have hardened His heart, they declared a ‘fast unto death’ till God had listened to their prayer.
('59', 431, 1, 8, 771161) Religious history tells us of those who survived their fast, because God listened to them but it tells us nothing of those who silently and heroically perished in the attempt to win the answer from a deaf God.
('59', 431, 1, 9, 771371) I am certain that many have died in that heroic manner, but without their faith in God and non violence being in the slightest degree diminished.
('59', 431, 1, 10, 771517) God does not always answer prayers in the manner we want Him to.
('59', 431, 1, 11, 771582) For Him life and death are one, and who is able to deny that all that is pure and good in the world persists because of the silent death of thousands of unknown heroes and heroines!

('59', 431, 4, 17, 772250) I feel tempted to offer satyagraha, but I desist lest I might do so in anger.

('59', 432, 1, 10, 773515) God is known not by His thousand names only but by millions of names.

('59', 432, 1, 13, 773869) This is not a movement in which faint heartedness can be of any use.

('59', 432, 3, 16, 774170) 600. LETTER TO MIRABEN
('59', 432, 4, 17, 774193) March 4, 1933
('59', 432, 5, 18, 774207) MIRA, This is Saturday before prayer time 3.30 a.m.
('59', 432, 5, 19, 774259) No letter from you till Friday evening.
('59', 432, 5, 20, 774299) I put off even yesterday in the hope of getting your letter in the afternoon and still posting you something yesterday but that was not to be.
('59', 432, 5, 21, 774442) So each week your letter is getting later in coming.
('59', 432, 5, 22, 774495) But though I look forward to it I do not worry.
('59', 432, 5, 23, 774543) The letter writing is not a right of prisoners.
('59', 432, 5, 24, 774591) Therefore there is no deprivation.
('59', 432, 5, 25, 774626) What in ordinary life religion calls duty becomes or seems to be compulsion in the prison life.
('59', 432, 5, 26, 774722) But that is not the case with us.
('59', 432, 5, 27, 774756) We are in a way voluntary prisoners.
('59', 432, 5, 28, 774793) Therefore we may not feel
('59', 433, 0, 1, 774819) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 433, 1, 2, 774861) the compulsion as such when a certain permission is withdrawn or is regulated in the manner suited to the authorities.
('59', 433, 1, 3, 774980) I can do without your letters if need be and you must train yourself to do likewise and feel happy 1. In a manner everybody trains himself to do without things when he cannot get them.
('59', 433, 1, 4, 775165) A follower of the Gita dharma trains himself to do without things with happiness 2 called equanimity in Gita language, for happiness of the Gita is not the opposite of unhappiness.
('59', 433, 1, 5, 775346) It is superior to that state.
('59', 433, 1, 6, 775376) The devotee of the Gita is neither happy nor unhappy.
('59', 433, 1, 7, 775430) And when that state is reached, there is no pain, no pleasure, no victory, no defeat, no deprivation, no possession.
('59', 433, 1, 8, 775547) Prison life is a life of privilege if we learn to practise the Gita teaching.
('59', 433, 1, 9, 775625) It is easier in the prison than outside.

('59', 434, 7, 25, 778834) It means perfect accord between thought, speech and deed, and when there is that completely, you are within sight of Truth.

('59', 436, 1, 6, 780753) I should hold it to be a great tragedy if through the tenderness of friends, untruth had crept into my life or had passed current among the people.
('59', 436, 1, 7, 780901) If what I hold is truth, it must stand the light of fiercest criticism even of friends who have hitherto worked with me.
('59', 436, 1, 8, 781022) I have no end to serve but that of Truth.
('59', 436, 1, 9, 781064) If my defeat means victory of Truth, I would count that defeat itself as victory.
('59', 436, 1, 10, 781146) I do not regard my judgements as infallible and even though I may be right in 99 cases out of 100, I do not want to trade upon it and assume or expect other people to assume that the 100th judgement is also right.
('59', 436, 1, 11, 781360) I have for that reason called Gurudev the great sentinel, and I have always appreciated his warnings even when I have not been able to depart from my course by reason of his warnings.
('59', 436, 1, 12, 781544) They have put me on my mettle and made the .

('59', 436, 1, 17, 782059) But if he has any doubt I want the benefit of that doubt because I do not want the people to be confused.
('59', 436, 1, 18, 782165) As it is, on this temple entry question I do not hold the field undisputed.
('59', 436, 1, 19, 782241) They have all kinds of arguments put before them for examination.

('59', 436, 1, 22, 782486) I am personally not quite sure that Gurudev agrees with you in your attitude, for Santiniketan has its own temple or church or mandir, whatever you like to call it.
('59', 436, 1, 23, 782651) Where two or three people gather together in a particular place in the name of God to offer worship, it becomes a temple.
('59', 436, 1, 24, 782773) In Santiniketan we have a humble but beautiful building where prayers are offered, incenses burnt and sermons given.
('59', 436, 1, 25, 782890) In Sabarmati we have no building, no walls, but the cardinal points are the walls, the sky is the roof and mother earth is the floor; nevertheless, the spot that has been selected for the morning and the evening prayers has all the essentials of a temple.

('59', 439, 10, 16, 787498) 609. WHAT SHOULD HARIJANS DO?
('59', 439, 11, 17, 787528) Q. (1) What should be done to unite the several sub castes among Harijans into
('59', 439, 13, 18, 787607) (2) In large cities where there is sewerage the Harijan brothers are being
('59', 439, 14, 19, 787682) deprived of their livelihood.
('59', 439, 14, 20, 787712) What should they do under these circumstances?
('59', 439, 15, 21, 787759) (3) In certain towns at the time of marriages and the like Harijans are not
('59', 439, 16, 22, 787835) 1 The addressee was secretary to Shivaprasad Gupta who was seriously ill 2 Plato’s Phaedo
('59', 440, 0, 1, 787925) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 441
('59', 440, 1, 2, 787970) allowed to ride a horse.
('59', 440, 1, 3, 787995) You have written about the duty of caste Hindus.
('59', 440, 1, 4, 788044) But please write and say what the Harijans should do under such circumstances.
('59', 440, 1, 5, 788123) A. The above three questions have been sent by a Harijan brother.
('59', 440, 1, 6, 788189) All the three are difficult questions.
('59', 440, 1, 7, 788228) As long as there are several sub castes among caste Hindus it is very difficult to abolish the different sub castes among Harijans.
('59', 440, 1, 8, 788360) But this much is true that if there is a great awakening among Harijans then they can march ahead by leaps and bounds, at once.
('59', 440, 1, 9, 788488) I should like to see a time when Harijans will be actually far ahead of the caste Hindus.
('59', 440, 1, 10, 788578) But the question here is about the present condition.
('59', 440, 1, 11, 788632) In the present circumstances, it can only be said that castes considered higher among the Harijans should attempt to mix with castes deemed lower.
('59', 440, 1, 12, 788779) For example, the Mahar 1 caste should mix with the Mang 2 caste; they should begin to eat together and intermarry.
('59', 440, 1, 13, 788894) The Mahars who mix in this way with the Mangs should be fearless and face whatever difficulties they might encounter.
('59', 440, 1, 14, 789012) The second question is common to all.
('59', 440, 1, 15, 789050) In this age of transition many occupations will vanish and new ones will crop up.
('59', 440, 1, 16, 789132) It has always been so.
('59', 440, 1, 17, 789155) The question of sewerage can never arise in villages, Only towns can have sewerage.
('59', 440, 1, 18, 789239) Scavengers are found in towns.
('59', 440, 1, 19, 789270) I imagine that where there is sewerage, some scavengers must lose their jobs.
('59', 440, 1, 20, 789348) It is the duty of the municipality to provide work for such unemployed scavengers.
('59', 440, 1, 21, 789431) My advice is that weaving or some such occupation should be learnt by the scavengers.
('59', 440, 1, 22, 789517) In Gujarat I noticed that scavengers who lost their jobs took to weaving.
('59', 440, 1, 23, 789591) There is no common remedy for all in this matter.
('59', 440, 1, 24, 789641) It varies with the individual.
('59', 440, 1, 25, 789672) The third question is very difficult.
('59', 440, 1, 26, 789710) It is implied in the question itself that Harijans are entirely helpless and frightened.
('59', 440, 1, 27, 789799) Under these circumstances, it can only be said that they should go to the police for help.
('59', 440, 1, 28, 789890) Dr. Ambedkar told me that since the police belong to higher castes, they do not assist and this is quite possibly true.
('59', 440, 1, 29, 790010) Therefore, it can only be said that where there is police indifference or opposition and where no help is offered by the caste Hindus and where the Harijans are not sufficiently strong, it is best to have patience.
('59', 440, 1, 30, 790225) The only consolation is that there are occasions in the life of every person and every community when there is no other course open except to
('59', 440, 2, 31, 790367) 1 Sub castes among Harijans of Maharashtra 2 ibid
('59', 441, 0, 1, 790417) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 441, 1, 2, 790459) keep patience.
('59', 441, 1, 3, 790474) Were it not so, man would become an atheist, and forget God.
('59', 441, 1, 4, 790535) Therefore, if the Harijans can see no non violent way out of a difficulty, then they had better pray to God for help.
('59', 441, 2, 5, 790653) Harijan Sevak, 5 3 1933

('59', 445, 2, 3, 796138) March 5, 1933
('59', 445, 3, 4, 796152) DEAR SATISBABU, I have your letter, and I have also two copies of the Bengali Harijan.
('59', 445, 3, 5, 796239) I wish my knowledge of Bengali was such as to enable me to read what you have been writing.
('59', 445, 3, 6, 796331) Ghanshyamdas has heard me say that I am studying Bengali.
('59', 445, 3, 7, 796389) Unfortunately, that is untrue.
('59', 445, 3, 8, 796420) What I told him was that I was studying Urdu and that if I had the time I had a great longing for studying Bengali and reviving my knowledge of Tamil.
('59', 445, 3, 9, 796571) A study of Bengali, as you know, is an old dream.
('59', 445, 3, 10, 796621) It was about to materialize in 1914, but I had to abruptly leave London for India and the lessons which Mrinalini Devi was giving to me had to be suspended.
('59', 445, 3, 11, 796778) Therefore when Mahadev has read the paper 1 will send you what he has to say.
('59', 445, 3, 12, 796856) The cover is certainly attractive.
('59', 445, 3, 13, 796891) You will let me know what reception it has had from the public.
('59', 445, 3, 14, 796955) As for the articles to be sent in advance, there are tremendous difficulties, but I shall see what can be done.
('59', 445, 3, 15, 797067) I understand your position about vaccination.
('59', 445, 3, 16, 797113) Your faith will sustain you.
('59', 445, 3, 17, 797142) You will see how the report that you sent about the Bengali work was interwoven by Shastri into the “Week to Week” columns.
('59', 445, 4, 18, 797266) Have you noticed the ‘comedy of errors, that happened in connection with the information that Hemprabha had given me about Aroon’s father’s death?
('59', 445, 4, 19, 797413) When I read her letter, I could not believe my eyes.
('59', 445, 4, 20, 797466) There was nothing wrong with you.
('59', 445, 4, 21, 797500) You were Aroon’s [sic] father and yet the expression ‘Aroon’s father, was there right enough.
('59', 445, 4, 22, 797594) I read or showed it to the 9 Sardar, Mahadev and Chhaganlal, and we all came to the conclusion that it must be another Aroon whose father was dead, because later from the language used by Hemprabha it was clear that you were to have seen Aroon’s father before he died, but you and she were too late.
('59', 445, 4, 23, 797894) I had a vague recollection of Hemprabha having adopted a boy or girl, so I connected Aroon with this adoption, and yet there were not two Aroons to my knowledge.
('59', 445, 4, 24, 798056) Therefore my letter 2 to Hemprabha baldly referred to a strange Aroon’s father.
('59', 445, 5, 25, 798136) 1 Of Harijan
('59', 445, 6, 26, 798149) 2 Vide “Letter Hemprabha Das Gupta”, 25 2 1933
('59', 446, 0, 1, 798196) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 447
('59', 446, 1, 2, 798241) letter cleared the mystery.
('59', 446, 1, 3, 798269) And now comes Aroon’s postcard, but of course your letter itself was quite clear that it was your father who had died.
('59', 446, 1, 4, 798388) If I had remembered, as I should have remembered, that your father was still alive, I would at once have known that Hemprabha meant grandfather instead of father.
('59', 446, 1, 5, 798551) But at the time I read Hemprabha’s letter I had forgotten altogether that your father was still alive.
