('59', 446, 4, 15, 799228) 618. LETTER TO V. S. R. SASTRI
('59', 446, 5, 16, 799259) March 5, 1933
('59', 446, 6, 17, 799273) DEAR FRIEND,
('59', 446, 7, 18, 799286) I have read your letter of 24th February from beginning to end with greatest attention.
('59', 446, 7, 19, 799374) Whilst I acknowledge the great pains you have bestowed over the composition and the Sanskrit learning which you exhibit, you will permit me to say that I miss the application of that learning to the reality, and it has been a matter of very deep grief to me that in the contact I am having with so many learned sanatanists, hardly any one of them has touched the fundamental points I have raised.
('59', 446, 7, 20, 799771) I state them for you.
('59', 446, 7, 21, 799793) Of all those who appear as untouchables in the census figures, who are the untouchables by birth?
('59', 446, 7, 22, 799891) Where is the authority in the Vedas for regarding them as such?
('59', 446, 7, 23, 799955) And if there is none in the Vedas, call the later Shastras impose disabilities or create classes not contemplated by the Vedas?
('59', 446, 7, 24, 800083) What is there in the Shastras to justify the numerous disabilities which I have described in the pages of the Harijan and which are suffered by those who are classified as untouchables?

('59', 453, 1, 31, 809614) I will admit all the shortcomings of the Ashram which you may point out.
('59', 453, 1, 32, 809687) But you will help me better if you also suggest suitable remedies at the same time.
('59', 453, 1, 33, 809771) Even if, however, you cannot do that, I must have your criticism.
('59', 453, 1, 34, 809837) I use my brain as much as I can.
('59', 453, 1, 35, 809870) I know this: the Ashram’s shortcomings are not its own, but mine.
('59', 453, 1, 36, 809936) If the potter makes an ill shaped pot, is that the fault of the pot or of the potter?
('59', 453, 1, 37, 810022) I literally believe what I have said, and the shortcomings of the Ashram, therefore, are a measure of my ignorance.
('59', 453, 1, 38, 810138) But notwithstan ding its shortcomings, I like the Ashram, for I am not ready to say positively that I do not like myself.
('59', 453, 1, 39, 810260) I like myself in the measure that I do not feel the sense of “I”, and ceaselessly strive to overcome what still remains of that sense.

('59', 464, 1, 2, 830815) 643. LETTER TO F. MARY BARR AND DUNCAN GREENLEES
('59', 464, 2, 3, 830864) March 8, 1933
('59', 464, 3, 4, 830878) MARY AND DUNCAN, I like your letter very much indeed.
('59', 464, 3, 5, 830932) Before I argue to the contrary, let me say what I have told Narandas and I think I made clear to both of you, that you should not be treated as the other learners who come to the Ashram, that you should take only such part in the Ashram work as you like and can digest and that you should use your time as may seem most profitable to you from your own standpoint.
('59', 464, 3, 6, 831296) Now for my own opinion.
('59', 464, 3, 7, 831320) The Ashram is a place where the idea is to enforce literally the maxim ‘to labour is to pray’.
('59', 464, 3, 8, 831415) This labour was interpreted by Thoreau and Tolstoy to mean physical labour and Tolstoy adopted Bondaref’s maxim of bread labour being God’s law for all mankind.
('59', 464, 3, 9, 831576) I read the same thing in the third chapter of the Gita.
('59', 464, 3, 10, 831632) I have tested the truth of the interpretation in my own life and in the lives of many companions and I have felt that our lives have been incomplete and unsatisfying exactly to the extent that we have failed to carry out the interpretation in practice.
('59', 464, 3, 11, 831885) Therefore I would say that, so long as the routine of the Ashram appears to be a slavish following of it, the spirit of tile Ashram is not imbibed.
('59', 464, 3, 12, 832033) I confess unhesitatingly that so few have imbibed the spirit.
('59', 464, 3, 13, 832095) Many follow the routine mechanically and, therefore, slavishly.
('59', 464, 3, 14, 832159) I do not grumble over the mechanical following, because even that is better than people idling away their time and I am not without hope that even those who are mechanically following the routine will some day detect the spirit and the beauty behind it.
('59', 464, 3, 15, 832413) So many Englishmen and women, especially missionaries, make, in my opinion, the tremendous mistake of directing the activity of others without themselves taking a direct part in it.
('59', 464, 3, 16, 832595) They, therefore, remain untouched by the activity itself and often become blind guides.
('59', 464, 3, 17, 832683) As I am dictating this, illustrations from life crowd in upon my mind.
('59', 464, 3, 18, 832754) I would, therefore, say that if you can appreciate and understand the spirit of my remarks and feel the truth of them, then follow the routine patiently, intelligently, whole heart edly, till it becomes a part of your nature, lies light upon your mind and seems to speak to you its message.
('59', 464, 3, 19, 833045) Then, but not tillthen, are you really able to write anything serious for public service.
('59', 464, 3, 20, 833135) Not even every good thought is worth giving to the world unless it is repeatedly tested on the anvil of experience.
('59', 464, 3, 21, 833251) All true labour is both contagious and
('59', 465, 0, 1, 833290) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 465, 1, 2, 833332) infectious.
('59', 465, 1, 3, 833344) I wonder if I have driven my meaning home.
('59', 465, 1, 4, 833387) If I have not, you must reject all my argument without the slightest hesitation and do exactly as you feel you should, so as to get the best out of your experience of the Ashram.
('59', 465, 1, 5, 833566) With loving blessings from BAPU From a photostat: G.N. 5996. Also C.W. 3321. Courtesy: F. Mary Barr

('59', 469, 3, 30, 842376) 649. MESSAGE ON WEDDING OF LAKSHMI AND MARUTI
('59', 469, 4, 31, 842422) March 8, 1933 I feel a little unhappy that neither Ba nor I will be present in the Ashram on the occasion of the wedding of Lakshmi and Maruti 3, but I think that is ignorant love.
('59', 469, 4, 32, 842603) One should feel happy wherever devotion to dharma may make it necessary for one to be.
('59', 469, 4, 33, 842690) Since one who
('59', 469, 5, 34, 842704) 1 Lakshmi’s parents.
('59', 469, 5, 35, 842725) The family joined the Ashram in 1915; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 16 9 1915 2 ibid
('59', 469, 6, 36, 842814) 3 A South Indian orphan boy, brought up by Velabehn and Lakshmidas Asar
('59', 470, 0, 1, 842886) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 471
('59', 470, 1, 2, 842931) follows dharma should never wish that things should be otherwise than they are, he can have no cause to feel unhappy.
('59', 470, 1, 3, 843049) Moreover, when so many elders and friends, men and women, will be assembling to give their blessings, Ba’s presence or mine should not be considered at all essential.
('59', 470, 1, 4, 843216) Lakshmi was of course eager that Ba and I should be present at her wedding.
('59', 470, 1, 5, 843292) So was Chi.
('59', 470, 1, 6, 843304) Maruti.
('59', 470, 1, 7, 843312) I could understand their desire.
('59', 470, 1, 8, 843345) But all of us felt that the marriage should take place without delay, and hence I advised both the bride and the bridegroom to have the wedding as soon as possible and they accepted my advice.
('59', 470, 1, 9, 843538) Lakshmi has been brought up in the Ashram since her childhood.
('59', 470, 1, 10, 843601) But we have not been able to educate and train her as well as the Ashram and I would have liked to do.
('59', 470, 1, 11, 843704) We did not, therefore, think it desirable to keep a girl in the bloom of youth unmarried for very long after betrothal.
('59', 470, 1, 12, 843824) The fact that Chi.

('59', 470, 1, 14, 843914) I regard Maruti as a very worthy young man.

('59', 470, 1, 17, 844058) He realizes the responsibility he is undertaking.
('59', 470, 1, 18, 844108) He will not only be a husband to Lakshmi, but will also be a friend and teacher to her.

('59', 470, 1, 21, 844447) Maruti and Chi.

('59', 470, 1, 29, 845135) Velabehn came to my help and suggested Maruti’s name.
('59', 470, 1, 30, 845189) Lakshmidas also liked the idea.
('59', 470, 1, 31, 845221) I put the suggestion to Lakshmi, and she, too, accepted it.
('59', 470, 1, 32, 845281) Her father also gave his consent and the two were betrothed.
('59', 470, 1, 33, 845342) In my opinion all that we did was in conformity with dharma.
('59', 470, 1, 34, 845403) I regard marriage too as a protective hedge
('59', 471, 0, 1, 845447) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 471, 1, 2, 845489) for dharma, and we should hope that the bride and the bridegroom also will regard it in the same light.
('59', 471, 1, 3, 845593) This marriage has no connection with the present movement.
('59', 471, 1, 4, 845652) Mixed marriages like this one are in no way a part of the movement for the removal of untouchability.
('59', 471, 1, 5, 845754) This marriage is a recognition of the point of view of one who believes in all the various ideals of the Ashram.
('59', 471, 1, 6, 845867) I hope that no one will misunderstand its significance because it is taking place at the present time when the movement for removal of untouchability is going on and because it is inspired by one who is the chief leader of that movement.
('59', 471, 1, 7, 846105) I do not hold up this marriage as an example for anybody to follow.
('59', 471, 1, 8, 846173) I regard marriage as a matter of the parents’ and their children’s free will.
('59', 471, 1, 9, 846251) I believe that there is ample support for this view in Hinduism.
('59', 471, 1, 10, 846316) However, it has no connection with the problem of the removal of untouchability.
('59', 471, 1, 11, 846397) The question belongs to another field of reform in Hinduism.
('59', 471, 1, 12, 846458) [Vandemataram] from
('59', 471, 2, 13, 846478) MOHANDAS
('59', 471, 3, 14, 846487) From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I. Also C.W. 8329. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('59', 471, 4, 15, 846573) 650. DRAFT CONSTITUTION OF THE HARIJAN SEVAK SANGH
('59', 471, 5, 16, 846624) [March 9, 1933] 1
('59', 471, 6, 17, 846642) The following resolution was adopted on behalf of what are known as caste Hindus by a meeting of their representatives from all India held at Bombay under the presidentship of Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya on 25th September, 1932. 2
('59', 471, 7, 18, 846873) This Conference resolves that henceforth, amongst Hindus, no one shall be regarded as an untouchable by reason of his birth and those who have been so regarded hitherto will have the same rights as the other Hindus in regard to the use of public wells, public roads and other public institutions.
('59', 471, 7, 19, 847170) This right shall have statutory recognition at the first opportunity and shall be one of the
('59', 471, 8, 20, 847263) 1 This is presumably the draft mentioned in “Letter to Amritlal V. Thakkar”, 14 3 1933. The Sunday previous to March 14 was March 9. The constitution was finally adopted with minor changes on January 2, 1935. Gandhiji says in the above letter that the draft was prepared by Mahadev Desai.
('59', 471, 8, 21, 847552) The portions of the original draft left after Gandhiji had revised it are underlined.
('59', 471, 8, 22, 847638) 2 Vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932.
('59', 472, 0, 1, 847711) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 473
('59', 472, 1, 2, 847756) earliest acts of the swaraj Parliament, if it shall not have received such recognition before that time.
('59', 472, 2, 3, 847861) It is further agreed that it shall be the duty of all Hindu leaders to secure, by every legitimate and peaceful means, an early removal of all social disabilities now imposed by custom upon the so called untouchable classes including the bar in respect of admission to temples.
('59', 472, 2, 4, 848139) This was followed up by a public meeting convened by the Hindu leaders from all parts of the country and held in Bombay on the 30th September, under the presidentship of Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, at which following resolution among others was passed:
('59', 472, 3, 5, 848393) This public meeting of the Hindus resolves that an All India Antiuntouchability League, with its headquarters at Delhi and branches in different provincial centres, be established for the purpose of carrying on propaganda against untouchability and that for this purpose the following steps should be immediately taken:
('59', 472, 4, 6, 848713) (a) All public wells, dharmsalas, roads, schools, crematoriums, burn ing ghats, etc., be declared open to depressed classes.
('59', 472, 5, 7, 848838) (b) All public temples be opened to members of depressed classes.
('59', 472, 5, 8, 848904) Provided that no compulsion or force shall be used with regard to (a) and (b), but peaceful persuasion will be adopted as the only means.
('59', 472, 6, 9, 849042) This public meeting of Hindus appeals to the Hindu community to collect as large an amount as possible to be used for the removal of untoucha bility and cognate objects and for this purpose authorizes the President and [the] Secretary to take all necessary steps.
('59', 472, 6, 10, 849306) In pursuance of the said resolutions a society, named the All India Anti untouchability League subsequently named as Harijan Sevak Sangh was duly formed and a constitution was adopted by it at [Delhi] on 26th [October, 1932].
('59', 472, 6, 11, 849532) It was then considered advisable to frame a fuller constitution and the following was finally adopted at a meeting of the central board of All India Harijan Sevak Sangh held at Delhi on .
('59', 472, 6, 12, 849720) superseding the previous constitution.
('59', 472, 7, 13, 849759) T HE C ONSTITUTION OF THE H ARIJAN S EVAK S ANGH

('59', 472, 10, 16, 849838) 1. The name of the Society will be Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('59', 472, 10, 17, 849894) 2. The object of the Sangh shall be the eradication by truthful
('59', 472, 11, 18, 849958) and non violent means of untouchability in Hindu Society with all its
('59', 473, 0, 1, 850028) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 473, 1, 2, 850070) incidental evils and disabilities, suffered by the so called untouchables hereinafter described as Harijans in all walks of life and to secure for them absolute equality of status with the rest of the Hindus.
('59', 473, 1, 3, 850279) 3. In furtherance of its objects the H. S. S. will seek to establish contact with caste Hindus throughout India and show them that untouchability as it is practised in Hindu society is repugnant to the Shastras and to the best instinct of humanity, and it will also seek to serve Harijans so as to promote their moral, social and material welfare.
('59', 473, 1, 4, 850627) 4. The affairs of the Sangh shall be managed by a Central Board
('59', 473, 2, 5, 850691) constituted as hereinafter provided.

('59', 475, 5, 10, 854875) 23. Any member of a board when required thereto fails to carry out instructions duly issued to him by a competent authority may be relieved of his office at the discretion of the Central or the Provincial Boards.
('59', 475, 5, 11, 855088) 24. Any person who subscribes to the object of the Sangh and will help the Sangh by paying and collecting contributions to the Sangh and otherwise further its object can become an associate of the Sangh and shall be kept informed of the proceedings of the Sangh from time to time and shall be entitled and invited to attend the meetings of the Central Board or of the Board of his Province without however the right of voting.
('59', 475, 5, 12, 855515) 25. ('59', 475, 5, 13, 855910) 26. ('59', 476, 1, 3, 856491) 28. The E. C. shall meet every three months and oftener when necessary and have all the power exercisable by the Central Board subject however to revision of its work by the Central Board in so far as such revision is possible.
('59', 476, 1, 4, 856719) The four members besides the President and Secretaries will subject to re selection retire every year.
('59', 476, 1, 5, 856822) 29. All the acts performed hitherto and transactions undertaken under the superseded constitution are hereby ratified.
('59', 476, 1, 6, 856941) 30. Consistently with the foregoing, the old constitution is hereby repealed—not inconsistently with the object of the Sangh, Central Board shall have the power to revise this Constitution from time to time.
('59', 476, 1, 7, 857149) 31. During the transition stage the existing organizations shall function till changes in consonance with this Constitution are completed.

('59', 478, 4, 8, 859913) 653. LETTER TO BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('59', 478, 5, 9, 859955) March 9, 1933 THE JOINT HON.
('59', 478, 5, 10, 859984) SECRETARIES BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION 18 BRITISH INDIAN STREET, CALCUTTA
('59', 478, 6, 11, 860058) DEAR FRIENDS, I thank you for your letter of 23rd ultimo enclosing a memorandum on the Poona Pact on behalf of the British Indian Asso ciation.
('59', 478, 6, 12, 860202) 2 I have been carrying on private correspondence with friends in this matter to ascertain Bengal opinion.
('59', 478, 6, 13, 860308) My own position is quite clear.
('59', 478, 6, 14, 860340) I was wholly uninterested in the number of seats reserved for untouchables or depressed classes.
('59', 478, 6, 15, 860437) Once the principle of reservation was conceded, my own position was that the more they got the better it was for them and for Hinduism and, therefore, for the whole of India from every point of view.
('59', 478, 6, 16, 860637) If untouchables are a part of ourselves, what can be grander than that we reserve seats for them without any
('59', 478, 7, 17, 860746) 1 The postscript appears only In the Shadow of the Mahatma, according to which source it was written in Hindi.
('59', 478, 7, 18, 860857) 2 The memorandum was prepared by a subcommittee, with Sir Bepin Bihary Ghose as its president” appointed by the All Parties Bengali Hindu Conference held on the January 11, 1933, in the hall of the British Indian Association.
('59', 478, 7, 19, 861083) The memorandum inter alia said: “It will thus be seen that the caste Hindus of Bengal are already smarting under a sense of injustice; and the Prime Minister’s acceptance of the Poona Pact comes as a sensible addition to their grievances.
('59', 478, 7, 20, 861322) Upon the basis of the facts set forth above, it is submitted that the Poona Pact did not fulfil the conditions for a substituted agreement laid down in the Prime Minister’s Award, and that, therefore, the Prime Minister has ample justification for re considering his assent to the same” (S.N. 20341 ) .
('59', 479, 0, 1, 861625) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 479, 1, 2, 861667) reservation.
('59', 479, 1, 3, 861680) That to my mind would be the very best method of killing the spirit of difference.
('59', 479, 1, 4, 861763) I wholly dissent from the view that the principle of separation is left intact in the Yeravda Pact 1. On the contrary, the principle of joint election has been the main feature of the Yeravda Pact so far as the political side is concerned.
('59', 479, 1, 5, 862003) That the candidates for joint election have to be selected by Harijan electors in the first instance is surely no drawback, if we have faith in ourselves and in our regard for them, and if all the four candidates selected happen to be anti Hindu reactionaries it would be to me proof positive that during the period of grace we had failed to command their affection or esteem and we would have to thank our stars if we have to elect from among reactionary candidates.
('59', 479, 1, 6, 862471) I do not in any way share your fear that depressed class members will not do justice to the Hindu or the national cause.
('59', 479, 1, 7, 862592) Nor have I any fear that they will not be able to discharge their proper function as representatives of the people.
('59', 479, 1, 8, 862708) Should it prove otherwise it will mean that we are not fit for swaraj.
('59', 479, 1, 9, 862779) All things considered, therefore, I fear that I can be no party to the revision of the Pact, and in any case I am only one of the parties concerned, and my opinion will be valueless if all the other parties consent to or desire revision of the Pact in the direction suggested by the British Indian Association.
('59', 479, 1, 10, 863090) As I do not wish to compromise your position in any way, I have not entered into a public discussion of your position nor will I do so now unless you wish me to.
('59', 479, 1, 11, 863252) The very first person I wrote to was, I think, Dr. Bidhan Roy, and he told me that he was seeing all the interested parties and that he would write to me.
('59', 479, 1, 12, 863407) I have not heard from him since.
('59', 479, 1, 13, 863440) I am now in your hands.
('59', 479, 1, 14, 863464) Yours sincerely,

('59', 480, 1, 2, 863680) 654. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('59', 480, 2, 3, 863719) March 9, 1933
('59', 480, 3, 4, 863733) DEAR SATISBABOO, I have your letter giving me the contents of the two issues of the Bengali Harijan.
('59', 480, 3, 5, 863834) You will see the note 1 that is to appear in the ensuing number of the Harijan.
('59', 480, 3, 6, 863914) I note what you say about smallpox.
('59', 480, 3, 7, 863950) I do not know however whether it is a useful thing for us to have statistics about the distribution of smallpox among different castes.
('59', 480, 3, 8, 864086) I am glad you are keeping in touch with sanatanists.
('59', 480, 3, 9, 864139) That they will not listen to the other things until we give up temple entry is well known.
('59', 480, 3, 10, 864230) My suggestion is before them that they should start their own organizations and take up the other items.
('59', 480, 3, 11, 864335) If they don’t, it shows the hypocrisy of the whole thing.
('59', 480, 3, 12, 864393) As to varnashrama, I do mean that today if we must classify the whole of Hindus according to varna, there is only one varna possible, and that is Shudra.
('59', 480, 3, 13, 864547) Acceptance of the fourth varna by all will repre sent not only the true state of Hindu society, but it will at one stroke level down all distinctions of high and low.
('59', 480, 3, 14, 864714) That does not prevent anybody from attaining divine or any other knowledge, but it does mean that all live by their labour and all become entitled therefore to nothing more than simple maintenance.
('59', 480, 3, 15, 864912) That in my opinion is varna dharma in a nutshell.
('59', 480, 3, 16, 864962) That Hinduism has never lived up to it perfectly is true, but in my opinion it is equally true that Hinduism has in its purest period consciously lived up to it with success.
('59', 480, 3, 17, 865137) Yours sincerely,

('59', 487, 3, 4, 875776) NARANDAS,
('59', 487, 4, 5, 875786) I send with this my reply 1 to the question asked by Mary and Duncan.
('59', 487, 4, 6, 875856) Read and think over it and then pass it on to them.
('59', 487, 4, 7, 875908) I wrote to you 2 yesterday regarding Lakshmi and also sent a message for the occasion.
('59', 487, 4, 8, 875995) Most probably Devdas will arrive there on Sunday.
('59', 487, 5, 9, 876045) I am becoming convinced that the source of asthma also is in the stomach.
('59', 487, 5, 10, 876119) If, therefore, Chimanlal and Jamna cling to the experiment of milk diet with determination, their asthma is bound to be cured.
('59', 487, 5, 11, 876246) And they need not also think that they must drink a certain quantity of milk.
('59', 487, 5, 12, 876324) I think that they will be able to digest only a very small quantity.
('59', 487, 5, 13, 876393) Milk is drunk for the sake of the proteins, the ghee and the vitamins which it contains.
('59', 487, 5, 14, 876482) If proteins give strength, they also diminish it if there is the slightest excess of them.
('59', 487, 5, 15, 876573) Weak people, therefore, can build up strength by drinking milk in a very small quantity.
('59', 487, 5, 16, 876662) The chief food of such people should be vegetables and juicy fruits.
('59', 487, 5, 17, 876731) Without trying other remedies, therefore, if they eat bhaji and juicy fruits in plenty and drink a very small quantity of milk for strength, they are bound to get all right.
('59', 487, 5, 18, 876905) And if this regimen does not help them, I will not mind their concluding that nothing else will and doing nothing.
('59', 487, 5, 19, 877020) They should drink the milk unboiled and mixed with some fruit or green vegetable.
('59', 487, 5, 20, 877102) In doing so, they would be eating milk instead of drinking it, and it will then be much easier to digest.
('59', 487, 5, 21, 877208) They should also regularly do pranayamas, slowly and moderately, on an empty stomach.
('59', 487, 5, 22, 877294) Besides, they should take sun bath.
('59', 487, 5, 23, 877330) In this season, hip bath also is bound to be beneficial.
('59', 487, 6, 24, 877387) I have looked into Radha’s accounts.
('59', 487, 6, 25, 877424) I am returning them.
('59', 487, 6, 26, 877445) I think in the present circumstances we are helpless in this matter.

('59', 490, 4, 5, 881298) January 13, 1933
('59', 490, 5, 6, 881315) BAPU: Even after this Bill is passed the majority should not exercise their
('59', 490, 6, 7, 881391) right to frighten away the minority.
('59', 490, 6, 8, 881428) The temple should be kept open for a few hours
('59', 490, 7, 9, 881475) daily for the sake of the minority.
('59', 490, 7, 10, 881511) They too have a certain sentiment for the image

('59', 490, 8, 12, 881600) I would say to them that they should have darshan to their heart’s content before the temple becomes ‘impure’; I would go in
('59', 490, 9, 13, 881725) after that.
('59', 490, 10, 14, 881737) SADASHIVRAO: But would it not hurt their inferiority complex?
('59', 490, 11, 15, 881799) BAPU: The question of inferiority arises only in the case of Harijans.
('59', 490, 11, 16, 881870) If the reformists are in a majority, the Harijans should act like seniors, and should do out of their free will what they are not bound to do by law.
('59', 490, 12, 17, 882020) I don’t want separate temples erected.
('59', 490, 12, 18, 882059) But I would say to them [the sanatanists]: ‘I shall make the necessary arrangement for you.
('59', 490, 12, 19, 882151) You should not go away.
('59', 490, 12, 20, 882175) I do not want to pay you in the same coin.
('59', 490, 12, 21, 882218) You had regarded us as low.

('59', 490, 13, 24, 882331) regard you as low.
('59', 490, 13, 25, 882350) We shall let you precede us and we shall respect your sentiments regarding the purity of the image.’ Man compromises either through weakness or because he is strong.
('59', 490, 13, 26, 882516) As a votary of truth I would make a compromise on the basis of my strength.
('59', 490, 13, 27, 882592) Only yesterday I dealt with the sanatanists in this way.
('59', 490, 13, 28, 882649) They asked me to sign some document.
('59', 490, 13, 29, 882686) Normally I would not endorse such a statement.
('59', 490, 13, 30, 882733) But in order to satisfy them I affixed my signature, but after making a couple of most essential changes.
('59', 490, 13, 31, 882839) If I disclose what took place between them and me, it is not going to shed lustre on Hinduism.
('59', 490, 14, 32, 882934) I have learnt a lot from my involvement in this issue.
('59', 490, 14, 33, 882989) I came to know what the Shastras had to say.
('59', 490, 14, 34, 883034) Without knowing all this I could not have issued such statements.
('59', 490, 14, 35, 883100) I would not have at any rate been able to write with such authority.
('59', 490, 14, 36, 883169) Even the thought of this compromise would not have occurred to me had I not had all these interviews with them.

('59', 491, 1, 2, 883504) raise objections are insincere.
('59', 491, 1, 3, 883536) I don’t want to drive them out of the temples.
('59', 491, 1, 4, 883583) The lives of those who go to temples with a sincere heart are linked with the temples.
('59', 491, 1, 5, 883670) I say this on the strength of my mother’s example.
('59', 491, 1, 6, 883721) She would not put a grain in her mouth without having darshan in a temple, however ill and bed ridden she might be.
('59', 491, 2, 7, 883837) She used to derive strength from this practice of hers.
('59', 491, 2, 8, 883893) I do not want to exercise the right I have acquired as though I were a demon or a bully.
('59', 491, 2, 9, 883982) I have to give a thought to a true mother.
('59', 491, 2, 10, 884025) All the women who visit temples are but mothers to me.
('59', 491, 2, 11, 884080) If they want to preserve the purity [of the images], they may do so.
('59', 491, 2, 12, 884149) The Harijans should be charitable enough to let them do it.
('59', 491, 2, 13, 884209) In fact they should let them do it of their own free will.
('59', 491, 2, 14, 884268) Take the instance of spectacles and injections which are in vogue.
('59', 491, 2, 15, 884335) Our ancestors would regard these as superstitions.
('59', 491, 2, 16, 884386) Tomorrow there may come up somebody who may regard praying as so much superstition.
('59', 491, 2, 17, 884470) Even then we ought to respect people’s sentiments.
('59', 491, 2, 18, 884521) Therefore the compromise I have suggested is absolutely correct.

('59', 492, 4, 5, 886034) Q. What is meant by the Inner Voice?
('59', 492, 5, 6, 886071) A. The Inner Voice is the voice of the Lord.
('59', 492, 5, 7, 886116) It is a voice other than our own.
('59', 492, 5, 8, 886150) It could be the voice of Satan or of God.
('59', 492, 5, 9, 886192) In order to ensure that it is God that speaks from within us, we should correctly observe the yamas and niyamas.
('59', 492, 5, 10, 886305) Millions of men may claim to hear the Inner Voice but the true Inner Voice could be heard in very few.
('59', 492, 5, 11, 886408) We cannot adduce proof in its support.
('59', 492, 5, 12, 886447) But it does have its influence.
('59', 492, 5, 13, 886479) The Inner Voice is a power beyond us but it is not an outer force.
('59', 492, 5, 14, 886546) ‘Beyond us’ means ‘a power which is beyond our ego’.
('59', 492, 5, 15, 886599) When the ego is lying dormant there are two forces which act upon it, the real and the unreal.
('59', 492, 5, 16, 886694) When we are one with the power that is real it is said, in the language of mysticism, that God is speaking through us.
('59', 492, 5, 17, 886813) When we are one with sat our ego is reduced to zero.
('59', 492, 6, 18, 886866) Q. When can man claim to have heard the Inner Voice?
('59', 492, 7, 19, 886919) BAPU: That depends upon the man.
('59', 492, 7, 20, 886952) When he experiences that he is not acting on his own he can make that claim.
('59', 492, 7, 21, 887029) Supposing I constantly try to hear the Inner Voice, I constantly pray to God that He should act through me and reduce me to a cipher, a moment will come when I shall feel that the Lord is letting me hear Him.
('59', 492, 7, 22, 887238) At such a time I can even say that I am hearing the voice of the Lord.
('59', 492, 7, 23, 887309) But how can I prove it?
('59', 492, 7, 24, 887333) It is for my conduct to prove it.
('59', 492, 7, 25, 887367) But that too will not be the final test.
('59', 492, 7, 26, 887408) Supposing a man lies buried in a cave in the Himalayas and God sends me there to see him.
('59', 492, 7, 27, 887498) Supposing I reach the place, I dig a little and meet the man.
('59', 492, 7, 28, 887560) Even then quite likely it may not be that I heard the Inner Voice.
('59', 492, 7, 29, 887627) It could be a mere accident or even my illusion or someone might have said it to me.
('59', 492, 7, 30, 887712) The world will no doubt judge me from the result.
('59', 492, 7, 31, 887762) If the result is favourable the world will say that it was a miracle.
('59', 492, 7, 32, 887832) But indeed there can be no final proof in this case.
('59', 492, 7, 33, 887885) Man himself does not know when he is deceiving himself, or when he is pretending.
('59', 492, 7, 34, 887967) There is a greater danger in hypocrisy than in self deception.
('59', 492, 7, 35, 888030) We find further proof when there are many instances pointing towards the same conclusion.
('59', 492, 7, 36, 888120) This includes all the great men, Buddha, Krishna, Mohammed.
('59', 492, 7, 37, 888180) It was not with their own power that they uttered the truths.
('59', 492, 7, 38, 888242) But some occult power urged them to such utterance.
('59', 492, 7, 39, 888294) Some people are worthy enough, and through them the occult power works.
('59', 492, 7, 40, 888366) But we cannot be sure when it will happen.
('59', 492, 8, 41, 888409) [From Gujarati]

('59', 497, 12, 22, 899925) January 14, 1933
('59', 497, 13, 23, 899942) “Sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof” cryptically remarked Mahatma
('59', 497, 14, 24, 900017) Gandhi when your correspondent met him this afternoon in the shade of a mango tree
('59', 497, 15, 25, 900100) in the jail compound and asked him what would be his attitude if the Government
('59', 497, 16, 26, 900180) decided on some dilatory course of action to gain time and refused immediate sanction

('59', 498, 3, 7, 901566) APPENDIX V
('59', 498, 4, 8, 901577) STATEMENT BY MADAN MOHAN MALAVIYA1
('59', 498, 5, 9, 901612) The object of the special session of the Sanatana Dharma Mahasabha is to focus and voice the most informed and most esteemable orthodox opinion on some questions, including those relating to the removal of untouchability and temple entry which has been agitating the sanatanist world on one side, and those who are described as reformers on the other.
('59', 498, 5, 10, 901964) I have been distressed to note differences between the two sides becoming acute, and it is evident that if these differences are unsolved, the Hindu community would be further divided and weakened.
('59', 498, 5, 11, 902162) The differences are largely due to misunderstanding, and this, in its turn, is due to a great extent on imperfect knowledge of what the Shastras have laid down for our guidance in important matters in question.
('59', 498, 5, 12, 902373) It should not be necessary to say that Mahatma Gandhi cannot desire to injure sanatana dharma.
('59', 498, 5, 13, 902468) He has proved to the world that he is willing and determined to throw away even his life in the attempt to serve the country by removing disabilities under which the vast number of those who belong to it labour, so that they may enjoy the full benefit of being Hindus and remain contented and happy members of the community.
('59', 498, 6, 14, 902793) It is equally necessary to say that sanatanists who do not agree with Mahatma Gandhi’s proposals or methods are not wanting in sympathy with the depressed classes.
('59', 498, 6, 15, 902957) This being so, I am confident that it is possible to arrive at a solution of the problem in conformity with the Shastras which should be acceptable to both sections of sanatanist opinion—more advanced and less advanced—and which should establish peace and religious unity among the Hindu community on a basis that will endure.
('59', 498, 7, 16, 903284) From statements recently made by Mahatma Gandhi, it is clear that he is not only willing, but anxious to show every respect for the orthodox opinion.
('59', 498, 8, 17, 903434) 1 Vide “Letter to Madan Mohan Malaviya”, 20 1 1933 and “Agreeing to Differ”, 18 2 1933
('59', 499, 0, 1, 903521) 500 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 499, 1, 2, 903563) From utterances of several esteemed exponents of sanatana dharma, it is also clear that they are willing to move forward to bring about an understanding which will be consistent with the Shastras.
('59', 499, 1, 3, 903760) This being so, I believe that, by dispassionate consideration of the Shastras by those who claim to expound them, it will be generally conceded, rules of action can be laid down which would secure the most liberal and practicable advance for the humblest Hindu and satisfaction to the most orthodox conservative opinion which is willing to act in conformity not merely with the letter, but also with the spirit of the Shastras.
('59', 499, 1, 4, 904188) I have convened the Mahasabha with the conviction that such a unity can be brought about among the sanatanist Hindus and appeal to all of them to make such contribution to the success of this effort as lies in their power.
('59', 499, 2, 5, 904411) To prevent misunderstanding, I wish to make the position clear.
('59', 499, 2, 6, 904475) Speaking in 1923 as the President of the Hindu Mahasabha of Holy Kashi in the presence of great gathering of learned and pious men, I pleaded that opportunity should be afforded even to the humblest Hindu to have a purifying and ennobling darshan of the deity
('59', 499, 3, 7, 904735) whom we adore in our temples and offer his prayer to Him.
('59', 499, 3, 8, 904793) I urged that this may be done in conformity with rules which may be laid down in that behalf and further urged that other disabilities from which the depressed classes suffered should be removed.
('59', 499, 3, 9, 904989) I still hold the same opinion and have publicly repeated it many times during the last few years and last few months, but have never been able to approve of recourse to satyagraha with the object of getting the temple opened to the depressed classes.
('59', 499, 3, 10, 905240) I do not think it right that this kind of pressure should be exerted in a matter where religious convictions and practices come into play.
('59', 499, 3, 11, 905379) Those who adhere to the orthodox view have also got their convictions which are deep seated and come down through the ages.
('59', 499, 3, 12, 905503) I believe that it is the sacred duty of those of us who differ from them to do our best to bring about a change of those convictions.
('59', 499, 3, 13, 905637) But by the very nature of the case, this duty demands that we should attempt it by resort to peaceful persuasion only.
('59', 499, 4, 14, 905756) This was laid down in a resolution which was passed by the Bombay public meeting held immediately after the Poona Pact over which I presided, and at which, the All India Anti untouchability League was established for the purpose of carrying on propaganda against untouchability.
('59', 499, 4, 15, 906035) That resolution stated that “for this purpose steps should immediately be taken to secure as early as possible that (a) all public wells, schools, roads, sarais, dharmashalas, crematoriums, burning ghats, etc., should be declared open to the depressed classes and (b) all public temples should be open to members of the depressed classes provided that for carrying out (a) and (b) no force or compulsion be used but resort shall be had only to peaceful persuasion.” It is both just and expedient that the solution of such a question should be one that would satisfy the community as a whole.
('59', 499, 4, 16, 906627) In my opinion, such a solution can be reached only
('59', 500, 0, 1, 906678) VOL. 59 : 13 JANUARY, 1933 9 MARCH, 1933 501
('59', 500, 1, 2, 906723) by the method of argument and persuasion with the help of those scholars who are versed in the Shastras and who desire the good of every section of the community.
('59', 500, 1, 3, 906886) It is to bring about such an agreement and solution that I have invited the special session of the Sanatana Dharma Mahasabha, and I am hoping and praying too that God will bless the attempt and crown it with success.
('59', 500, 2, 4, 907103) Towards this end, I intend to place the following concrete proposal before the Mahasabha, that for the uplift of the depressed classes, the following plan may be adopted: 
('59', 500, 3, 5, 907275) 1 (a) Samskar and updesh—initiation and instruction—known as diksha.
('59', 500, 3, 6, 907344) This will consist (a) of prayashchittam—penance and purification;
('59', 500, 4, 7, 907410) (b) tyag—giving up carrion and beef, leavings of dishes (uchchhishta), wine;
('59', 500, 5, 8, 907487) (c) diksha—receiving mantram, either ashtakshar mantram (with or without wearing tulsi bead); panchakshar mantram (with or without wearing rudraksha bead);
('59', 500, 6, 9, 907643) (d) Achara grahana—daily bath and daily prayer (morning and evening), daily
('59', 500, 7, 10, 907719) reading of the sacred book (teaching every man, woman and child to read and write will be an integral part of the scheme);
('59', 500, 8, 11, 907842) (e) vrata—vows—observing five necessary vows which are prescribed for all castes, ahimsa, satya, asteya, shaucham and indriyanigraha, (hurtlessness, truth,
('59', 500, 9, 12, 907998) non stealing, purity of body and mind, and control of senses);
('59', 500, 10, 13, 908061) 2 (a) freedom to join public meetings and public schools;
('59', 500, 11, 14, 908119) (b) use of public wells, roads, parks, sarais, dharmashalas, burning ghats, etc.; and
('59', 500, 12, 15, 908205) (c) entry into public temples for devadarshana and stuti.
('59', 500, 13, 16, 908263) If the scheme is approved, the giving of diksha should be completed
('59', 500, 14, 17, 908331) within a month.
('59', 500, 14, 18, 908347) The carrying out of this scheme will mean a great social, religious and spiritual uplift of the classes.
('59', 500, 14, 19, 908452) It will mean making them Harijans in the full sense of the term.
('59', 500, 14, 20, 908517) This will be only one of the proposals to be placed before the gathering of Acharyas and learned men.
('59', 500, 14, 21, 908619) There will be many proposals before them for their consideration.
('59', 500, 14, 22, 908685) There is every hope that with God’s grace result of deliberations will be one which will be welcomed with joy by all followers of sanatana dharma and all well wishers of humanity.
('59', 500, 15, 23, 908865) The Bombay Chronicle, 19 1 1933

('59', 505, 7, 30, 920341) Whenever they have a doubt in their mind they try to believe that there must be God’s hand behind.
('59', 505, 7, 31, 920440) Andrews had written to me several times expressing his doubts.
('59', 505, 7, 32, 920503) Afterwards he wired to me cancelling all his letters and assured me that he had then understood the whole thing correctly.
('59', 505, 8, 33, 920626) Alluding to people’s superstitions, Rajaji said: Some people really believe that hitherto Gandhiji used to bring the rains but now he is committing an act owing to which the rains may fail.
('59', 505, 9, 34, 920816) BAPU: You are talking about the ignorant people.

('59', 506, 1, 2, 921152) BAPU: My present feeling is that the possibility of the fast is not very far away.

('59', 506, 4, 8, 921785) BAPU: It is difficult to tell.

('59', 506, 7, 20, 922559) LETTER FROM GOVERNMENT OF INDIA1
('59', 506, 8, 21, 922592) [Before February 17, 1933]
('59', 506, 9, 22, 922619) The Governor General in Council has carefully considered the points urged by Mr. Gandhi in his letter of the 1st February 1933, addressed to the Private Secretary to the Viceroy, in which he requests that, for the reasons stated therein, the Government of India should facilitate the progress and passage of the Bills regarding temple entry, which will be introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Ranga Iyer and others.
('59', 506, 9, 23, 923032) He is unable to accept the arguments developed by Mr. Gandhi relating to the Poona Pact, and notes that the Resolution he has quoted did not form part of the Pact as communicated to the Government of India.
('59', 506, 9, 24, 923239) In the matter of the Pact, Government
('59', 506, 10, 25, 923277) 1 This was received on February 17. Vide “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 1 2 1933, “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 17 2 1933 and “Letter to Home Secretary, Government of India”, 19 2 1933
('59', 507, 0, 1, 923455) 508 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 507, 1, 2, 923497) were concerned merely to accept a modification of the representation in the Legislatures which had been provided in the Communal Award by His Majesty’s Government.
('59', 507, 1, 3, 923661) But quite apart from the Pact, the Government for many years have taken an active interest in the improvement of the conditions under which the depressed classes live.
('59', 507, 1, 4, 923829) That interest has been directed to the matters referred to in the Resolution which he quotes, such as education and the provision of the normal facilities of life, which were placed in the forefront of the Resolution but appear not to be regarded by him as the vital part of it.
('59', 507, 1, 5, 924108) The Government have naturally taken no initiative in matters which specifically affect religious practice.
('59', 507, 1, 6, 924215) In regard to that, they have nothing to add to the statement issued to the Press on 23rd January.
('59', 507, 1, 7, 924313) They must reiterate that in their opinion it is essential that the consideration of a measure, which so closely affects the religious customs and usages of the Hindu community, should not proceed unless the proposals are subjected to the fullest examination in all their aspects, not merely in the Legislatures, but also outside it, by all who will be affected by them.
('59', 507, 1, 8, 924683) This purpose can only be satisfied if the Bill is circulated in the widest manner for the purpose of eliciting public opinion, and if adequate time is given to enable all classes of Hindus to form and express their considered views.

('59', 512, 21, 29, 937066) APPENDIX XIII
('59', 512, 22, 30, 937080) B. R. AMBEDKAR’S STATEMENT1
('59', 512, 23, 31, 937108) Although the controversy regarding the question of temple entry is confined to the sanatanists and Mahatma Gandhi, the Depressed Classes have undoubtedly a very important part to play in it, in so far as their position is bound to weigh the scale one way or the other, when the issue comes for a final settlement.
('59', 512, 23, 32, 937422) It is, therefore, necessary that their viewpoint should be defined and stated so as to leave no ambiguity about it.
('59', 512, 24, 33, 937538) To the Temple entry Bill of Mr. Ranga Iyer as now drafted, the Depressed Classes cannot possibly give their support.
('59', 512, 24, 34, 937655) The principle of the Bill is that if a majority of municipal and local board voters in the vicinity of any particular temple on a referendum decide by a majority that the Depressed Classes shall be allowed to enter the temple, the trustees or the manager of the temple shall give effect to that decision.
('59', 512, 24, 35, 937960) The principle is an ordinary principle of majority rule, and there is nothing
('59', 512, 25, 36, 938038) 1 Vide “Interview to Associated Press”, 14 2 1933 and “Letter to C. Rajagopalachari”, 22 2 1933
('59', 513, 0, 1, 938134) 514 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('59', 513, 1, 2, 938176) radical or revolutionary about the Bill, and if the sanatanists were a wise lot they would accept it without demur.
('59', 513, 2, 3, 938292) The reasons why the Depressed Classes cannot support a Bill based upon this principle are two.
('59', 513, 2, 4, 938387) One reason is that the Bill cannot hasten the day of temple entry for the Depressed Classes any nearer than otherwise would be the case.
('59', 513, 2, 5, 938524) It is true that under the Bill, the minority will not have the right to obtain an injunction against the trustee, or the manager who throws open the temple to the Depressed Classes in accordance with the decision of the majority.
('59', 513, 2, 6, 938754) But before one can draw any satisfaction from this clause and congratulate the author of the Bill, one must first of all feel assured that when the question is put to the vote, there will be a majority in favour of templeentry.
('59', 513, 2, 7, 938982) If one is not suffering from illusions of any kind, one must accept that the hope of a majority voting in favour of temple entry will be very rarely realized if at all.
('59', 513, 2, 8, 939151) Without doubt, the majority is definitely opposed today—a fact which is conceded by the author of the Bill himself in his correspondence with the Shankaracharya.
('59', 513, 3, 9, 939313) What is there in the situation as created after the passing of the Bill, which can lead one to hope that the majority will act differently?
('59', 513, 3, 10, 939453) I find nothing.
('59', 513, 3, 11, 939469) I shall, no doubt, be reminded of the results of the referendum with regard to the Guruvayur Temple.
('59', 513, 3, 12, 939570) But I refuse to accept a referendum, so overweighted as it was by the life of Mahatma Gandhi, as the normal result.
('59', 513, 3, 13, 939686) In any such calculations, the life of the Mahatma must necessarily be deducted.
('59', 513, 4, 14, 939766) If Hindu religion is to be a religion of social equality, then an amendment of its code to provide temple entry is not enough.
('59', 513, 4, 15, 939893) What is required is to purge it of the doctrine of chaturvarnya.
('59', 513, 5, 16, 939958) The Bombay Chronicle, 13 2 1933

('59', 514, 1, 2, 940470) I am following of course with great interest your campaign against untouchability, as far as I can from The statesman and the Pioneer.
('59', 514, 1, 3, 940605) Anything that you

('59', 514, 3, 8, 940899) My suggestion about a short holiday in Ceylon was made chiefly in the interest of Krishna.
('59', 514, 3, 9, 940990) I am a little worried about her.
('59', 514, 3, 10, 941023) After a year in prison, with our home practically broken up, she feels rather at a loose end and does not know what to do.
('59', 514, 3, 11, 941146) Ever since her childhood the poor girl has been deprived of real home life and proper education because of our preoccupations and repeated visits to prison.
('59', 514, 3, 12, 941303) She grew up a rather lonely girl not having as much friendship and sympathy as she was entitled to.
('59', 514, 4, 13, 941403) Father’s death shook her up a great deal.
('59', 514, 4, 14, 941445) I tried to soothe her and win her confidence and I am glad to say that I succeeded to some extent.
('59', 514, 4, 15, 941544) But 1931 was for all of us a year full of work and worry and anxiety.
('59', 514, 4, 16, 941614) Then came a long spell of prison for her, and for a young girl this was a far greater ordeal than it could be for most of us.
('59', 514, 4, 17, 941740) As her release drew near I sensed how she must be feeling and how life in Anand Bhawan as it is today would be no joy to her.
('59', 514, 4, 18, 941866) She would feel out of joint.
('59', 514, 4, 19, 941895) She would want to do something and yet not know what to do, and this would rob her of peace of mind.
('59', 514, 4, 20, 941996) I was myself not clear what to suggest to her.
('59', 514, 4, 21, 942043) Latterly she has begun to look upon me almost as a kind of refuge in a friendless world.
('59', 514, 4, 22, 942132) If I had been out I might have been of help to her but I could do little from Dehra Dun Jail.
('59', 514, 5, 23, 942226) I felt that a short holiday in neutral surroundings would ease her mind and remove the tension.
('59', 514, 5, 24, 942322) Hence my proposal about Ceylon.
('59', 514, 5, 25, 942354) Three weeks in Ceylon would not have solved any problem but she would have freshened up and returned with a brighter outlook on life.
('59', 514, 5, 26, 942488) These were my reasons.
('59', 514, 5, 27, 942511) I was thinking more of mental health than of physical health.
('59', 514, 5, 28, 942573) But the proposal seems to have fallen through as nobody seems to be keen on it.
('59', 514, 5, 29, 942653) In the present, therefore, Ceylon is off.

('59', 514, 7, 35, 943021) had been very discourteous to Mother and Kamala and I felt that I had no alternative; besides I have not yet got rid of my obstinacy—a hereditary failing in me of which you cannot be unaware.

('59', 516, 7, 7, 946681) TALK WITH MATHURADAS1
('59', 516, 8, 8, 946703) February 18, 1933
('59', 516, 9, 9, 946721) [BAPU]: It is true that according to the Vedas the Shudras have no privileges; mainly they speak of only three varnas.
('59', 516, 9, 10, 946840) However, the Vedas which are available to us are not the only ones.
('59', 516, 9, 11, 946908) Of the thousands of books only a few have come down to us.
('59', 516, 9, 12, 946967) There is religion as well as history in the Vedas.
('59', 516, 9, 13, 947018) And history is not religion.
('59', 516, 9, 14, 947047) The part dealing with religion is timeless and eternal whereas the one dealing with history describes the circumstances then prevailing.
('59', 516, 9, 15, 947184) Who knows how long I have to live?
('59', 516, 9, 16, 947219) But if I had no other task to demand my attention, I would certainly wish to take up the work of varnashramadharma.
('59', 516, 9, 17, 947335) But the establishment of varnadharma needs the foundation of ashramadharma without which the whole structure would necessarily be weak.
('59', 516, 9, 18, 947471) There is contentment at the root of varnashramadharma.
('59', 516, 9, 19, 947526) It implies willing acceptance of one’s dharma and karma.
('59', 516, 9, 20, 947583) Therefore varnashramadharma is a divine way of life whereas all the others are demoniac ones.
('59', 516, 9, 21, 947677) Varnashramadharma has nobility as its predominant quality whereas the others are dominated by calculated selfishness.
('59', 516, 10, 22, 947795) Once this law is understood many other things will follow.
('59', 516, 10, 23, 947854) If we know how to drink water but do not know the science behind it, then it is of no use.
('59', 516, 10, 24, 947945) If we know the various forms of water such as snow, vapour and hydro electricity, then we can be said to have understood the science of water.
('59', 516, 10, 25, 948088) Similar is the case with varnashrama.
('59', 516, 10, 26, 948126) This is a principle applicable in all cases.
('59', 516, 11, 27, 948171) [M.D.]: In other words, as Muslims claim that Islam means peace, and that it is the universal law meant for the whole world, you say that varnashramadharma is the universal law.
('59', 516, 12, 28, 948349) BAPU: Yes, it is in the same sense.
('59', 516, 12, 29, 948385) Every religion has some eternal principles and the followers of a particular religion follow their dharma in that measure.
('59', 516, 12, 30, 948508) The rest of their religion is related to the circumstances of time and place.
('59', 516, 13, 31, 948586) I would give up varnashramadharma this very day, were it not connected with
('59', 516, 14, 32, 948662) 1 Vide “Letter to Motilal Roy”, 18 2 1933.

('59', 517, 1, 2, 948747) What would otherwise be left in it?
('59', 517, 1, 3, 948783) I would maintain that the correct thing would be that the son of a carpenter should be a carpenter and not a blacksmith.
('59', 517, 1, 4, 948904) If as a result there are to be hundreds of castes, let there be.
('59', 517, 1, 5, 948969) So long as there is inter dining and intermarrying among them let there be any number of castes.
('59', 517, 1, 6, 949066) The restrictions about dining and marriage have turned the whole thing into a wretched affair.
('59', 517, 2, 7, 949161) I would certainly say that Dronacharya had fallen from dharma.
('59', 517, 2, 8, 949224) What I mean is not that a member of one varna may never follow the profession of another varna, but that it is not proper.
('59', 517, 2, 9, 949347) This varnashramadharma as I propound it is for everybody to follow not blindly but after due deliberation.
